		<date>2005-03-18</date>
		<username>zardoz-13</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The people who made "King Arthur" strive to live down the legend.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Anybody who knows anything about the history of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table in the cinema knows that English director John Boorman staged the best version of the Arthurian myth in 1981 in his classic sword &amp; sorcery saga "Excalibur." Before "Excalibur" set the gold standard, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer produced as their first widescreen film "Knights of the Round Table" (1953) in blazing Technicolor with Robert Taylor and Ava Gardner. The 1967 musical "Camelot" featured Richard Harris as Arthur and Vanessa Redgrave as Guinevere and the serviceable 1995 Sean Connery/Richard Gere swashbuckler "First Knight" both deserve honorable mention. Any of these four, however, would eclipse the latest rehash of the Arthur legend. Not only do "Training Day" director Antoine Fuqua, "Gladiator" scripter David Franzoni and "Pearl Harbor" producer Jerry Bruckheimer strip the luster off the legend in their new movie "King Arthur" (** out of ****), but also they forego full-blown fantasy for half-baked fact. Based on 'recent archaeological findings,' Fuqua, Franzoni and Bruckheimer have revised the fable, so they can tell 'the untold true story that inspired the legend' in their tedious, long-winded, grimy, 130-minute mishmash of British mythology. Romance takes a back seat to the shoddily choreographed action sequences, and to preserve a PG-13 rating the filmmakers could only show blood on the combatant's swords. This time around Merlin appears as a wise elder with zero magical powers, while Guinevere emerges as a feisty battle maiden dressed up as a dominatrix packing a sword or a bow in either hand. Despite its mostly-Brit cast led by actor Clive Owen in a sterling performance as Arthur and "Black Hawk Down" lenser Slawomir Idziak's atmospheric cinematography, "King Arthur" does everything wrong in its misguided effort to create a new, different, and more realistic Arthur."King Arthur" concerns itself with the roots of the Round Table. In this handsomely produced but hackneyed hokum, we learn that the mythical Arthur owes everything to a real person who lived back in the Dark Ages during the Fifth Century. This Arthur (Clive Owen of "Beyond Borders") is a Roman officer in command of an elite cavalry unit consisting of guys from Sarmatia (somewhere near the modern Republic of Georgia in Europe) who made a pact with Marcus Aurelius to serve in his army for fifteen years. Imagine a gritty, down-to-earth "Magnificent Seven" as knights on horseback, and you'll have an idea what to expect. As the story unfolds, our heroes await their walking papers as Arthur discusses terms with Roman Bishop Germanius (Ivan Marescotti of "Hannibal"). The Bishop cooks up a last-minute suicide mission for Arthur and his knights that requires them to cross Hadrian's Wall and liberate a Roman family living on a farm in the middle of enemy country. The savage Saxon hordes, like the Apaches in a western, are descending from every quarter, and the Romans are pulling out, so the Bishop needs somebody expendable. After Arthur and his knights reach the farm, they discover the slimy Roman has natives holed up in a dungeon where he tortures them in the name of the Vatican. A wizened shaman named Merlin advises these rebellious Woads, and Guinevere (Keira Knightley of "Pirates of the Caribbean") is one of them, locked up and tormented until Arthur sets her free. Now, our heroes must escort this motley crew through treacherous territory with the murderous Saxons breathing down their necks every inch of the way.The chief problem with "King Arthur" lies in David Franzoni's dreadful screenplay. The rescue mission on which Arthur and the knights embark resembles an uninspired 1950's era cavalry western. Interestingly, the rescue recalls Fuqua's lackluster last opus "Tears of the Sun" with Bruce Willis. In "King Arthur," Franzoni and Fuqua make the fatal mistake of taking themselves far, far too seriously. Not even actor Ray Winstone's churlish character Bors can redeem "King Arthur." As a chivalrous Round Table Knight, Bors is a poorly dressed shaven-headed lout with several illegitimate children who threatens to marry their mother. Fuqua and company play Bors largely for laughs. Using crude contemporary slang, Bors becomes the first on-screen knight to carp about the need to urinate. Hans Zimmer's dirge-like orchestral music hangs tragically over the ponderous action. Fuqua should stick to helming urban thrillers like "The Replacement Killers" and "Training Day," because he cannot orchestrate epic battle sequences. The larger-than-life battle between our heroes and the villainous Saxons on an iced-over lake lacks dramatic intensity, though the underwater shots bolster the suspense. Watching Keira Knightley triumph over opponents twice her size in combat stretches credibility to the breaking point. Meanwhile, the underwritten characters of Gawain, Tristan and Galahad spend most of their time on the periphery of the action, while the heavy-handed historical exposition bogs down the action. Stellan Skarsgard doesn't make much of an impression as the villain through his bearded face and whispered dialogue. Franzoni pulls a surprise that cannot be revealed without spoiling the plot. Believe me, when it happens, you will feel cheated. As for the love triangle involving Guinevere, Arthur, and Lancelot, "King Arthur" leaves it out! In their quest for a more historically accurate interpretation of the Arthurian legend, the people who made "King Arthur" strive to live down the legend. (Note: This review applies to the theatrical release.)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Had potential, but went down hill real quick...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoilers here-inI went into this movie with high expectations. As a history buff and a lover of Arthurian Legends, I was anxious to see this movie. I loved the idea of peeling away all the myth, getting at the core of the story. Even more so, I loved the idea of seeing Arturius Rex in action. Unfortunately, within mere moments, I realized this movie had little chance of improvement.Starting off the film with a young Lancelot going off to war, this film was very slow. But slow is not always bad. Writer David Franzoni (Amistad, Gladiator) and Director Antoine Fuqua (Training Day, Bait) make an interesting coupling, but it just does not work. The change of Guinevere from a dainty Queen to a Warrior was a welcomed one. The problem with this film is that it throws in names simply for recognition purposes only. Had the film-makers truly been interested in keeping the film, Merlin, most likely, would not have been mentioned as he is a fairly recent addition to the saga (as are Lancelot, Guinevere, and several others). The knights mentioned (Gawain, Galahad, et al) are glazed over. One of the main failings with the film are not its dialogue, cinematography, or even its lack of character development. Instead, it fails on the historical level. To quote Polydore Vergil, court historian for King Henry VIII, If Arthur had fought against the Romans, he would have had to be at least 200 years old when he took on the sixth-century Saxons. With Rome leaving the British Isles in A.D. 406, and this film being set in the seventh century, Arthur looks mighty well preserved. The problem, however, is that this film is combining TWO different Arthurs. The first fought against the Romans, the second fought the Saxons. If this film is going claim "The untold true story that inspired the legend" as they do on the Previews and the Poster, I should think that they would have done more research.For someone who is not a history buff, but is a lover of Arthurian Legends, this is still not the movie for you. Ending with the Battle of Mount Baedan (Badon Hill), it is Lancelot who suffers the untimely death, instead of Arthur at Camblam (Camlann). The appearance of the Sword in the Stone seems thrown into the hodge-podge of the story simply for recognition purposes, and with no explanation as to why it is there.Now, I admit I am viewing this film from a biased stand-point, so I may not be the one to best judge the film, but I have always felt if you are going to make an adaptation of a book, play, or other source material, then you should stick to the story that is given. Certain changes I can understand, but to totally go off-track from the story is precisely what was done with many other book-to-film adaptations. If you want a better adaptation of King Arthur, check out Excalibre, Camelot, or even Disney's The Sword in the Stone.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Anachronisms abound as Hollywood once again tears apart the Arthur myth</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I suppose they meant well. And their attempts to place the legendary hero Arthur in a more realistic era are to be applauded. But in truth, there are all sorts of problems with this disappointing failure.On the upside, it looks good. It's well dressed, well shot, and where the lesser characters are concerned, well acted. But unfortunately that's where the plaudits end and the brickbats begin.As Arthur, Clive Owen is about as wooden as it's possible for an actor to be and remain in place as the star of the film. Guinevere is portrayed by Keira Knightley as a Celtic warrior princess ? not a bad idea, but as always in the hands of Knightley, and particularly ludicrously on this occasion, she sounds as though she's just emerged from ladies finishing school. Perhaps the biggest disappointment of all is the absence of Merlin, the most enigmatic personality in the whole story. Okay he's here, but he does and says so little that he might as well not be.We also have several bizarre switches from winter to summer. One minute we're on a frozen lake, the next we're on a verdant meadow with all the trees in full leaf. It's baffling and rather silly, and completely detracts from the otherwise effectively harsh climate that the film seeks to create. Even the battles don't work particularly well. They've been applauded by many, but to me they suffer from what I call "the 'Troy' disease" in that they are painfully over-choreographed. It's more like watching a ballet rehearsal than an actual fight.There are all sorts of historical issues too, and yet again you wonder why, when they had such a good original story to work from, the movie makers had to change so much. Everybody knows nowadays that Arthur, if he existed, was not a medieval king presiding over a chivalrous court. He was most likely an ex-Roman officer, who assembled tribal leaders to fend off the Saxon incursions (the Saxons incidentally did not invade Britain via Scotland, as is shown in the film ? they came in through the south-east, and their conquest was not a holocaust, but a gradual colonisation). In this instance however, Arthur is presented as a Roman officer serving at the head of a troop of Samartian horsemen (very anachronistically referred to as 'knights'); an odd and pointless diversion from the myth, in which, far more excitingly, his supporters are natives who must learn to defend their homeland after the protection of the legions has been withdrawn. Sadder still, none of the really dramatic events of Arthur's reign ? his creation of the Round Table to unite a nation, his heroic death not at the hands of invaders but in a treachery-filled civil war ? are even touched upon. All we're really dealing with here is a rescue mission just north of Hadrian's Wall, which goes badly wrong. Hardly the stuff great romances are made of.Another missed historical opportunity, and in this case a particularly bad one ? with the money that was spent here, a seriously good Arthurian epic could have resulted.</fullReview>

		<username>DR-9</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Just a BIT of Historical Accuracy, Please!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For a film purporting to be the real story of King Arthur, this offering is rife with historical inaccuracy. The Romans are shown abandoning Britain at the same time as Arthur's coming to power, and his climactic battle against Saxon invaders (presumably, the Battle of Mount Badon). In reality, the last Roman legionary left Britain sometime between 406 and 409 A.D., while the Battle of Mount Badon has been dated between 495 and 520 A.D.Arthur is portrayed as a Christian, but as an adherent of Pelagius, a lay monk who came to prominence as a writer, then as a heretic, in the early 5th Century Rome. Because Pelagius was known by the nickname "Brito" or "Britannicus" he is believed to have come from Britain. The film depicts the heresy of Pelagius as a belief that all men are equal. In reality, his teachings had nothing to do with the equality of man, centering, rather, on original sin and grace. Also, the film hints that Pelagius was killed for his beliefs, when, in reality, he was tried by more than one church council and released, never executed. He left Rome and is believed to have traveled east, as did most of his followers. Thus, historians can find no evidence that he ever returned to Britain and discount the possibility that Arthur was influenced by him.Lastly, the film paints (no pun intended for these decorated warriors) the natives of Britain as uniformly pagan, another inaccuracy. In fact, Christianity was brought to Britain by Roman traders in the first Century A.D. and accepted by many. By the sixth century it was definitely in its ascendancy, dominating most towns and spreading out into the countryside.Considered exclusively on its cinematic merits, the film offers a strong performance by Clive Owen in the title role. One might wish, however, that the producers had spent a little extra money to hire a dialect coach to rid Mr. Owen of his working class accent. While it worked splendidly in his role as a prisoner/gardener in the neglected "Greenfingers," it lacks the distinction and authority required of a legendary king. Keira Knightley was undeniably attractive as a warrior Briton, who, despite a lack of armor of any kind, emerges improbably unscathed from the film's battles. (Parental caveat: their love scene is too intense for children.) And it is a service to rescue Arthur from the late-Medieval setting into which popular imagination tends to place him and correctly return him to the immediate post-Roman era. Other bright spots are an interesting battle staged on ice, and the ever-moving music of Hans Zimmer. Otherwise, the film shortchanges the viewer on character development, inexplicably reducing the pivotal Merlin to a dirty-faced near-prop with a peculiar accent, and script clarity. (One scene about immuring -- Whom? Monks? Pagans? Ascetics? -- is not only bizarre but virtually incomprehensible.) In all, it seems a rehashing of better films, including "Arthur" director Antoine Fuqua's 2003 "Tears of the Sun," "Gladiator," and, of course, the wonderful "Braveheart."</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-12-24</date>
		<username>Ben Burgraff (cariart)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Much Ado About Nothing...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wince whenever I see a film described as "the Real Story", especially when recounting events that occurred fifteen hundred years ago, and claiming to be the 'truth' about Arthur and his knights. While there are certainly theories that 'Arthur' was, as the film implies, a Roman military commander, equally legitimate claims can be made that he was a Welsh or Briton chieftain, a Celtic warlord, or, most likely, an amalgamation of several powerful early warrior/generals, combined by French troubadours of the 11th - 13th centuries into a single 'King of England' to promote the concept of Chivalry. As Guinevere, Lancelot, and a majority of the famed knights and deeds of Arturian folklore date from this later period, the only 'fact' that can be proved is that Britain, after the Romans departed, was a bloody battleground between the Britons and the swarming Saxons, as well as from other tribes from the north and across the English Channel.With this 'battlefield' concept, "King Arthur" still might have worked...except that Guinevere (a Celtic girl with a habit of fighting nearly naked), Merlin (a Celt chieftain with engineering talents equal to the Romans), and Lancelot, Tristan, Gawain, Galahad, and the other knights (Eastern European 'indentured soldiers' of Rome) all are 'named' characters in the film...and with the possible exception of Merlin, none had even been introduced before the 11th century! Dropping the 'Name' and 'Is it True, or is it Bruckheimer?' complaints, there are some good points to the film; Ireland, substituting for England, has a raw beauty in keeping with the time period; Stellan Skarsg?rd (with an American accent!) plays the Saxon 'king' with a bloodthirsty yet stoic quality that certainly captures your attention; the battle scenes (in the Director's Cut) are brutal and believable; and the conflict on the ice (with a resolution familiar to anyone who has seen the Russian classic, "Aleksandr Nevsky") has a tension often lacking through much of the rest of the film.As for the leads...Clive Owen makes a strong, sincere Arthur (although, by the sixth century, even the Romans were wearing beards; being beardless was seen, mostly, in clerics); Ioan Gruffudd, as Lancelot, does his best with a role that begins promisingly, then drops off to a series of complaints and knowing 'looks'; Keira Knightley (Guinevere), at 18, shows great enthusiasm in action sequences, and great promise in her scenes with Owen. Ray Winstone, as the surly but likable Sir Bors, easily steals the film, providing most of the spirit, on screen.I know that many will find my criticism of "King Arthur" far too picky, but if you love a medieval battlefield epic, "Braveheart" is still the movie to see...and if you love the King Arthur of lore, buy "Excalibur", and cherish the legends! Sadly, "King Arthur" is a pale imitation of both!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Underrated historical war film - see the director's cut</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although much-reviled on release, KING ARTHR gains a new lease of life when you view the Director's Cut of it. From a kiddie-friendly family film, it has been transformed into a gory, gritty adventure in which the blood sprays across the scene in frequent bursts and people are beheaded left right and centre. Dispensing with the mystical medieval aspects of the story, in this version the film takes place in a wild and untamed England, inhabited by the Woads and the Romans, who have decided to leave. The enemy are the Saxons, led by true Saxon Stellan Skarsgaard.KING ARTHUR is an old-fashioned story which questions religion, free will and man's calling in life. As a film, it looks very good, with excellent choreography in the battle scenes and fine camera-work all round. The Irish locations are wonderfully picturesque and the wildness of the elements is put across very plainly, as our heroes battles snow, ice and freezing rain. The plot, as many have mentioned, bears a little resemblance to THE MAGNIFICENT SEVEN, but that's the case with plenty of movies anyway. Production values are high as is the testosterone evident, with a shouty Ray Winstone on good form and Clive Owen as a rugged, working class Arthur. Sadly, Owen's acting is a little stilted, and he is outdone at virtually every turn by the excellent Ioan Gruffudd as Lancelot. A cast of British regulars pad out the leads and the attractive Keira Knightley ably supplies the love interest.Action fans will be here for the battle sequences, which are impressive and carry on in the recent tradition of TROY, THE LAST SAMURAI, THE LORD OF THE RINGS trilogy and others. The battles are bloody and frenetic, true life-or-death down-and-dirty fighting, with clever tactics. The best moment of the film has to be the battle on an iced-over lake, which progresses pretty much the way you would expect, and is very much the better for it. The climactic battle is worth waiting for and seems undeniably epic. KING ARTHUR doesn't equal the status of rivals like BRAVEHEART, but it does prove to be a generally good film that is definitely worth a watch.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An admirable and novel approach with the obvious blockbuster trappings</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>People should be more open-minded and daring about taking classic tales and putting them in different time periods. Everyone accepts the adaptation of Heart of Darkness into Apocalypse Now as a classic and brilliant cinematic decision, so why is the Antoine Fuqua's interpretation of King Arthur set in Ancient Rome so heinous to some people? The film strips bare all the children's magic that people know Arthur for and make it a bleak yet simple vision of Arthur and his nights. The important elements - the round table, the relationship with Guinevere, the sword Excalibur (without the magic) - are kept and adapt well to this version of events.Clive Owen makes for an interesting Arthur. His performance tends to live and die by the screenplay - during the cringeworthy moments (of which there are a few), he does poorly, but for the most part seems fully in control of this Roman Christian officer with his strong religious faith and stoic leadership. The most interesting thing about the knights played by Mads Mikkelsen, Joel Edgerton, Hugh Dancy, Ray Winstone, Ray Stevenson and Ioan Gruffudd is that they interact like a bunch of boys who've grown up in a boarding house together. This is completely consistent with the version of events Fuqua is trying to tell, and provides many of the film's best moments. Ioan Gruffudd portrays Lancelot as a cocky womaniser, and Ray Winstone steals the whole movie as the brutish, foul-mouthed, Gimli-esque Sir Bors. Every single scene with Winstone is better than a scene in which he is absent. As the antagonist, Stellan Skarsgard portrays Cerdic as a man who is weary of killing and pillaging but does it out of obligation, which he does very well but it doesn't fit at all with the movie.At large times, it is very clear that this is a Jerry Bruckheimer studio movie. Keira Knightley glows with makeup after being rescued from a dungeon and wears minimal clothing wherever she can. A happy ending is tacked on the end of the film, regarding the coronation of Arthur and his marriage to Guinevere (with whom he has sex for 30 seconds and they pass that off as romance). There are two major battle sequences, full of shaky cam, smoke effects and fire. However, the third battle sequence in the middle of the film, on a frozen lake, is one of my favourite battle scenes in movies. It is full of tension and excitement. One thing that did suffer from the big budget approach was the story of Pelagius and how his relationship with Arthur affects Arthur's worldview. I only barely picked up on it this time, and I've seen this movie a few times before.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Genuinely dreadful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is genuinely dreadful. By all means stop reading at this point and choose not to watch this debacle - but I'll tell you why I found it to be so bad anyway.First of all, this film bills itself to be a historical retelling. It isn't. It isn't a faithful retelling of the Arthurian legend either. It's a lazy Hollywood re-write that takes liberties with what might be considered historically possible or even plausible.There is such a disregard for consistency and detail in this film that you really want to throw things at the TV.The film sets itself at around 300 A.D.Geographically it sets itself in what we now call Britain.These markers float to suit the film maker without warning.OK. Draw breath.Many other reviewers - countless in fact - have pointed out the frustrations of depicting Britain between Stonehenge, Hadrian's Wall, and a massive frozen lake that an arm could stand on (where is that?).The geographical impossibility, and the convenient transportation of the film to an impromptu ice-age is the least of it's worries.All of the film's key characters are awful too.I'm just going to look at the Kiera Knightley character - Guinevere. Guinevere is transformed into a sexy alluring seductive Boudica warrior. She is found originally walled up and starved in a pagan/Christian tomb. Despite her starvation, and apparently broken fingers - she is fighting with the vigor of a Spartan warrior within two days of her rescue. She comes complete with three costumes - the first a serf like woven Anglo-Saxon event with designer scruffiness and glossy lips. The second is a sheer, off the shoulder, fantasy/Roman/princess affair (with glossy lips). The final wardrobe is a stone age body paint/war paint bikini (despite the passing ice age - and the fact that she is fighting men dressed in furs) - with glossy lips. Her weapon? She is nothing less than an expert with the Mongolian composite recurved bow. Quite spectacular considering they didn't become available until the 13th Century - and even then on the other side of the earth.Pause on this if you will. The battle of Agincourt was fought in 1415 - the greatest victory of the English longbow. At that time the longbow was the prevailing weapon of the English military and had become a national sport to encourage national proficiency. By this time the Mongol empire had disintegrated - and even though the Mongol bow had been demonstrated as being so much more powerful and versatile - the composite recurved bow still had to not been integrated into military tactics of Western Europe.So Guinevere's proficiency with this weapon is not only historically impossible, geographically impossible, it is entirely incongruous with it's setting - why not give her a Spitfire or a sniper's rifle? As if to confirm this, the closing battle - the culmination of the film - sees the knights of King Arthur arrive wearing - and wait for it now - Samurai armour. Not just any Samurai armour mind you - the kind that evolved in the 19th Century - and (wait for it) - it's blue.Don't watch this film. The acting is generally irritating but the plot and portrayal of a tenuous story (which might as well be about anyone in fiction) is intolerable.</fullReview>

		<username>Spikeopath</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>King Arthur (2004) D/C</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Arthur, you fight for a world that will never exist.King Arthur is directed by Antoine Fuqua and written by David Franzoni. It stars Clive Owen, Keira Knightley, Ioan Gruffudd, Mads Mikkelsen, Ray Winstone, Joel Edgerton, Stephen Dillane, Hugh Dancy, Ken Stott, Stellan Skarsg?rd and Til Schweiger. Music is scored by Hans Zimmer and cinematography by Slawomir Idziak.The Roman Empire is departing Britannia, and local commander Artorius Castus (Owen), is given one final mission to rescue an important Roman family from the invading Saxon hordes. Calling on the support of his trusty Knights, Arthur leads his men on a mission that will define them all.Save your prayers boy, your god doesn't live here.The flaws of director Antoine Fuqua's Arthurian epic have been well documented, as has the tinkering of producer Jerry Bruckheimer, the latter of which took his lusty scissors to the original cut of the film and created a rather choppy experience for a film already on rocky waters. Yet in spite of the uneven narrative, the unsound historical spin on the Arthurian legend, and the gross miscasting of Clive Owen in the lead, the film still went on to make roughly $80 million in profit from the worldwide box office. The director's cut of the film, whilst not altering the strength of the movie in the way that the D/C of Kingdom of Heaven does, has a more comprehensive flow to it, more blood and boldness and yes, it's more fun.The Knights are demons. That is the gate of hell!The film is undeniably epic in scope and production, the lush photography of expansive lands, the set design and costuming (including the wonderfully attired horses in the final battle at Badon Hill), Zimmer's gladiatorial score and the ensemble of actors gathered. Action quota is high and energised, well choreographed and in the case of the battle of Badon Hill, extended into a good portion of the running time to really crown the story. How nice to see sensible military tactics used, it may not be genius to note Arthur telling his small band of troops to "aim for the wings of their ranks, make them cluster" (this during a brilliant fight against the Saxons on a frozen lake), but there's a common sense logic here that is often missing in similar big budgeted historical epics.Artorius! Rus!Most agreeable is the story itself. It focuses on the decline of the Roman Empire, the withdrawal from Britain, the impact of berserker religion at this time, the Saxons and the Woads (Picts/Celts). In the middle of all this world changing anger is Arthur's inner turmoil, his battle with faith as he leads his loyal knights out of the promised freedom into yet more bloody chaos. The arrival on the scene of Guinevere (Knightley), here as a Woad warrior, in the second half of the picture clouds things still further, the possible love triangle between herself, Arthur and Lancelot is only hinted at, and the story is more intriguing because of it. In fact Fuqua proves most adept at characterisations, even if sadly he can't get the best performances from some of the big players.We will go home across the mountains.With Owen looking the part but too bland in delivery to make this Arthur convince, it needs the other big players to step up to not let the lead performance hurt the piece too much. Yet the best performances are coming from the supporting players like Edgerton, Mikkelsen, Stevenson and Dancy, but like Gruffudd (the one who truly looks and sounds the part), they are all underused. Skarsg?rd is ace, making Saxon leader Cerdic a fearless, emotionless and formidable foe, and Schweiger as his son Cynric also leaves a telling mark, but these too are also underused. Further viewings of the directors cut do show Knightley's performance in a better light, Guinevere dominates the narrative in the second half and Knightley is full of guts and lively in her action scenes, but the voice just irritates and someone in production should have picked up on that. Winstone gives a fun turn, certainly it's not in keeping with the surroundings, mind, as you half expect him to don his West Ham United scarf and start shouting ICF! But it is fun and becomes tolerable the longer the film runs.It's a flawed epic for sure, but one that still remains a great piece of historical filmic fun. Often rousing and blood stirring, even emotionally satisfying too. That is if you can forgive it for its failings? 7/10</fullReview>

		<date>2015-12-05</date>
		<username>Sheridan Brown</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Well, they tried</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Released in July 2004, King Arthur manages to shake the very foundations of historical knowledge?in only 126 minutes. Claiming to be "the untold true story" behind the King Arthur legend, the movie spins a tale entirely unknown to the Arthurian world. Arthur (Clive Owen) and his knights are soldiers bound in service to the Roman Empire. After fifteen long years of fighting in Roman-held Britain, the knights are to receive their discharge papers only after one final, dangerous mission to rescue an important Roman family from a mounting Saxon invasion. Among those aided by the knights is a young woman? Guinevere (Kiera Knightly), the daughter of Merlin. Though the mission is ultimately successful, the knights choose to remain in Britain after the Roman withdrawal, defending the land and its people from the Saxons. The movie closes with the commemoration of Lancelot (Ioan Gruffudd) and Tristan (Mads Mikkelsen), followed by Arthur's wedding to Guinevere and his popular appointment as king of the newly independent Britain. This take on events may strike audiences as unfamiliar? largely because it is. Much of what happens in the movie has little to no historical or literary support, resulting in a jumbled retelling that contains only the most base-level elements of traditional Arthurian narrative. The names of most of the knights may be familiar?the movie features Gawain, Galahad, Bors, Tristan, and of course Lancelot?but their characters and quests have been drastically altered to fit the ideas of Roman soldiers longing for freedom rather than medieval knights fighting for chivalry and honour. Perhaps the most dramatic difference between this film and other Arthurian adaptations is the presentation of Guinevere, not as a lady or queen, but as a mysterious, feisty warrior whose main claims to fame are charging into battle mostly shirtless, giving highly philosophical advice?"You and I are not the polite people that live in poems. We are blessed and cursed by our times" and "What tomorrow brings, we cannot know"?and create a mostly irrelevant love triangle between herself, Lancelot, and Arthur, which is eventually resolved in Lancelot's rather predictable death. In this retelling, Guinevere is one of the Woads, a native people of Britain who resisted Roman Rule. According to the film, they are led by Merlin, a mystical man characterised more as a man of nature than a sorcerer. The devices of Merlin and his followers are of deception and trickery rather than magic, as seen in a clever (if somewhat unrealistic) trap to cut off Arthur and his Knights, and later in the use of war machines and flaming arrows. Historical inaccuracies abound. The opening scene in which a young Lancelot leaves his family to begin his Roman service is dated 452 AD. According the movie chronology, Rome would then have withdrawn from Britain in 467 AD. This is 57 years too late, as Rome completely withdrew from Britain in 410 AD1. The repeated use of the word "knight" to refer to Arthur and his men is also chronologically inaccurate, as the word "knight" did not come into common usage until about 1100 AD2, 600 years after the film is supposed to have taken place. As movie which claims to be an "untold history", it is critically undermined by such blatant failures on the part of the script writers to do even the most basic research. A viewer uninterested in the historical aspect of the movie might enjoy the story slightly more, but even non-scholars would likely notice the almost complete failure of the film to follow traditional Arthurian tales. Lancelot and Galahad, for example, appear as brothers in arms rather than father and son as in most tellings. Rather than fighting against Rome, as in Geoffrey of Monmouth's History of the Kings of Britain and Sir Thomas Malory's Le Morte Darthur, Arthur and his knights are fighting for Rome, at least until Rome abandons Britain to the Saxons. While a child Arthur does pull his father's sword from a stone, it is in an attempt to save his mother and not to prove himself worthy of being king. Arthur is portrayed as the first king of Britain, rather than a successor in a line of great kings which in traditional narrative included his father, Uther Pendragon. Other famous characters, such as Percival, Morgan le Fay, and Mordred are also markedly absent. The unique take on the Arthurian legend may appeal to some viewers; after all, one can only watch so many renditions of the Grail Quest before becoming bored. They should, however, be wary of its lack of literary precedent. The movie itself is high-action, full of battle scenes as the fate of Britain is decided on a smoky field. There is certainly enough blood to merit the movie's R rating. The actual setup of the movie is fairly well done; the acting is convincing, the landscapes are realistic enough, and the score, written by Hans Zimmer and Maire Brennan, well accompanies the sequences of action. The plot is easy to follow but incredibly predictable: betrayal, danger, several close encounters, and an ultimate victory, all wrapped in with a wedding to make the audience feel better about the thousands of people whose violent deaths they just witnessed. A love affair?every movie needs at least one?and an introspective quest for the true meanings of justice, duty, and belonging are thrown in just to make things interesting. The final battle scene is particularly unimaginative: desperately outnumbered, it is the courage and skill of the fighters that eventually bring them to a narrow victory only after Lancelot, the main character's best friend, has been tragically killed. All in all, the movie is passable as an independent work but an unbearable travesty of Arthurian tradition. Were one to change the names of the characters, the movie could stand on its own as a popular independent work. The next time director Antoine Fuqua decides to render King Arthur's timeless tale, one can only hope he will do his reading first.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Interesting mish-mash of historical events, people and some sheer artistic licence, beautiful production values</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The film looks great, it's obvious that if they needed something built they just built it, if they needed some CGI they just did it. The budget for this film was immense, and probably could have been put to use on a better film. But anyway.King Arthur is set during the declining years of the Roman Empire, around 450 AD. However if you are after a historically accurate representation of that time in Britains and/or Rome's history, you'd be better off grabbing a history book and curling up in front of the fire with that instead. This film and it's hero, Arturius, seem to be based on a conglomeration of numerous historical figures and events. Watching King Arthur, I could not help but compare Arthur to stories I have read of great generals and leaders like Julius Caesar, Scipio Africanus, Alexander, and a hodge-podge of qualities lifted straight from English Kings and folklore. He seemed to be a mix of all these people, and thus he seemed a slightly aloof and unbelievable character. He had some memorable lines, and some "strong, silent type" moments which were pretty cool, but beyond that I thought the character of the dude with the eagle (can't remmber his name) was far cooler. Yet he suffered one of the worst fates at the hands of the "bad guy" (don't get me started on him - he was a mish-mash of Genghis Khan, Attila the Hun, Hannibal and any other "bad guy" you can think of throughout history). This film casts an awful light on Saxons anyway, not a very accurate representation. It was indeed the early Roman Empire's philosophy to "never leave alive a man, woman or child who can carry a sword" NOT the Saxons'.Anyway, The film has some okay battle scenes, but is also unintentionally funny in a couple of places. Mainly to do with the choice of Keira Knightly to play Guinevere. Keira Knightly a warrior-woman? I don't think so! She's about as intimidating as a Jane Austen novel. And the love scene...very, very Hollywood. I mean, c'mon...WHEN, during all the fighting and travelling they do before it, did she have time to shave her legs? Haha. And even in the scenes in a dark forest, she always seem to have a bright light permanently installed just out of shot above her head, casting this ethereal glow over her. Then we cut back to Arthur and he's in almost total darkness. Please. I'm pretty good at suspending disbelief, but that was taking it a bit far! Aside from that, the film really DRAGS in the middle...to the point where I think you can safely nod off for a while and not be confused at all when u wake up and re-join the story. I dunno, giving it a 5 because I'm half-half, I don't even know if I'll be bothered ever watching it again, but it has it's good points. If you're just after a "Roman Empire" movie though, I'd much more hastily recommend Spartacus, The Fall of the Roman Empire, Ben Hur, or even Gladiator before I'd recommend this.</fullReview>

		<username>Blueghost</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>My two bits on King Arthur.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I liked this movie, though I have qualms with some of the minor technical bits and thematic pieces.When I saw the promo on television for this film I interpreted the advert to convey the message of a corporate test-screened fiasco, replete with lots of pointless action, sex, a hip-hop soundtrack with metal rift overtones to appeal to all demographics.And so I passed on "King Arthur" when it hit the theatres, as I had with most films. I wanted a film that addressed the Dark Ages in Britain, but not one aimed at teenagers, and riding the heels of other "blockbuster" fiascoes.But I was intrigued by what kind of "fiasco" I had missed, and so rented a copy at Blockbuster. My expectations were extremely low, but I wanted to reassure myself that it was the right decision to pass up a bad film in the theatre by paying a bargain video rental price.That's not what I got.I got something that seemed to be exceptionally well shot, though I viewed the opening sequences with via my own prejudiced lens. But as the film rolled I discovered some very solid film making, with excellent art direction coupled with moody and eloquent cinematography, and first rate emoting from a fine cast.Wow! I understand the historical quibbles many an audience member will have with the story. And I, most of all, appreciate the disagreements, and after a fashion probably agree with a lot of the criticisms of the liberties taken with the history, yet, as a "fictional" piece taken as a presentation of what might have been history, I truly loved the film.There were a couple of borderline B-movie moments, but they're few and separated enough that they don't stand out unless scrutinized closely. If there were one real critique I could make it would be in the exposition of the story early on in Act I. Without revealing what happens I think a more grounded basis for Arthur's beliefs needed to be shown, maybe even showing a scene or two in Rome itself to explain Arthur's character.I think that's what it comes down to. Arthur's convictions are deep and profound, and with a magnificent stage set by Fuqua, the only thing missing are examples of why Arthur believes what he believes. We're shown some small portions of his reasons for his convictions, but not until later on. It's truly a minor oversight, but I think people latch onto this instinctively.Beyond that it's a first rate film. And I for one am eternally grateful that Fuqua removed (or toned down) the love-triangle from Mallory's text. Fuqua was right in his commentary, such an affair, particularly in those times, makes absolutely no sense among the people these characters represent. They're hardened men, with pride and loyalty, not petty lusts.In short "King Arthur" has one minor exposition shortcoming, and does juggle the historical facts, but approach it with an open mind, and you will be entertained. It truly is a well made film. One of my favorites.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Poor script ruins movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie has a terrible script. Every epic cliché line written in Braveheart, LOTR and Gladiator was thrown into this movie and mishmashed to suit the director's purpose. From the upraising of swords and all the hooting and chest thumping that goes on, it becomes a terrible spectacle. Uninspired to say the least. For example, one scene has Arthur emerging from the city gates to meet Cerdic, the Saxon chief. Fog and smoke roil around him, making him look like a rock star from the 80's walking on stage. Just plain cheesy.Clive Owen, great in roles like Derailed and Sin City just doesn't seem right for this part. Although he has movie star looks, he does not have the screen presence to carry off an effective Arthur. Keira Knightly is not as bad in this movie as everyone says, but her lines are poorly written. She has an intriguing character though and a different twist on Guinevere. Ioan Gruffudd is wooden as the passionate Lancelot. Even the great Ray Winstone, marvelous in all those British gangster films, overacts his part. His over the top role as the crazy warrior becomes annoying very quickly.What good can be said about this film? Low key actors like Mads Mikkelson as Tristan and Stellan Skarsgard as Cerdic are simply great. Maybe their roles, because they didn't have to deliver many lines from the terrible script, made them shine. Regardless, they are fun to watch on the screen. Stellan as the old Saxon chief with that murderous axe and sweeping beard truly looks the part of an ancient warrior.The sets are simply phenomenal. From the burning villages to the mortared cities, they were inspired as much as the script wasn't. Details for armor, weapons, horses are flawless.The battle scenes? Spectacular! Swordplay, hails of arrows and flinging fireballs were a treat to watch. It's too bad there wasn't more of them. All the knights of Arthur have different fighting styles, with Tristan's saber to Lancelot's two sword fighting skill to Arthur's traditional longsword. Great stuff. The final battle scene was rousing to say the least. With flying bodies, splattered blood, classic one on one matches and the chaos of life and death m?lée, it was amazingly portrayed on the screen.The final word? If you want to watch a movie that has eye candy but little emotional content, an uninspired script and ho hum acting then by all means, rent this flick. It's really too bad that this movie hadn't really poured some work into these areas, because it could have been on par with the other epic classics.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An artful movie featuring King Arthur</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Looking around, I've seen people dissing about "King Arthur", saying it's a lousy flop and yadda yadda yadda. I say, consider all factors before speaking for or against it. This movie does have its ups and downs. The first time I watched it, I was dumbfounded and didn't know what was going on there. But now, I see it differently. The reason why people don't like this movie is because it's not what they expected. No Merlin and the pointy hat, no affair between Lancelot &amp; Guenevere, no sword in the stone, no Morgaine Lefaye, no Lady of the Lake etc. And sure, the movie makers didn't really keep to the historical facts, but you must realize that this is a movie, not a documentary. They did twist the facts... a lot... but they did make their point as well: that Arthur was Artorius, a hero from Rome, not an illegitimate son of a great man who couldn't keep his pants on. Although the choreography is not all impressive, it isn't too bad either and in some parts, it was done pretty well indeed. What I noted most was presentation of the characters, especially the knights. In the movie, Arthur and his knights were spoken of as formidable, legendary heroes and even close to gods. And the movie not only tells this, but shows it by presenting them with good effects. Example, how Arthur's silhouette emerged from the smoke through the slowly opening gates to meet the Saxon king, and how the knights are spotted behind the smoke upon the hill with their banners waving in the wind. And how the they and their horses moved as one. I especially liked how the movie makers played with the dust and smoke, wind and snow, how they paid attention to detail. Though I'll agree the story didn't quite have much to do with King Arthur and was mostly featuring him that surrounding him, I find that the cinematography, camera movement and effects etc all outweigh the poor, simple storyline, which I am greatly doubting as completely original. When I watched this movie, I couldn't help but wonder if I was watching a movie based on a book I read: The Last Legion. The description of the landscape in the book and the scenes almost EXACTLY match the ones in the movie. Example, the lake before Hadrian's Wall, the final battle at Badon Hill, the confrontation on the frozen lake and the way victory was won. The movie highly resembled all that was in the book. (The Last Legion will be coming out soon, starring Colin Firth.) That's why I'm not for the story, but like I said before, taking the rest into consideration, this is one entertaining ride.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Not my Arthur</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What I learned from this movie: Arthur, "demystified" was not the Ur-defender of Britain, he was a prescient Champion of Freedom. Alrighty, that was moderately annoying. Full disclosure: I have a stake in Arthur. Not a big sake. But I was raised in England, and there is a part of me below my rational brain that believes Arthur will return. That Arthur did return, in the person of Elizabeth I and the storms that drove back the Spanish Armada. That Arthur did return, in the person of Winston Churchill and the RAF driving back the Nazis. That he will return to protect London from the rising waters. I get all misty eyed. But this guy? Not that Arthur. Not one of the avatars of that Arthur. Okay, based on one of the seven plus figures from history or myth that I have read might lurk in the Arthur matrix; a Roman soldier who stayed behind to protect his mother's people from hoards of . . . well, I'm not sure. From the movie, it appeared to be proto-Nazis. Racially pure "Saxons," intent on maintaining their ethic purity as they invaded new lands. Right. This Arthur was a champion of contemporary American values; freedom, religious and ethnic diversity, gender equality, blah blah blah. I mean, I am too. And so is Captain Kirk and John Crichton, and I love Captain Kirk and John Crichton. But thrusting those values back on Arthur . . . disconcerting. And not necessary for any reason I could tell. What unites all of the Arthurs was the bedrock fact that They Defended Britain. That's who Arthur is. He is the Defender of Britain, and he's every hero who prevented the night from falling for the space of his generation. Even my atheist flesh is all tingly at the thought. This Arthur? Not so much. 		<shortDescription>Interesting filmic interpretation to a known story.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Character &amp; Plot Analysis ==========================When I saw the film for the first time I was instantly struck by the way the aura of Arthur and Lancellot was built. It was interesting to see a film where rather than just having this knight called Arthur, having a lead up to how he became the known Arthur.There are a few points though that I feel could and indeed should have been done better:1. In the very initial stages of the film we are introduced to Lancellot as a young boy - how he was taken away from his normal life and sent to the Roman outpost. We get a glimpse into his past and a bit more of an understanding of his pain. We next see him 15 years later - but where is the introduction to the main protagonist - Arthur. This back look is given later on in the film but again it is too little, this is the main protagonist we are talking about here.2. I love the fact that the film has a deep, dark feel to it, Arthur and the knights are fighting for a cause that is alien to them. The knights fight for freedom and Arthur fights also for freedom but in turn to go to Rome which is the very cause of his lack of freedom. The belief in a dream these knights are experiencing is almost reminding of reality, where we all have a dream and a goal to reach but often loose sight of reality for the dream. 3. The obligatory romance. It is almost a requirement of films today to have a romantic element in them. Arthur the knight in shining armor coming to save the damsel in distress. She turns out to be a great warrior and they fall in love - OK that is the normal thing but there was a subtle twist in the film. Lancellot evidently had a soft spot for her and she for him, throughout the film we have him stealing glances at her and her at him - in the battle at the end he rushes to rescue her. Again a filmic allegory to the distant hero. An almost silent submission by Lancellot to Arthur. Perhaps this is the weakness of Lancellot. 4. The film is set in the dark ages and this was indeed a time where wizards and magic was common. Merlin depicted as a dark wizard but there is almost a hint of humor in him. He has a aura of wisdom and fighting spirit but at the same time is a soft person when realizing that love is brewing. Filmic Analysis ===============Overall I felt that the film was shot quite well. The tonality of the set was speaking dark ages with a deep over hue in the coloration and shots. In the battle scents the editing spoke of chaos and gore with short quick shots moving from angle to angle.The tonality overall I felt to be quite crude and almost morbid, I felt that this was done intentionally to give a sense of feeling into the roughness of the moment. In the scene where the knights are at a bar having a drink before gong out on mission, during the melancholic song of home the camera play of tonality gave a sense of future problems and impeding doom. Overview ========I feel that as a film the story line was good and the filming was great. Filmic representation to the beginnings of the Rule Of Arthur. Overall the romance is subtle but enough and the plot is well balanced through the whole film. The acting is natural and gentle with a keen eye for detail on costumes. The tonality is great. A good film overall.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-07-16</date>
		<username>CTS-1</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>A Bit of a Waste</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What can I say? Well, for starters, I no longer think Kingdom of Heaven is that badly done. Let's start with how this film gets rolling. In the "plot convenience theatre" department: Arthur and all his knights need to be sent out on a mission to rescue this VIT (very important teenager), a mission so important that getting him back is the last thing the Roman army will do before departing. So, this kid is hanging out at some isolated plantation on the wrong side of Hadrian's wall??? Ladies and gentlemen, our human McGuffin is in place. And, in the same scene, what is it with the way Christians are being portrayed in these films? Is it some attempt to balance the fact that, fifty years ago, Christians were always portrayed as superior to Pagans, so now it is some kind of payback? In Kingdom of Heaven, a lot of the Christians were portrayed as venal, violent, and dim. How could King Arthur do worse? Venal, violent, cowardly, dim, and to top it off, pointlessly sadistic! How sadistic? Well, they do this dorky "torture Pagan children just because" routine. How pointless? Well, they have Keira Knightley in a dungeon, and all they can think of doing is breaking her fingers. How pathetic- and uncreative. This is Keira Knightley...Which brings to our film's antagonists: the Saxons. Let's play "You are the Saxon commander!" Despite apparently getting lost on the sea crossing and landing several hundred miles north of all the other Saxons, you have just come across a hastily abandoned Roman plantation. The plantation's carts and draft horses are gone, and the serfs have fled, but a fully furnished large luxury villa, outbuildings, tilled fields, and livestock remain. Do you say to yourself:A. FREAKING GREAT! THIS is why we invaded England: free pre-built fiefdoms! They even left the tableware, excellent. Now for the hard decision: keep it for myself, or give it to one of my successful captains instead of having to pay him? OR, B. WE HATE BUILDINGS! Burn! Burn the blasted thing to the ground. Kill everything that moves! We're Saxons- that's what we do! Sure, it is winter in Britannia, and the livestock we are pointlessly killing might come in handy to feed my army, but us Saxons prefer sleeping outside, on the ground, and eating- well, whatever. That's what makes us superior? Most historical Saxon commanders, in fact, chose option A. But, I guess Bruckheimer and company didn't think that invading land to take over and run things was eeeevil enough. So, the producers brought in the gang from "The Road Warrior," took away their dune buggies, and called them the enemy. Frankly, I suspect that their behavior would leave most historical Saxons going "huh?"One thing a lot of Saxon commanders would have liked, though, was all the groovy crossbows they had. Did someone time travel to eleventh century Genoa and buy them all? If they did, it would seem easier to come back with Lee-Enfield rifles and solve all their problems. Must be one of those time machines that only allow for the transport of non-gunpowder weaponry.The "am I watching a Godzilla film?" moment came after the rescue of teen McGuffin from the Saxon marauders and right before a battle on a frozen lake. Clive Owen gives an "inspirational" speech. The whole scene was re-dubbed from what Owen was originally saying, however, and the synchronization is horrible. Clive's lips start moving a full half second before we get any words. When I see that, I expect to hear Godzilla sounds or Hong Kong Martial-arts film sound effects immediately following. Hard to believe this film was done in English. Since Owen's speech was pretty cheesy, I shudder to imagine what Owen was saying originally, to be dubbed over with that cheese.The "battle on the ice" itself- it is just like Alexander Nevsky, except for the fact that it isn't good. Just a badly shot muddle of people on the ice more reminiscent of the "Monty Python Women's League" battle re-enactments than Eisenstein.After the Nevsky homage, we are treated a the most awkward, painful so-called "love scene" featuring Clive and Keira. There was a time in film when they would have just faded out when it was obvious what would happen. That would have been such an improvement. With these sort of scenes, do it right or don't do it at all! Poor lighting, camera angles straight out of "Battlefield Earth" and the old Batman TV show, enough camera movement to give some viewers motion sickness- even a porn film director could have done better.Of course, any film like this needs a final, climactic battle. Okay, so you have the best fortification in Britannia in the form of Hadrian's wall, and you let them through, supposedly as part of a trap. It appears that for this plan to work, the Saxons had to charge past the fortress and into battle, instead of thinking that maybe they would want to keep the fortification and let the natives attack them while they had the nice building; it is a good thing these road-warrior Saxons hate buildings and fortifications. And where did all the petroleum for these fire-traps come from? Lancelot was impressive, though. Why use a crossbow, if you can throw your sword forty feet and have it stick? And then, of course, the final wedding scene with the flaming arrows being shot into the sea (winner, 2004's most retarded Freudian image in film). But anyway, we have this great image of the wedding of Christian and Pagan, on the rocks. It just has a certain "love boat" kitschy quality to it which ruins any alleged message."Kingdom of Heaven" looked like a mish-mash when I first saw it. But, compared to this, it is a masterpiece.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-07-13</date>
		<username>Poseidon-3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not your grandpa's King Arthur. Proceed with caution.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The best plan when viewing this film is to toss aside any hopes of a traditional Arthur/Guinevere/Lancelot storyline and, in fact, to cast aside any notion that anything previously associated with the Arthurian legend will be represented at all. It also helps to avoid expecting any semblance of actual history to seep into the movie. So where does that place it? Right in there with any other inaccurate historical spectacle that is more interested in the clanking of swords and the amount of curls dangling from the heroes' faces, than in truly bringing to light the events and details of the period. In other words, it is a mildly entertaining battle story with a cast of solid actors, but has no regard for its roots or its reasonability. (This is despite a crawl at the start of the film which purports to set the record straight about the real King Arthur....right.....) Owen plays the man who would be king. Here he is a soldier, indentured to Rome, who must complete one final task before he and his men can claim their freedom. Owen, Gruffudd (as right-hand man Lancelot) and the other knights must venture north to territories held by the savage Saxons in order to rescue a young boy and his family who are important to the future of Rome. Once they arrive (at the improbably located home of this family), they find a gaggle of serfs and a pair of nearly dead religious prisoners and they bring them back with them as well. They then find themselves being hotly pursued by the Saxons, led by beastly Skarsgard and his upstart son Schweiger. Finally, a huge battle for the future of the territory takes place with Owen, Gruffudd and Knightly (as Guinevere) leading the way. Owen is a handsome and solid Arthur. Gruffudd is never allowed to be the shining and beautiful knight that Lancelot is often portrayed as. He is more often a grungy and surly sidekick. Those used to seeing Guinevere braiding her hair or doing needlepoint while wearing a velvet gown will get quite a shock at the sight of Knightly. She does wear a dress in a few scenes, but primarily is a war-painted, woodsy archer who kicks as much butt as any man! The famed knights of the round table are played by an able and amiable clatch of international actors who eventually emerge as individuals though it takes some time to sort their dirty faces and scraggly hairdos out. They all do well, but Winstone and Stevenson are the most impressive. Dillane turns up as a highly atypical Merlin, leader of the Woads (a murky tribe of scantily clad archers.) Skarsgard affects a hilariously American-sounding accent that wouldn't be out of place in a truck stop, but he is a physically imposing villain. Schweiger is effective as his edgy son. As an action-adventure film, it delivers in several areas, notably during a skirmish on top of a frozen lake. The whole enterprise might have been best served as an original story without dragging the fabled names of Arthurian legend into it. All that did was upset most purists and since any and all mysticism, along with several key characters (and the central crux of the story - the love triangle!) have been omitted entirely, it seems pointless. The film seems to borrow heavily from other, better films like "Last of the Mohicans", "Braveheart" and "Gladiator" with only a small amount of its own merit shining through. "Excaliber" remains the most satisfying take on the material.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Okay - the score is pretty good. The acting struggles to become wooden, and the plot is an incomprehensible mish-mash. No military commander deliberately gives up the best defensive position of his time, for any reason.The historical (in)accuracy is no big deal - we are dealing with a myth; you can make up anything you like, as long as it is entertaining. The garbled plot and questionable tactics ensured that it was not. For example in the confrontation on the ice; if you have a longer attack range than the enemy you keep him outside his effective range - you don't wait for him to advance, nor do you allow him to do so. As noted above, you don't give up a defensive position by inviting the enemy past it, and so on. The 'flyover' shots of Hadrian's Wall and accompanying fortifications are extremely poorly-done CGI; it looks like circa 1995 CAD work on freeware or cheapware programs like "My House Designer." I am delighted that I didn't sit through this dreck in a theatre; at least the DVD rental was cheap. Forget the spoiler warning - if you haven't seen it, the whole film is a spoiler.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I was actually surprised--I'd expected the movie to be much worse than it was. The effects and action scenes were, of course, "thrilling," "breathtaking," "ground-breaking" (supply your own PR adjective). Perhaps more surprising was the acting, which was tolerable, even convincing. The characters weren't complete card-board cutouts, and hinted at a bit of depth. And the film was atmospheric without being comical.The film totally and utterly lacked a plot, unfortunately. Ultimately it was little more than a series of vaguely-connected battles, love scenes and angst-filled monologues, slavishly plodding to the only possible conclusion: the conversion of Artus into Arthur, King of the Britains, and the gathering of his followers 'round the Round Table. The producers promised a rewriting of the Arthurian legend; instead we get little more than a time-shift, this telling taking place a millennium before the classic setting, and characters that are slightly more interesting than the archetypes of the original tales.Moreover, excepting the primary characters, character motivation was totally absent. Why were the Saxons invading? What motivated the Saxon leader--was he simply cruel? Was it merely blood-lust? The search for a worthy adversary? And was his son a closet pacifist, or a wanna-be king? Evil, or misunderstood? Were the Romans decadent, misguided, or multifaceted? Ultimately all peripheral characters were merely props for the continuation of the film.I did enjoy the film, however, hence my five-star rating. It was fun to watch, if not particularly moving or enlightening.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Poor Celts, poor history, poor legend!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>One of the rare movies I rated really bad, because expectations promised by the title itself to a fan of Celtic culture ended up by bitter disappointment. The whole movie was to me like inconsistency upon inconsistency from A to Z in everything a movie is made of.Legend:The Arthurian legend is one of the most popular in the world history. The authors explicitly decide to tell us their version. But who would think it will have so little in common with the legend! Not a single word about Grail, Camelot, Morgane, Avalon. Merlin is a Pict! A dirty shaggy ragged wise man of a primitive tribe, yes. Guinevere is a Pict too, and quite a good warrior! Arthur Castus... he's a Roman captain, that's all! At least before he decides to stay at his mother's homeland. His "knights" are just... Sarmathian cavalry ? men serving their 15 years military duty to Rome! Nothing more. All we have left is Excalibur taken from father's grave (but looks like it was a deed for a kid he was to simply lift it) and the empty Round table biggest from all movies (I bet it's able to host more than a double dozen!), looking really mistakenly with only 6 companions (all who's left alive after battles for Roman rule in England!). Difficult to castrate the legend more.History:May be the authors decided to discard all mystical elements and take an historical approach? We have a handful of Roman soldiers, Arthur with his cavalrymen and a Bishop in the fortress. Not much faces in the city, no peasants around. The only peasants we see are those serving the Roman nobleman living behind the wall between England and Scotland (!!!) built especially for defence against aggressive tribes. But I doubt local peasants would be so obedient to a stranger, if he would survive at all up there. All we see as truly local population are Picts truthfully described as a primitive tribe... But where is the rest of British population??? Did they wipe them all out "to control the land"? Devastation. Empty Britain save for those poor Picts before Saxes came. Hey, where are the Celts??? Even in 4th century they were already occupying all the South and their descendants are still living in Whales. And they could tell you the names of those knights Gawain and Galahad retained from the legend are 100% Celtic. Not Sarmathian, I can assure you living on latter's historical motherland! Were Celts considered also a mystical part of the legend?! Shame on makers of an historical movie! (if this is one at all).Story:Looks more like a sketch of the story. The story lines are raced through. Some episodes are depicted in slow details and then big parts are simply cut out. There is too much milk and water (soldiers' jokes, tribesmen matters) comparing to content essential for the story. Many episodes finally serve to nothing and some banal ideas are repeated too many times. The driving motive judging by accents is "soldiers wanna go home", at least this warrior part is most emotionally filled. Other relationships and love line look like very long entanglement suddenly passing into abrupt denouement, completely unelaborated. Even the psychological culmination of Arthur's ideological disappointment in Rome and turning to local heritage have much time divergence filled with nothing substantial. So we have no good story either comparative to "First Knight" as much unfaithful to the legend but at least offering a fascinating story in itself.Characters:Basically flat and banal (brave captain, crafty Bishop, etc). There is an obvious lack of individuality, psychological evolution and motivation. Our heroic knights dream about simple domestic joys. Guinevere though tribeswoman looks quite decent until she suddenly jumps into Arthur's bed. Arthur has a specific strain of deep thoughts and high responsibility on his face, too forced IMHO. There is a hint on his special abilities in the beginning but it does not take any shape. He doesn't make the presence of a powerful hero. It is not rigid seriousness which makes beloved leaders, and it is not stupid braveness which makes heroes, and it is not plain honour which makes kings. Nobody to look at all in all.Artwork:Picts' blue faces painted with spiral red lines the same as on their tomahawks are beautiful. The rest of "original" details is not really original. The wonderful firework of flaming arrows we had in "First Knight". The sexy war costume of Guinevere is a leather copy of Lulu's medical stripes in "Fifth Element". Location:I don't know why they had to shoot the movie on location (in Ireland though) with all other relativities (hills and forests must be not hard to find). I guess they took some real castle, but we don't really see much of it, except the long wall. And I have strong impression that the same wall is used for the frontier wall. The gate in it was huge and at first I was pleasantly surprised seeing it opened with 2 horses, but in the end one heavily wounded soldier opens them with only his own weight, so it didn't keep consistent for long either. I guess all of it could be easily replaced with decorations. As well as a very small one but obviously real ring of stones in which the wedding takes place. It is naturally deprived of upper beams which should probably be intact in 4th century, not speaking of the fact that those stone rings were not for weddings like in Christian world and "coronation" looked also quite exotic for modern views. One word ? it's one of poorest speculations on Arthurian legend I've seen. Sadly I was caught on the bait of the title, but happily didn't spend anything on it save from my time.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>King Arthur (2004)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'King Arthur' is by the books, formulaic action/epic for the masses. It is very well produced and executed formulaic action/epic for the masses though. Clive Owen is Arthur, a general fighting for Roman occupied Britain. He too is Roman and wish he too is Roman and wishes to return home. His knights have fought by his side for about 15 years and all want their freedom and no more obligations to Rome. Of course this isn't as easy as they think, and they are ordered on one last mission to rescue some Romans before they can have their issues. As Arthur puts it, this is of course their most dangerous mission yet. So dangerous in fact that they will no doubt succeed, against all odds, bickering between each other, and one of the lesser characters will probably have to sacrifice themselves. Then when it looks like it is all over they will probably stay and fight a big battle for friendship and honour etc. It doesn't take a genius to see where this film is going. The script is a usual action film with new characters. Clive Owen is a very effective Arthur, fantastic as usual and very convincing. His toned down (and in my opinion, more realistic) acting doesn't always go with the other actors techniques, especially Kiara (don't be hypnotised by that mouth) Knightley. The SFX are nothing to hang your jaw low about, but they do often go by unnoticed (always a plus). The film is full of wonderful performances, by actors stuck in poor roles. No character is well developed, the heroine jumps into bed with the hero no questions asked. There is a bit of tension with Lancelot, but that is swept under the rug for the majority of the film. It's nice to see the Arthur legend stripped down to a 'factual' and realistic setting, but with no magic or mystery the film is rather dull. The only scene that really stands out is the fantastic, tense breaking of the ice scene. Where Arthur and his knights stand up against a few hundred Saxons on a frozen lake. Stellen Skarsgard is given a normal evil villain to play, who seems interesting with one line "Finally a man worth killing" but again he is just evil and someone to hate and face off against Arthur. I found myself narrating this film before stuff happened, which takes away from the whole film and makes it slightly comical. For example a secondary character should not go up against the main bad guy, especially when the hero has pledged to kill aforementioned evil doer. And should secondary character have a pet bird he sets free, while he is dyeing, if he should look to the sky, he will see said bird. All very predictable, but some fine action sequences, and a nice build up to the end battle. Despite the films assurance that this is reality and not fantasy, it is unmistakeably Hollywood.</fullReview>

There were not only Sarmatians in Rome's service in Britain, also Saxons, Germans, Francs,... Now, the expression RUS comes from the Swedish Vikings who traveled on the Volga to what is known today as Russia and founded Kiev. The word Rus comes from the Finnish wort "Ruotsi" that means Sweden. But this happened in the 7th and 8th century, what's the messing about in this Arthur Tale??? Now, the Saxons did terrorize both sides of the channel before they set foot in England, but first when the Romans had already gone. And they approached from south not north! The Saxons settled in an area between the Rheine and the Weser an area today between the Netherlands and Holstein. Their Chief Cerdic is good portrayed by Stellan Starsgard but Till Schweiger (his son Cynric) looks like a punk with his blond goatee. The shields the wardrobe guys made are fine so are the standards and some of the helmets. But what the f..ck did the director think by putting crossbows in their hands. The crossbow saw it's birth for military use in wester Europe not before the battle of Hastings in 1066! The church tried to ban it in the middle age cos'it was meant to be a villainous and unchivalrously weapon, but this was almost 900 years after the Artus Saga. Oh dear, the weaponry of our knights is so ridiculous, thank god Excalibur was just a sword and not some magic tool. Mount Badon took place between Bath and London, not Hadrian's Wall!!! We just seen 7 Brits slaughtering 200 Saxons on the Ice, now we see 6 Brits and 50 Woads annihilating 2000 Saxons. The shield wall (or skaldborg) they form is a very good scene (thanks to the military advisers who taught the extras the Saxon battle techniques). 		<username>Mattias Petersson</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Mixed experience</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The historical epic seems to be the genre of choice for Hollywood at the moment. What most of these movies have in common in my opinion is the mighty yawn they induce. While i can certainly appreciate the genre i feel most of these movies are lacking something to make them truly enjoyable. The trend started out well with the pompous but entertaining "Gladiator" and has since reached bottom levels with crap like "Alexander". This however falls somewhere in between.The problem when you make an epic movie is, where does the epic feeling come from? Is it massive battle scenes with thousands of extras? Is it the clichéd dialog full of pompous metaphors and philosophy? Is it the costumes? The music? It's a concept that might be hard to grasp, but still it more or less decides whether a movie such as this one will be successful or not.To me "King Arthur" was a mixed experience. The movie and i got off on the wrong foot with the whole "This is the true story"-statement in the beginning. When it comes to legends and parts of history that we more or less only can make educated guesses about, it always irritates me when people state that they have THE truth. The movie itself is nicely done with nice cinematography and a top-notch overblown adventure score by Hans Zimmer (one of my favorite composers).The main weaknesses are in the script and the direction. The movie has a problem with pacing. Long periods of time more or less nothing happens. When action scenes do happen though they are nicely done, but they are quite few and far between. Clive Owen is a talented actor in my opinion, but his Arthur is a bit too pompous and self-righteous for my taste. Stellan Skarsg?rd on the other hand is almost cartoonish as the antagonist. With more skillful direction these caricatures could have been avoided.In the end this is a more or less forgettable movie. It's not dreadful, slow and inane like Alexander. But it lacks the grandiose and epic feeling that made Gladiator such a feast for the senses. The biggest mistake was probably hiring over-rated Antoine Fuqua to direct, with a more skillful director this could have been more enjoyable. Now it's just entertainment for the moment, nothing to remember but entertaining enough. I rate it 5/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
