		<shortDescription>"King" is perhaps the wrong title</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Antoine Fuqua's "King Arthur" aims to be the new definitive Arthurian movie of the MTV-generation crowd, which has a large shadow to emerge from behind - 1981's "Excalibur," anyone? - John Boorman's supreme and (to some), the definitive film about King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table.The new vision proudly discards the recent mystical and more prominent history of Arthur and his knights and swaps those qualities with a more realistic, gritty tone and look. Only the title is what remains of Sir Thomas Malory's "Le Morte D'Arthur." In this new film, Arthur (Clive Owen) and the knights are under the services of the imperialistic Rome, which is currently in the middle of a costly conflict with the bloodthirsty Saxons.By film's opening, Arthur, Lancelot (Ioan Gruffudd), and the Knights of the Round Table are nearing the ends of their mandatory military services with the Roman army. Arthur is now seen as someone who is devout in his faith, on shaky grounds with his knights especially Lancelot, and has no place to call home as his most dutiful exploits are in butchering men on the battlefield.Bishop Germanius (Ivano Marescotti) enlists a reluctant Arthur to go on one last mission, which is to evacuate a small village from the invading Saxons, who are some of the most brutal warriors the Knights of the Round Table may ever go up against.As stated before, this film aspires to be a more "realistic" telling of the Legend. The cinematography is beautiful, giving a true sense of dread and perhaps even capturing a more honest vision of Europe during the medieval period. There is no Camelot (yet) and Guinevere (Keira Knightley) is one tough cookie, hardly needing any man to come to her rescue; also, there is no affair between her and Lancelot that helps lead to the destruction of Camelot.The presentation of the Legend in this respect is interesting to the say to the least, but the problem is that it's not living up to the best it could be. As Roger Ebert pointed out, the events in the film bear such a strong resemblance to current events in Iraq that it actually deters from the realism of the story, much rather than add to it.One of the reasons Boorman's film succeeded is because of its faithfulness to Malory's classic tales. Honestly, this doesn't make Fuqua's film bad, but I really would have preferred if the title of the film was "Arthur and the Knights," since they're not exactly a legend yet and Arthur doesn't become king until the film's ending.On the plus side, this film should win over the massive MTV-generation crowds, who will definitely get buzzed off the vicious battle sequences (which is much more satisfying in the definitive director's extended cut) and a fine-looking Ms. Knightley who sadly doesn't bare it all in the film's one love scene.A valiant effort is "King Arthur," but I still look to "Excalibur" to pacify my love of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table.7/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Plot hole beyond belief</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although I generally liked this movie the poor script and wooden acting plagued it often. Its best aspects were the sets and art direction, background research into the historical and cultural aspects of the place and time, the cinematography, location shooting and action sequences. The music score was also notable.The sets deserve particular acclaim. Rather than use CG techniques for creating Hadrian's Wall the producers opted to actually build a one kilometer structure, the largest set ever built in Ireland, to lend extra realism to many scenes.That was the good, now for the bad. The plot hinges on the rescue of a nobleman's family, especially his young son who is being groomed for high office in the church. This family's estate is supposedly located north of the Wall and is about to be over-run by an invading army of Saxons. The primary reason for the Wall was to protect Romans on the southern side and keep out the hoards of Picts and other barbarian people (now mainly the Scots) that plagued the Empire's tenuous grip on Britain in the 3rd and 4th centuries A.D. Why an important Roman noble family would choose to or be permitted to live north of the wall and expose themselves to the Pict raids (and require possible rescue from time-to-time by legions stationed at the Wall) is beyond belief give the state of affairs as otherwise presented in the movie.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Coronation of a Legend</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Antoine Fuqua's "King Arthur" attempts to trace the origins of the legends of King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table. The story finds the characters in the wake of the Roman Empire. Arthur (Clive Owen) is a Roman/Briton centurion, Guinevere (Keira Knightley) is a Celtic warrior princess, Lancelot (Ioan Gruffudd) and the other knights are Sarmatian mercenaries. It's a fascinating look at how the stories might have come to be. Personally, I've always believed that all mythology has some basis in historical fact. Here, the pristine, chivalrous images of old are stripped away to expose the gory origins. Guinevere tells Arthur, "We are not the polite people who live in poems," a quote that fits the concept of this story. Let "King Arthur" be a lesson in the evolution of popular legend.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A King's Ransom for Fool's Gold</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What kind of individual inspires a legend? The conclusion from "King Arthur" seems to be: one who disguises lack of charisma with smoldering glances. More importantly, what it is about Jerry Bruckheimer-produced movies that dulls any attempt at sharp characterization? While Johnny Depp in "Pirates of the Caribbean" was one rare exception, Clive Owen is rendered virtually anonymous in the title role. Other principal characters fare no better. Here is a movie that gives its characters not much more than perfunctorily distinctive fighting styles to set them apart from one another.The movie-makers also eshew the fantasy aspects of the "sword in the stone" and "Merlin's sorcery" and try to play up historical accuracy; what is left, however, fails to convey the advertised "untold true story" in any compelling manner. As a salute to accuracy, the battles do look gritty enough (with the "unrated" version apparently restoring all its bloody glory) -- and the movie musters up one exciting battle scene on ice -- but the movie rewards no one searching for a point about the man and the myth. All that remains is a movie that neither informs nor entertains, but is not jaw-droppingly bad enough to be memorable. "King Arthur" falls on its own sword: it is easily forgotten and ironically destined to become an arcane historical footnote in an obscure film encyclopedia.Final note: Why make a big deal about making a female character strong, if ultimately she is just going to fall back on needing a man's protection? And what is with the female battle outfit? Do only "naughty bits" need protecting? Keira Knightly looks undeniably sexy, but there is no feminist gain here.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Poor interpretation of the historical Arthur</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Whilst I have to admit that seeing Kiera Knightly in small amounts of clothing is nothing to sneeze at, the simple fact is that this movie is little more than a typical Bruckheimer eye-candy actioner. There is little here that is fact.It is true that it is closer than the mythical Morte d'Arthur-style of movies we have seen in the past, but it is so full of innaccuracies, while touting itself as the "real" story, that I was very disappointed.Fact: There are various references to the real Arthur, and they actually did get his name right- Arturius Castus.Fact: 462 A.D. is the accepted time of his life.Fact: He was a Roman and did command in Britian around this time.That's about it. The movie really offered little else. I think the problem was with the director. Mr. Fuqua has directed some wonderful movies. Unfortunately, his preachy-style of storytelling ill-fits this genre. Frankly, one could have merged Ridley Scott's "Gladiator" with Mr. Fuqua's "Tears of the Sun" and seen this movie. Arthur was not a commander with a troubled conscience. He was basically a barbarian, and the men who followed him did so because he was more bloodthirsty then they, and he won the battles. The concept that a Pict Guinevere could appeal to his sense of being, and then seduce him is frankly, ludicrous. He would have taken her at his will and at his whim. They were both little more than savages in a savage land living in a savage time, and the thought that the moral sense of righteousness would make Arthur choose the correct path is plain silly.Yet, this is the type of movie that Fuqua excels at. "Tears of the Sun" was the epitome of that style for him. But to take modern-day morals and apply them to people who live 16 centuries ago is at best, banal. Arthur would not place the needs or wants of his knights ahead of the objective. Nor would any commander of the time heed the Roman dictum to go on one last mission. Once the agreement was broken, he would have killed the Bishop and assumed command of all around him. He would not be swayed by the preachings of a young girl: He would have slit her throat and left her in a ditch.And in essence, this is what the real Arturius did. He was never a king, simply a warlord. Actually, Stellan Skarsg?rd's portrayal of Cerdic was more to the actual Arthur than Clive Owen's.The knights were the best thing. They depicted the basic, raw warrior of the time. Ms. Knightley, while lovely, was all wrong for the part. Too small, too beautiful, did they actually think we would believe that she could be a veteran of so many battles without a single blemish when the knights were all a-scarred? Lastly, the "look" of the movie. Hadrian's Wall was not the tall, stately, crennelated monolith as depicted. It still exists today, and was a 4 to 6 foot stone wall. There were no Roman-style buildings: in fact, Arthur's fortifications at best would have had wooden buildings. He was a nomadic warrior: little time for impressive edifices in his life.So, all-in-all a decent popcorn movie, but one that was poorly researched, poorly directed, and another depiction of what Bruckheimer Hollywood believes the real world is like.2 1/2 stars</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Disappointing, at best. I gave it one star, on a scale of zero to four.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Most, or at least many, people seem to like the movie because it's fresh, and puts a new twist on an old legend, and is believable. I say, everyone knows and loves King Arthur as he is, there is no need to change it. And when I think of King Arthur, I think of powerful wizards and magic swords. Arthur is surrounded in unbelievable, but endearing, legend. When anyone who knows and loves the legend of King Arthur and his knights - and let's face it, you don't title the movie "King Arthur" if you're not trying to appeal to those people - hears the name, they think of Camelot, and of the round table, and of Excalibur and Merlin. With the legend so well known, expectations are bound to be high. If this movie were original, it may have received a better score. But because it's a classic, this version really fails to deliver. It's really more of a prequel to the legend, anyway, and one which doesn't seem to follow previous tales. King Arthur is not introduced as a magnificent king or leader. He's nothing more than an indentured servant to Rome, just beginning his sentence of fifteen years. This is when we meet Arthur. A poorly done fast forward (blank screen, straight to "Fifteen Years Later") brings us to the present. For the last fifteen years, Arthur and his knights have been charged with defending the Roman-conquered lands in Northern Britain. Arthur and his knights are still servants of the Romans, and he only has six knights. But, it is at this time he and his knights are supposed to be granted their freedom. Before they can have it, though, there is one last mission. Instead of defending his men and making Rome honor is pact, Arthur submissively accepts the mission. Along the way, they pick up Kiera Knightley, but we'll deal with why her performance was disappointing later. Finally, they return home, mission completed, they're free. Only, the Saxons are now attacking. Throughout the course of the movie, Arthur's identity has been in question. He is a Brit-born, but served the Romans, and believes in Rome. He makes a decision at this point to stop believing in Rome, because he finds out the Rome he believed in does not exist. He will stay and defend Britain, and stay a free man. His brave knights join him. They fight, and with the help of Merlin and his army, they win, and Britain, in the matter of half an hour, is a free land! However, Lancelot, the most famous of Arthur's knights, is dead. And, while it's entirely possible I have my legends confused, wasn't Lancelot married to Guinevere (Kiera Knightley)? Because in this version, the final scene is Arthur and Guinevere getting married. This film took a fantastic legend, and managed to change so many widely accepted, and loved, facts and change them, that the original story is lost. King Arthur should be epic, because it's an epic story. This film attempted to be epic by using special effects and having one of the hottest young actresses on its cover, instead of relying on the story, like it should have. Conclusion: King Arthur is a famous and beloved fairy tale. Its lore is widely known, and accepted. So when you want to make a movie about King Arthur, don't try to fix it, it's not broken. I'm a big Kiera Knightley fan. She's young, but has great potential. I've had the pleasure of seeing Clive Owen in this and "Closer." From what I've seen, I love his acting. And he even managed to portray this version of Arthur very well, a feat that is not easy, considering the material he was working with. Clive gets three stars for his role. Kiera was, as previously stated, was disappointing, and might get as much as one and a half stars, no more. King Arthur inspires images of grandeur, of Excalibur, of Merlin and his magic, of castles with round tables, of Arthur's valiant knights and their brave deeds, of a land of fairy tale that we can dream of. There was no need to try to change its perception, and to do so was a mistake.</fullReview>

But the worst thing about this film is summed up by the writer and producer themselves. Bruckheimer says, "King Arthur is the definitive story of the leader and warrior who emerged to lead the Brittons against the Saxons.". Franzoni says "The truth is that King Arthur lived in a much earlier time. There's a moment in history that we can actually pin down." This is the type of 'Faction' that should have some sort of intellectual warning on it - It is utter nonsense. Arthur very probably was born in an earlier time, but that time was most likely around 490 AD. Since the Roman army left Britain in 410 AD, Arthur and his 'Roman' knights would have had to hang around a while before the battle of Badon (518 AD). Also, if there is any truth at all in the idea that Arthur fought against the Saxons at this battle, he would have to have been the king of Powys, and therefore of strong Welsh blood, and most definitely not Roman, adopted or otherwise. My advice: see this film with a group of friends on DVD, so you can talk or forward over the dialogue, and just watch the battles. If you know anything of history, leave those ideas at the door. 4/10 Historically inaccurate, poorly written, directed, and produced.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Even though this movie is far from being historically accurate at least it attempts to give an accurate portrayal of the times rather than going with the myth surrounding king Authur. (e.g. St Patrick of Ireland, who was undoubtedly a great Irish hero and patriot, but was neither Roman, Catholic or Irish, and fiercely defended the ancient Celtic church in Ireland against the inroads of Catholocism.) It seems that any great hero of the past has automatically been claimed by the Vatican and either made into a myth or a saint in order to cover over the abuses of the church at that time.This movie makes a few mistakes for sure (example: the castle was a crusader style castle rather than early Celtish) and as far as the story line and characters go, who knows if any of that is based on truth, myth is the only source here. 		<date>2004-11-28</date>
		<username>sl1</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>At last, a credible tale of the basis behind the Arthur myths!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Given the period that the character of Arthur originated from, I have long awaited a movie that deals with one of the men who contributed to the myth. It is probable that the legendary Arthur was an amalgamation of several war-lords and resistance leaders in the immediate post-Roman period who, in their several areas and periodds fought the Saxons. This is, by far, the most convincing movie scenario yet. I admit that some elements of the plot were thin: the presence of a prominent Roman family north of Hadrian's wall does stretch credulity. However, the presence of a prominent Romano-British family friendly to Rome would not! But this subtlety would be totally lost on most movie goers so why split hairs? It was nice to see a movie based in Britain that had not been overwhelmed by American accents. Having had the recent history changed by the movies to indicate that US forces had gained or won EVERYTHING in WW2, it was refreshing to note mainly European (or at least cod-European) accents prevailed.Historically, this movie was as true to fact as could be expected. One or 2 of the weapons used were slightly anachronistic but all the technology did exist at the time so no real problem there. Anyone who wants to nit-pick about armorial details should compare this to any other Arthurian movie - that always contains fantasy or 15th-century armour - and then hold their comments on this aspect. As to the actors, the words 'understated', 'credible', 'intense' and 'human' apply. The performances were highly competent but not outstanding. The whole package made for a compelling drama-come-pseudo-documentary that provoked thought and gratified the need for action.Perhaps the most obscure element was making the indigenous northern tribes alien (by speaking Gaelic) and the Saxons closer to the Romans by their use of English. This demonstrated the power of the Arthurian myth that drew diverse peoples together against a more familiar race that was however a common enemy. This is probably the most salient point for our modern times.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>It's grim up north</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although this film looks and feels a lot more 'authentic' than most film treatments of the Arthur myth (jousting knights, anyone?), its claim to be based on facts is very doubtful. We don't know very much about the time in which Arthur lived - or if he lived at all. What we can be fairly sure of, however, is that Guinevere was not a semi-nude Pictish (or 'Woad') warrior princess, Saxons didn't use crossbows and the Roman army didn't organise its troops in bands of five, Sarmatians or not. In other words, this King Arthur, for all its grime and frequent cries of 'Ro-o-o-ome!' is as much a piece of hokum as Camelot. Matters aren't helped by Clive Owens' portrayal of the mythic one as a constipated Cockney barrow-boy or Ioan Gruffudd's oddly peripheral Lancelot. But my main gripe with the film is that it's so boring - the battles (even a scene stolen straight from Eisenstein's Alexander Nevsky) are bloody, sure, but completely unengaging, while the plot is thin and the romantic interest quite unbelievable. So there you go - if costume drama yawns are your bag, this is for you.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I looked forward to this film with great anticipation, which just heightened my disappointment once I got out to see it - it was a good premise, but it was poorly handled by all involved, from set and costume designers (Guinevere's battle dress was most unflattering to poor Ms. Knightley!) to the writer and (especially) the director - Mr. Fuqua may not have had much of a story to work with, but it is obvious that he better understands a more modern, urban setting (witness "Training Day") than 5th-century Britain. Hadrian's Wall (or its remnants) may be seen today, so show it as it really was - a barrier complex (from the south to north: an earth mound, then a ditch and further mound, then an open area on which a road was built to allow easy access to all parts of the wall all along its length, then the main wall itself, and just to the north of that, a deep ditch) with small forts at close intervals, larger ones more distantly-spaced - not a massive Roman Great Wall; leave out chain mail, crossbow-toting Saxons (in the North, for goodness' sake - where no Saxon ever went!) and Roman villas north of Hadrian's line. The film could be forgiven these blunders if it had been billed as a fantasy, a la Conan, and set in an entirely fictional time and place - but it wasn't, so it can't be.The saddest thing of all is that, as badly as this movie tanked, we may never see a better-handled treatment of the post-Roman, pre-Saxon (as opposed to Age of Chivalry) Arthur concept - Hollywood has a long memory when comes to movies that don't make money.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Any movie about King Arthur and his Knights is bound to be great, right? I mean, the legend of Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table is on of the most exciting tales around, so a movie about them just has to be great. Especially when it claims to be the "true" story behind the legend. Well, you better think again. This movie somehow manages to take one of the most exciting, interesting and well developed stories that exist and turn it into a bore. First of all, it is not the "true" story of Arthur, simply because nobody knows what the true story is. There are a number of historical figures that are assumed to have fueled the legend (the film's Roman Arthur is just one of them)and the most probable scenario is that the legend of King Arthur is based on several historic figures and events (and some of the legend's elements were created much later to spice things up). And the movie is not even historically accurate (weapons and things that were invented centuries later, the Saxons invading the wrong part of Britain etc.).But besides that, is the movie any good? Well, not really. Mediocre acting, inadequate script, some lame dialog, undeveloped characters are some of the films characteristics. The portrayal of Arthur as a goodie-two-shoes Christan made me feel sick. And Xena, the warrior princess - sorry I mean Guinevere - delivers the final blow. 	<review>
		<date>2004-09-10</date>
		<username>James Hitchcock</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointing Epic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In his novel 'The Lyre of Orpheus', the Canadian author Robertson Davies makes the point that, although the Arthurian legends have inspired a number of great works of literature, there has never been a particularly successful dramatic version, either in the theatre or in the cinema. Purcell's opera might be thought to be an exception, but Davies discounts it on the grounds that its plot differs radically from the standard version of the legend.This latest film version also diverges from what we have come to think of as the Arthurian story. Arthur is not a mediaeval monarch but a Roman military commander in fifth century Britain. Arthur's troops, although they bear the names traditionally associated with the Knights of the Round Table (Lancelot, Gawaine, etc.) are not knights as we think of them, but Sarmatian cavalrymen serving with the Roman army. Merlin is not a magician, but the leader of a British uprising against Roman rule. Guinevere is a British warrior-maiden. Excalibur and the Round Table itself make brief appearances, but there is no Quest for the Holy Grail, no adulterous romance between Lancelot and Guinevere, no Mordred and no Morgan La Fay.At the beginning of the film, Arthur and his men have just completed their fifteen years of service with the legions and are due to receive the discharge papers that will allow them to return to their Sarmatian homeland. They are, however, blackmailed by a Roman bishop into undertaking one final mission. They are to rescue a wealthy Roman senator and his family from their villa north of Hadrian's Wall, as the legions are about to leave Britain and the family will be in danger from both rebellious Britons and invading Saxons. (The film does not explain why such an influential Roman family should be living outside the boundaries of the Empire in what they would have regarded as barbarian territory.). The villa is presumably somewhere in present-day Scotland, a relatively small country about the size of Maine. The film-makers, however, seem to have had little idea of the distances involved, as it is summer when the knights set off, winter when they arrive at the villa and summer again when they return to the Wall. Even given that travel in Roman times was much slower than it is today, it is difficult to see why they needed six months for this journey.Arthur starts the film as a Christian and an idealist with a strong belief in the civilising mission of Rome. Gradually, however, he becomes disillusioned by the Romans' cynical duplicity and treatment of the native Britons, and comes to sympathies with the Britons' struggle for freedom. Rather than return to Sarmatia, he and his men throw in their lot with the Britons, who have hitherto been their enemies, and help them fight the Saxons. This is a film that relies heavily on ethnic and religious stereotyping; Arthur and his Sarmatians are civilised and decent, the Romans are sophisticated but cruel and decadent, the Britons are noble savages and the Saxons ignoble ones. Christianity also comes out of the film badly; the Romans are Christians who use their faith to justify keeping the pagan Britons in slavery. Arthur loses his faith when he learns that his friend the philosopher Pelagius has been executed as a heretic by the Church authorities. (The real Pelagius was indeed condemned for heresy by the Church, but there is no evidence that he was put to death. The manner and exact date of his death are unknown, but it is generally agreed that he died about fifty years before the time of the film).Instead of interpreting the traditional legend, the film presents itself as a 'historically accurate' version of the story. This is, unfortunately, an impossible aim. One cannot tell the story of Arthur with any accuracy, because there is no agreement as to the facts of his life. Even his very existence as a historical figure has been called into question. The film-makers have not even bothered to stick to known historical facts about the period. The withdrawal of the Roman legions actually took place in 410 AD; in the film they are shown as still being in Britain more than fifty years after that date. The Romans and Britons are shown as two quite distinct cultures, with the Britons still living as they had in pre-Roman times, when all the evidence is that, after nearly four centuries of Roman rule, many Britons, particularly among the elite, had adopted Roman ways. The Saxons are shown as invading Northern Britain in the region of Hadrian's Wall; in reality they first landed in the South-East and gradually moved north and west. The Romans never conquered Sarmatia, a region roughly corresponding to the modern Ukraine. The warriors of the period are shown making use of such anachronistic devices as the stirrup, the crossbow and, most bizarrely of all, barbed wire, something that was not invented until the nineteenth century. If the film itself were stronger, it would be possible to overlook both its departure from the 'Le Morte d'Arthur' legend and its historical inaccuracies and to see it simply as an exciting Dark Age adventure story, a sort of sword-and-sorcery fantasy without the sorcery. Unfortunately, it does not even work on this level. The story is confusing and difficult to follow, and the acting undistinguished. Clive Own makes an uncharismatic Arthur, and most of the knights do not emerge as individuals. (The one exception is Ray Winstone's comic-relief turn as Sir Bors, a mixture of foul-mouthed vulgarian and devoted father of a huge brood of children). Keira Knightley makes a splendid-looking Guinevere, but she lacks the physique to be convincing as a female warrior. (The film-makers obviously felt she would look sexier as a Boudicca figure than as a Romano-British lady). There are some effective set-pieces, such as the battle on the ice (possibly homage to Eisenstein's 'Alexander Nevsky'), but I found the film as a whole a great disappointment, much weaker than this summer's other epic, 'Troy'. Robertson Davies's dictum still holds good; there is no great cinematic version of the Arthurian legend. Except, of course, 'Monty Python and the Holy Grail'. 4/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I wasn't expecting too much from "King Arthur," but I thoroughly enjoyed it. The political tangles are sometimes hard to understand, as are the accents, but the performances are excellent, and the battle scenes are superbly filmed, not showing too much gore, yet effectively suggesting the madness of the battlefield. I greatly appreciated that the love story was kept to a minimum, and the one "scene of sensuality" was tastefully filmed. I think it's interesting that, unlike in so many epics, the love story is not a pointless subplot, but a union symbolic of Arthur's accepting his mixed blood and ending his tradition of war with the Woads. "King Arthur" is what an epic should be: a quest, the measure of a man (and woman; Guinevere is the symbol of feminism in this film), and no clichéd "love-conquers-all" resolution. Thank you to the filmmakers!</fullReview>
	</review>

I love the character qualities. Arthur is a Roman and a Christian, and he must deal with his Sarmatian knights who have conflicting (and in Lancelot's case, almost confronting) ideals. 		<shortDescription>Brilliant and highly credible new angle on the old legend</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Besides being a huge fan of Mr Owen's (I adore actors who can credibly deliver a broken character) I simply loved this fresh angle on the old legend of Arthur. This film is no variation on the old 'intrigue at Camelot' theme, but a completely new approach. It is much more consistent with what (little) we know about 6th century life than the usual King Arthur films. They used to make me think of the time when the legends were written: the characters acted like 15th century courtiers (sometimes almost Macchiavellian style) and troubadours.In this film the équipe of the Round Table are not superhuman goody-goody guys but men of flesh and blood without any fear of shedding some. And the swords really get red in the fight (i.e. the filmmakers were meticulously authentic). Even the Saxons (the enemy) are not just bloodthirsty baddies but conquerors with a different world picture from Arthur's and therefore a different standard of behaviour.I give this film the highest rating: great cast, superb acting, simply super!!!</fullReview>

		<fullReview>My love of this kind of quasi-historical epic (Gladiator, Braveheart...) and the fact that one of my favourite films is John's Boorman's fabulous Excalibur led me to ignore the critics and shell out my hard earned cash to see this film at the cinema. 		<fullReview>This is a telling of Arthur the Roman who became Arthur, King of the Brits.The story's set in GB, during winter. The Romans pull back, but one group of recruited Samaritans, led by Arthur, must go on a last quest before they can be free men: they must save an outpost.The group has an attitude towards the romans, nonetheless they kill their own people. However as they discover the romans at the outpost are really inhumane (towards their own people) they decide to cooperate with their own people again to fight the saxes, who are intruding their lands.The storyline is absolutely chronological and has no climax or sudden plot-turns. The movie starts with Lancelot telling the story of his getting recruited, which then is abandoned. The motives are the quest for the outpost and the defeat of the saxes. 		<username>DrLenera</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>About as historically accurate as The Sword In The Stone, but good in parts</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Films based on the Arthurian legend vary from the superb [Excalibur], to the awful [First Knight], to the okay Camelot]. This one promised to be one of the most interesting. An attempt to portray the 'Real King Arthur'without all that fantasy stuff, and supposedly based on 'recent archaeological findings"' It's not unenjoyable, and at times is actually quite good. One thing is certain though- the claims of historical accuracy are complete nonsense.Of course no one should expect any film to be completely factual, and there are differing opinions on Arthur anyway, with this film offering just one view. However, anybody with a basic grasp of history will notice things like the Battle Of Badon Hill taking place a century earlier than it actually did. Unlike in this film, the Saxons did not even threaten Britain until well after all the Romans had left. And it's best not to even ponder idiocies like a Roman nobleman living beyond Hadrian's Wall in isolation yet the area being so dangerous that Arthur and his knights are warned not to go there. Also, how come the Saxons never have ANY archers?Also annoying is that the filmmakers, despite the supposed grit and realism, keep throwing in names and elements familiar from the legend, and then hardly mention them again. Why have Lancelot and Guinevere glance at each other ,and then have nothing come of it? The film would have been better off without them glancing at each other at all. At least the round table looks good.Yet as a simple actioner the film isn't bad. There could have been more fighting, but the battles, especially the lengthy final one, are pretty good despite being obviously edited down to get a lower rating, and there is some stunning photography especially during the scenes set around snow. Yes, the film has a bleak look ,but it's an oddly beautiful kind of bleakness, and it really gives the 'Dark Ages' feel that the filmmakers elsewhere struggled to achieve. Clive Owen is adequate, but sees ill at ease, and is not helped by the fact that we don't really know what motivates his character to do what he does. His knights are hardly characterised at all, except for Ray Winstone, who as usual just grunts and shouts.In fact this is really a film to see and not hear. Some of the dialogue is horrendous ["don't worry, I'll stop them from raping you", says Guinevere to Arthur before one battle with the Saxons] and composer Hans Zimmer once again is under the assumption that a synthesizer played very loud is a good substitute for a full orchestra. When it comes down to it, though, it's the script that is the film's biggest problem. With some decent rewriting and a few changes, this could have really been a fine, if still historically suspect, film. As it is, this is still just about worth seeing ,if only to think of the film that could have been.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>who killed King Arthur?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**SPOILERS**My moneys on Peter Jackson.Now before I start getting flamed by all the rest of the geeky fan boys and girls out there, let me qualify my statement. I love LOTR, but PJ has spoiled me. Every epic battle film now has to be judged against his magnificent work, and inevitably is found wanting. King Arthur never really stood a chance.I'm a big fan of the legends of Arthur, in all their forms - Mallory's medieval fantasies, Bernard Cornwell's bloody Saxon imaginings, Boorman's sexy violence . . . . so I was really looking forward to seeing this film. Then I started seeing the trailers. 'THE TRUE STORY!!!'Granted, the main thread of the story does have some basis in historical fact. The Sarmatian warriors existed, as did Artorius Castus. However, to call this 'the true story' is ludicrous at best, at worst, it is yet another insulting example of big budget American film directors hijacking OUR history for their own ends. I'm sure I don't need to to dwell on the many inaccuracies - using the Castus thread should have excluded Guinevere, Lancelot and Excalibur; why did the Saxons invade via Scotland, etc etc etc.It's all been done to death by people who are better informed than I am. I could have put all that stuff to one side, if only the film had been good enough. But it wasn't.Visually, I liked it. I wish I lived in the Britain it depicted. Those blue skies, rolling green hills, spectacular snow covered mountains . . . . simply stunning. The confusion of the battlefield was well shot and it looked like it had been done the old fashioned way with lots of enthusiastic extras rather than CG characters. The scene on the frozen river was superb, well shot and extremely dramatic. The knights and the Britons looked terrific, if a little homogeneous. And Keira Knightley had some very pretty dresses; if a little impractical - I'm sure that she'd have been a little chilly on that river, not mention the fact that those sleeves would have been tangling in her bowstring something painful.The story as well, was well thought out, if a little predictable. Where the film fell over was the lack of characterisation, appalling acting and pandering to the censors.It was extremely difficult to tell the knights apart. I'm pretty well up on who is who, but I really struggled. Without some prior knowledge of the subject, I would have really been struggling. We had brooding knight with a birdy, brooding knight who wants to go home, honourable knight who wants to go home, ugly knight who talks about having a p*** a lot, ugly knight with a heart of gold . . . . Even the official website can't keep track of them, confusing Galahad and Gawain. The Saxons were even less well defined, and we only met two of them! There was big hairy daddy Saxon and big bald son Saxon. I never heard any names used during the film. All the characters were incredibly 2D and it was difficult to feel much for them. Ioan Gruffyd did his best, but it was obvious that many of his scenes had been butchered to pander to the American test audiences. The much vaunted chemistry between Lancelot and Guinevere was reduced to his catching a glimpse of her shoulder whilst she had a wash. Keira Knightley did her best to be a dramatic warrior queen, but was fighting a losing battle with her lackluster leading man. Clive Owen was unbelievably awful in this film. His Arthur had an impossibly square jaw and SHOUTED A LOT. If I'd have been one of his knights I'd have finished him off myself long before this stage. He had only one scene where he was at all believable - where he threatened the bishop.And finally, the epic battle scenes. Where no one ever sheds any blood. All the elements of a great epic battle where there, but they had been sanitised. Thus vanquished enemies simply sigh and roll over. There is no blood, and no real pain. In order to get around showing this side of the battlefield, we instead get repetition after repetition - Arthur riding towards the camera and 'beheading it', Tristan slo-mos towards Cerdic, Arthur slo-mos towards Cerdic, Guinevere slo-mos towards Cynric etc etc. And the happy ever after ending just made me feel nauseous.To summarise then. King Arthur had all the ingredients of a perfect Summer Blockbuster. But once again, Bruckheimer over eggs the pudding and cooks it at too high a temperature.</fullReview>

I could have forgiven the total recasting of the Arthurian legend, down to its repositioning centuries earlier than is normally suggested back to the contraction of the Roman Empire, if there had been a half-decent plot and some less stilted lines, surprising absences given that the writer David Franzoni authored the script for "Gladiator". "Gladiator" had Russell Crow and "Troy" had Brad Pitt, true stars with charismatic presence, but Clive Owen as Arthur cannot rise above his essentially television persona and Keira Knightly, lovely and spirited though she, is too young and has too few lines as Guinevere. In fact, the best performances come from Ray Winstone as one of Arthur's rough-hewn knights and Stellan Skarsg?rd as the leader of the brutal Saxons.If you can live with these faults and keep your expectations in check, then this is a reasonably uplifting action movie that attempts to do for early English nationalism what "Braveheart" did for Scotland.</fullReview>

		<username>TheNorthernMonkee</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>entertaining, whether accurate or not</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILERSEverybody always talks about historical accuracy, whilst at the same time, others attempt to add entertainment to the mix. Eventually what evolves is a film which attempts to entertain the audience but do this as truthfully as possible. With the legend of King Arthur, lots of people have their theories. Some claim he was Roman, some claim he was Welsh, some claim he was Roman, some Scots have even started to claim he was Scottish. With this "factual" version of his story however, irrelevant of whether it's accurate or not, Antoine Fuqua has created a fun, action packed movie which keeps the audience entertained.In this version of events, Arthur (or whatever the Roman wording is) is a Roman General who leads a group of Samerians around Britain. Keeping south of Hadrian's Wall and fighting Merlin's occasional little invasion, life is Hell for Arthur and his troops who all just want to return to their homelands. On their final day as conscripts of the Roman army however, this band of knights are sent on one final quest to rescue a Roman family. On this quest, Arthur will find his loyalties tested and he will meet his future Queen.Now "King Arthur" is not a bad film. It starts perhaps too slowly, and the script is absolutely abysmal, but it is an action movie, and that's all it was ever meant to be. With Clive Owen, Ioan Gruffudd, Ray Winstone and Kiera Knightley, the film has an ensamble of decent British actors who can perform adequately. Unfortunately for Owen and Gruffudd, their characters never properly develop and are giving some awful lines to spout. In contrast, Knightley and Winstone are given some beauties which they deliver well. Winstone in particular as the violent father Bors is superb as he walks around drinking, making comments about his lover and fighting.With Antoine Fuqua as director, it is easy to feel negative. With his most famous previous work being "Training Day" (2001), he doesn't at first glance look like the right man to direct this film. He is however brilliant. At times with this film, the shots and organisation of this film is superb. In fact, if anything Fuqua is unlueky. Sacrificing the majority of the legend in favour of what he is told is the true story, he sacrifices a lot of what attracts people to the legend of King Arthur. Merlin is a brilliant leader, but not a magician, Excalibur is simply Arthur's sword, and there is no love affair between Lancelot and Gwenever. By doing this, Fuqua has opened himself up for criticism, but this would be unfair. Another brilliant example is the fight scenes, the final battle in particular takes a while to get going, and the reasoning is that Fuqua has shown that Arthur was a tactical genius, sacrificing simple disorganised chaos (like most films) for a plan of action splitting troops up and fighting the battle tactically. Whilst not perhaps as enjoyable as simply having your heroes running into a crowd of enemies and emerging victorious, this tactical astuteness is more realistic and ultimately more satisfying.There are countless philosophical viewpoints which can be raised from this film, mainly bringing into play the negative view the film appears to take on Christianity and the Roman ideals. Ultimately however, "King Arthur" feels like it has tried hard to balance entertainment with a popularist view of the legend. Whether this new take on the story is accurate or not, that should not matter. This film is entertaining, not straight from the start, but from about twenty minutes in through to the end. It might not be the best historical "Epic" piece ever (that title will always go to "Gladiator" from 2000), but it's still an entertaining film worthy of viewing. A definate seven out of ten.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>**SPOILERS**Some might say Clive Owen. Others might say Antoine Fuqua. I say it was Peter Jackson.Now before all the geeky fan guys and girls start flaming me, let me expand. Now I was a little torn about this film. On the one hand, I love the King Arthur myths - in all their forms - and a couple of hours of heroic guys in armour with bows sounds great to me. I wish I lived in a Britain that looked like that. The battle scene on the river was incredibly shot - the bright blue sky contrasting with the dazzling whiteness of the snow and the dark leather and furs of the warriors. The costume design was magnificent - the richness of the Roman armour, the dirty peasants, the British warriors, and of course Guinevere's pretty dresses. Owen, I believe, has deliberately avoided offering too much to ensure King Arthur remains an enigmatic character - he is a Captain of a Roman unit, he tells people what to do he doesn't explain why or how. Thankfully this Arthur does not come with a wife, 3 kids and a labrador - he is what he is, a warrior who cares for the people.I was also impressed with the battle scenes that got their point across without becoming exploitative. So too was the photography which enhanced the movie without turning it into a postcard for Irish tourism.There were faults - no doubt the medieval scholars will have a ball pointing out the anarchronisms and yes the role of Guinevere is wasted on Keira Keightly. However the movie has stayed true to the heart of the Arthurian legends - that of people who would stand up and protect the weak and innocent, of their loyalty and of their refusal to betray the trust placed in them. As a fan of the legend I'm glad I did actually go and see the film!</fullReview>

		<date>2004-07-27</date>
		<username>jwkenne (jwkenne@attglobal.net)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It could be the true story -- but it gets it all wrong anyway</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Where to begin....Yes, there is a connection between Arthur and the Sarmatians. But the idea of Sarmatian boys being drafted in their homeland is all wrong. A whole retired regiment of Sarmatian mercenaries was settled in Britain in the 2nd century, and they continued to live there as a distinct cultural enclave for two hundred years that we know of, and probably into the Arthurian era. Their original commander was named Lucius (personal name) Artorius (family name) Castus (sub-family name). A descendant of his /might have been/ the real Arthur. On the other hand, it's also possible that his name became a word for "General" among the British Sarmatians.If the "Woad People" are supposed to be Britons, it's wrong; the Britons were Christian and Romanized by Arthur's time. If they're supposed to be the Picts, it's still wrong; the Picts were just as bad as the Saxons, attacking the Britons from the north while the Saxons attached from the east. (Yes, the east; if you sail from the Netherlands and/or Denmark to Britain, you don't normally arrive in Scotland.)Pelagius, as far as we know, died a natural death, and was not condemned as a heretic in his lifetime. And the movie's notion that Pelagius's theological ideas concerning free will are somehow related to Jeffersonian notions of political freedom is so confused as nearly to constitute a pun.Most of the knights named (Lancelot, Galahad, Dagonet....) are almost certainly creations of French literary works, not found in the early legends. And Dagonet was Arthur's /jester/. Bors is very likely a Sarmatian name, though.Add to this a jumpy plot, clumsy cinematography (the layout of the land at the climactic battle is incomprehensible, and the action is shot from both flanks, a gross cinematic sin), bad continuity (giant gates that need to be turned by Clydesdales in one scene apparently open and close by sheer magic in another scene), scenes that go nowhere.... It's a mess.Now understand, it's not absolutely disgusting. You can watch it, as long as you don't take it too seriously. And it /is/ truer to what probably really happened than any other Arthurian movie I know of. And Keira Knightley is a total hottie. But "King Arthur" is still a mess.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>If this is the truth, stick with the myth</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How disappointing. I love fantasy and the legend of King Arthur, but recognizing that it's fiction made me open for a 'demystified' take on the story. I was ready for an Arthur with no Lady of the Lake, no magical sword in the stone, no wizardry from Merlin, no gleaming armor, etc. however, what I wasn't expecting was that it would be this dull.The reason truth becomes legend and legend becomes myth is because in the retelling, the detail get embellished and made (more) interesting. Apparently, stripped of myth, the original story was just plain boring. Or at least, this movie's telling of the story was boring."King Arthur" feels like a 3 1/2 hour movie ruthlessly chopped down to 2 hours 5 minutes. So many characters and events are touched upon but nothing is ever developed. Famous names are tossed about - Merlin, Guinevere, Lancelot, Galahad, Gawain, Tristan - but ultimately, since they are so sketchily characterized, their seems to be no reason for the famous names. They could be just any guy with a sword and a horse. In fact, it is the lesser known names that are more developed (such as Bors), but overall, I got the impression that character development scenes were cut in favor of (particularly bloodless) battle scenes.Motivation was lacking all around, from Arthur himself (what exactly was he fighting for anyway?) to the villainous invading Saxon played by Stellan Skarsg?rd (did he even have a name?) to the evil priest guy Arthur &amp; co. are supposed to rescue. People just act in ways that are required of them to further the plot, never because of any internal character-based motivation.Questions abound. Why was Arthur so loyal to Rome? Why were the knights (essentially slaves) so loyal to Arthur? Why were the Saxons invading? Why were the Romans at that outpost torturing people? Why (and when exactly) did Merlin &amp; Arthur join up? What was Arthur ever 'King' of?This movie *needed* to be rated 'R' and at least twice as long in order to tell the story completely and more realistically. It needed more character development and battle scenes that were more than just clashing CGI army and quick cuts of swords.On the plus side, Kiera Knightly as Guinevere kicked some ass and looked good doing it. The fight on the frozen ice was clever and well-filmed. And Ray Winstone as the knight Bors was a standout amongst the generally generic knights.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The film, the reviews, the legend...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It is always interesting to read the reviews of others in assessing a film that touches on traditional mythos in society. There is no shortage of reviewers from the UK who feel as if their legend has been tainted. Notably this film succeeds by attempting to integrate an actual historical investigation into the origins of the Arthur legend. As the basis for the film this works and adds a fresh perspective to the well known story. However, where the film begins to fade is the interjection of all of Arthur's mythological characters and props. Merlin is now the leader of the native tribes, Guinevere a pagan warrior, etc. The scene which has Arthur recollecting about his mother and Excalibur is especially contrived. Its not that these artistic liscenses have destroyed the fabric of the film, it is simply that in attempting to de-mystify the legend all they have done is reformulate the old myth in a different era...rather unoriginal but understandable. The film's major failing is in the direction which attempts to create the sense that this new legend must be supported by Hollywood superhero tactics which are so wholly laughable as to detract from the whole film. One expressly humorous scene shows a Knight with an arrow piercing his chest throw a sword twenty odd feet perfectly into his nemesis before he expires. Schwarzeneger would be proud. The funny thing here is that most of these annoyances could be edited out to save this film's credibility if anyone cared. Finally with all of these shortcomings the film is still actually enjoyable. The knights are all cast well and likable as men driven by their sense of freedom during Roman reign. Gruffudd, Mikkelsen, and Winstone all deserve mention. Here I believe the all-Euro casting succeeds at least in the US where fresher faces add a nuance to new mythos. </fullReview>

		<date>2004-07-23</date>
		<username>jonann2</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best Arthur Movie EVER!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really loved this film on so many levels. First, I for one am glad that the filmmakers decided to get past most of the romanticized chivalry related crap that has been tacked onto Arthurian legend over the centuries, in order to get to the roots of the story of Arthur (well, mostly). For those who found this confusing, its probably because they are used to the glittery, knightly, courtly stuff they see in most Arthurian related films like First Knight, Excalibur, etc. But scholars who study Arthur in order to find who the real man might have been would say that most of that was added on by later bards and storytellers to bring Arthur to more relevance in their own time. Now, granted, the filmmakers who made this movie do the same thing. King Arthur does try to appeal to modern audiences with wisecracking heroes and Braveheart like action.But at the center of the film is the core story of who Arthur probably was. Most Arthurian scholars now believe that King Arthur was a Roman general, possibly of Britanic heritage, who commanded forces in Roman Britain around the time of the fall of the western Roman Empire in 476 A.D. When the Romans began to pull out of Britain to defend their own home city from Barbarian invasions, the Saxons (a group from another part of Europe) invaded. Arthur and those forces who remained loyal to him joined forces with the Britons to drive off the Saxon invasion. Arthur became King, and a time of peace and prosperity came to Britain. That's the core story.Now, what about the round table and Camelot and Lancelot and Guinevere? Most scholars think most of these characters were added by later storytellers, along with Merlin the wizard and Excalibur and the mists of avalon. Its like telling a fish story. The fish gets bigger and bigger every time you tell the tale.What is so brilliant about this film is that it correctly places Arthur in terms of time and place, but at the same time preserves some of the characters and situations of later Athurian myth in such a way that it makes a nice mesh of historical facts (as far as can be determined) and folklore. This creates a wonderful texture of a time and place in our distant past, and one that is filled with fictional characters that are very interesting and exciting. The fictional characters themselves are created in such a way that they also belong in that time and place. Arthur's knights in the film, for example, are Samanian warriors from another part of Europe conquered by the Romans. They were drafted into the Roman Army for a certain term of service in Rome's provinicial forces, in this case their Britain garrison. This conscription really did occur in the later Roman imperial period. What you are really seeing on the screen in a historical context is the death of the Roman world (and the ancient western world along with it) and the birth of the Middle Ages. Beyond the historical stuff, this is a great action/adventure picture, filled with excellent sword play and medieval archery. Its very reminiscent of Braveheart in this respect. I highly recommend this film to everyone. The reviewers who panned this film are just plain wrong, in my humble opinion.</fullReview>
	</review>

For those who found this confusing, its probably because they are used to the glittery, knightly, courtly stuff they see in most Arthurian related films like First Knight, Excalibur, etc. But scholars who study Arthur in order to find who the real man might have been would say that most of that was added on by later bards and storytellers to bring Arthur to more relevance in their own time. Now, granted, the filmmakers who made this movie do the same thing. King Arthur does try to appeal to modern audiences with wisecracking heroes and Braveheart like action.But at the center of the film is the core story of who Arthur probably was. Most Arthurian scholars now believe that King Arthur was a Roman general, possibly of Britanic heritage, who commanded forces in Roman Britain around the time of the fall of the western Roman Empire in 476 A.D. When the Romans began to pull out of Britain to defend their own home city from Barbarian invasions, the Saxons (a group from another part of Europe) invaded. Arthur and those forces who remained loyal to him joined forces with the Britons to drive off the Saxon invasion. Arthur became King, and a time of peace and prosperity came to Britain. That's the core story.Now, what about the round table and Camelot and Lancelot and Guinevere? Most scholars think most of these characters were added by later storytellers, along with Merlin the wizard and Excalibur and the mists of avalon. Its like telling a fish story. The fish gets bigger and bigger every time you tell the tale.What is so brilliant about this film is that it correctly places Arthur in terms of time and place, but at the same time preserves some of the characters and situations of later Athurian myth in such a way that it makes a nice mesh of historical facts (as far as can be determined) and folklore. This creates a wonderful texture of a time and place in our distant past, and one that is filled with fictional characters that are very interesting and exciting. The fictional characters themselves are created in such a way that they also belong in that time and place. Arthur's knights in the film, for example, are Samanian warriors from another part of Europe conquered by the Romans. They were drafted into the Roman Army for a certain term of service in Rome's provinicial forces, in this case their Britain garrison. This conscription really did occur in the later Roman imperial period. What you are really seeing on the screen in a historical context is the death of the Roman world (and the ancient western world along with it) and the birth of the Middle Ages. Beyond the historical stuff, this is a great action/adventure picture, filled with excellent sword play and medieval archery. Its very reminiscent of Braveheart in this respect. I highly recommend this film to everyone. The reviewers who panned this film are just plain wrong, in my humble opinion.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-07-19</date>
		<username>P Carr (pavel@fan.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Some of the parts are greater than the whole.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"King Arthur" takes a different approach than most representations of Arthurian legend, but unfortunately the final product does little to distinguish itself from other cinematic stories, which is why it is suffering a dismal box office fate ($38 mil so far), even though it probably deserves somewhat better. The opening title card claims that the movie is set in the Dark Ages, based on the true stories behind the medieval legends. That means we don't see actual kings or typical knights, but rather an armor-clad Magnificent Seven, a posse in the service of the Holy Roman Empire. Led by Arthur (Clive Owen) with all of the commonly known men in tow (Lancelot, Tristan, etc.), the septuplet fights for various causes and freedoms in Britain. Along the way, they encounter a completely different representation of Guinevere (Keira Knightley). Instead of the usual damsel-in-distress, she is now a warrior princess of the Woads, an Indian-like indigenous people of Britain who are fighting to maintain possession of their land. Regardless of actual veracity, the story is wholly believable enough despite a couple glaring question marks. The base problem with King Arthur is similar to, though not as severe as, that which plagued the last screen incarnation of the legend, "First Knight". Like "Lord of the Rings", Arthurian tales (or anything similar) should soar, inspiring awe with action, visuals, and nobility. While King Arthur contains flashes of brilliance (i.e. the brief flashback to Arthur's youth, or round table visuals), the inconsistencies in pace and tone do not allow the viewer to become emotionally involved. Some of that is due to director Antoine Fuqua's inability to direct battle-driven movies. He showed it in "Tears of the Sun", and he repeats his errors here. In neither film does he bother to distinguish much between the various protagonists. Lancelot, Galahad, Gawain, Tristan...these men are legendary, and here they are reduced to being one-trick ponies instead of pillars of greatness and nobility. The battle scenes, which should highlight the movie, are possess little sense of direction or overall momentum, but overly concentrate on individual conflicts (which are decent) within a generic mass fray. Plus the movie was hampered by its clear intentions of avoiding an R rating. The entire movie, whether it be battle scenes, jokes, or love scenes, feels censored, a notch tamer than the circumstances warrant. That tempers the movie into something lesser than the premises promise. That's a shame, because it wastes the splendid cinematography efforts of Slawomir Idziak (Black Hawk Down). Granted, the combination of Britain's rolling hills and classic castles isn't the most difficult thing to photograph, but Idziak does not paint his cinematic canvas with the conventional lush greens and blues of "Braveheart", but instead endows the movie with a gritty, somber hue. While this looks fantastic, it also contributes to another downfall of King Arthur; its generally subdued and gritty nature contrasts with the soaring themes that should be present in this sort of movie. The palette, although well done, aids in holding the movie back from being truly engaging or compelling, which is what separates great action films (like "LOTR") from the pack. Another dichotomy of "King Arthur" lies in the reasonable to good performances that still don't propel the movie past mediocrity. In fact what saves the picture from abject failure is the overall gravitas of the entirely European cast. Owen effectively brings an everyman quality to Arthur, but still doesn't quite capture his inspirational spirit, despite a solid turn. With the exception of a surprising wooden Stellan Skarsgard, everyone else, despite an assortment of accents, looks right and seems completely at home in their roles. Perhaps this is due to the stage backgrounds that most of the cast has. Whatever the reason, their quality performances make the movie more entertaining than it has any right to be. In this case some of the parts (not the sum of the parts) are greater than the whole, resulting in a flick that occasionally leaps to life, but just as often crumbles to rubble. I'm the type for whom sitting through any war-themed film is easy, so I'm not sorry I saw King Arthur, but I also can't recommend it. Go see a matinee. Bottom Line: Five of ten. But if this isn't your genre, you won't even enjoy it that much.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Saw King Arthur today, and there was much rejoicing...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I say there was much rejoicing because the shadow of "Holy Grail" will necessarily loom large over any movie about King Arthur and his English Knights (Eeeenglish K-niggits?) and I feel the filmmakers behind this one really were doing everything in their power to avoid any possible scene or bit of dialogue that would invoke snotty Frenchmen, Knights who say "Ni", Shrubbery (though the Saxon invaders would certainly qualify), and watery tarts with swords (this attempt failed, unfortunately, due to the soppy presence of Keira K-niggetly). Half-Roman, half-Celtic Artorious is indeed fortunate in his comrades in arms. In short order, we are introduced to nostril-flaring, smoldering Sir Lancelot, the Quite Frequently Pissed-Off; cheeky Sir Galahad, the Utterly Winsome; vaguely-psycho Sir Tristan, the Unkempt; bullroaring Sir Bors, the Ridiculously Fertile; tight-lipped Sir Dagonet, the Scary-Looking Moppet-Dandler; and finally, nondescript Sir Gawain, the Not-Quite-So-Winsome-As-Sir-Galahad.With a cadre of fighters such as these, Arthur's many successes in the field of battle should come as no surprise. Their foes include the Woad warriors, a proud race of Celts, and the Saxon invaders from the North, but along the way they also have to confront Romans who are oleagenous enough to put several of Italy's most productive olive groves out of business. This is a very important plot point, for those of you who are connoisseurs of plot, because it plants a seed of doubt in Arthur's mind that perhaps a quiet retirement in Rome surrounded by more of same might not be quite what they pictured in the glossy brochures he had been receiving for the past 15 years from the DeLuxe Roman Retirement Villas, Inc.Much plot ensues, and the movie doesn't even begin to have the merest whisper of the faintest hint of actual suckage until Gwinevere shows up and begins to act really poorly. The lack of on screen suckage up to this point is not really the sole accomplishment of the director and screenwriter--no, there are plenty of clunker lines but the British male actor cast is so adept at making lemonade from some of the lemons they are dealt that one doesn't mind a bit. If the Hero who Overcomes Long Odds to Succeed in the End is one of the oldest devices in fiction, then Lancelot has the second-oldest character device--the one of "Best Friend who objects to absolutely every single thing the hero proposes as being the height of idiocy or self-indulgence, but then goes along with all the hero's schemes, anyhow". Good things--Ioan Gruffudd is smokin' hot, and so are a few of the rest. But he has the inestimable advantage of TWO swords and the best armor, not mention that basket-weave leather jerkin that he wears early in the flick. I really enjoyed hearing Lancelot's and Arthur's leather creak when they moved about. This was a great touch. Also, the strategy behind the various battle scenes was interesting to watch unfold. The camera didn't linger overlong on Gwen and Arthur's big sex scene, and it became apparent why not later on, as they would only have had time for a quickie, since they would have had to spend the rest of the k-niggit mapping out a very elaborate battle plan to confront the masses of invading Uruk-hai, I mean SAXONS, who were camped outside Helm's Deep, I mean HADRIAN'S WALL, waiting for daylight. And then there was the cinematography, which had that silvered effect at times that was kind of intrusive in Gladiator, but it worked well here, in a story partially set in the Pleistocene Epoch.Bad things--I found the soundtrack really disappointing-I wanted it to be more Celtic in flavor. But mostly, Keira-sorry, credulous fanboys--she's terribly miscast here and the miraculous costume changes and obvious makeup were snark-inducing. The only 'machine' this Woad looked like she had been tortured with was a curling iron. The thought of her as "spunky, girl-power" Lizzie Bennet makes the blood run cold. She was fine for a rompy flick like Pirates of the Carribbean, but I thought she was NOT plausible as a warrior who ran half-naked into battle when the men were all wearing armor. They should have had her stick to shooting arrows with deadly accuracy from a distance. That was plausible. I also found Merlin a depressingly small presence, and wondered that they even bothered to include him at all.Anyhow, the Saxons do indeed battle Arthur and his Knights on two occasions, making heavy use of their primary battle tactic of getting upwind from their enemy and raising their arms and charging, letting their powerful B.O. render their enemies senseless and unconscious. Some of the Knights eventually fell prey to this diabolical tactic, but Arthur, his sense of smell numbed by the lingering stench of the last exchange of dialogue with Gwinevere which still clung to his crispy curls and creaking leather armor, was able to hang in there and claim his destiny as the eventual King of the Britons, overcoming long odds to succeed in the end.Gwenivere is clearly upset by Lancelot's death (we know this because her mouth hangs open like a fish, and she knits her brow--no, wait, she'd been doing that a lot before--anyhow, we know she is upset because, well--who wouldn't be?), as she had clearly been hoping to work her way through the whole cadre of Arthur's Knights, for comparison purposes. But, in the time-honored fashion of aspiring political wives, she elects to "settle" for electability over bad-boy sex appeal. Which only goes to show you the truth of the old saying--"Behind every Legendary Hero is a dodgy bit of Woad tail booting him back out into the fray whenever he starts talking about retirement."</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A generic epic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**Spoilers ahead**Let me start by saying that I am not very familiar with Arthurian legend. I know that there was a King named Arthur, a sword named Excalibur, a Queen named Guinevere, a round table where the knights sit, and the wizard Merlin. However I don't know too much beyond that. Still, I think that King Arthur could have benefited more from the "magic" of the legends because it doesn't do much to set itself apart from other movie epics.Clive Owen does an adequate job of portraying a dark, brooding Arthur, a former Roman soldier. First off Guinevere, played by Keira Knightley, is a fairly one-dimensional character. We learn next to nothing about her other than that she is good with a bow. In this movie Knightley is nothing more than eye candy (albeit very nice eye candy). The character of Merlin is also just another military leader, and not a wizard. And just like Guinevere, we get to know nothing much about Merlin himself.Also, despite the fact that this movie strives for "authenticity", the heroes are given seemingly superhuman abilities. For example, in a battle across a frozen lake when Arthur and his knights confront a Saxon army, the Saxons try and shoot arrows against the knights but are out of range. But of course the knights are never out of range, and kill dozens of Saxons. One knight is also able to crack the entire frozen lake with his axe, with the crack encompassing a large part of the lake, with most of the Saxons standing on it. Is that authentic? Give me a break.The Saxon leader Cerdic is unimpressive as a villain. He does not inspire any real sense of fear or dread. In one scene, he says to kill everyone him and his armies encounter. One would think that he could take prisoners and use them as slave labour, but nope, the movie has make him want to kill everybody, which is frankly a cheap ploy in the movie's plot to make the audience hate him.Lastly, King Arthur borrows much from previous epics. So much so that it's as if they were working of some sort of "How to Make an Epic Movie Cookbook". Let's see, take one part brooding hero, add in a cheap love story, big battle scenes, evil-for-no-purpose villain, and a final scene where the hero MUST kill the villain on the battlefield, and you got yourself movie.Overall, King Arthur is not a bad movie, just an average one. Had I've not seen movies like The Lord of the Rings, Braveheart, Gladiator, The Last Samurai, Ran, etc., I might have been more impressed. But for a movie that strives for historical accuracy as a selling point (which is in itself stupid considering we have no hard evidence Arthur even existed), this movie falls flat.I give King Arthur 6 out of 10.</fullReview>

		<username>rparham</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>A film not fit for a King</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The tale of King Arthur and his knights of the round table are one of the most enduring legends in all of history. The basic mythology, in some form or another, is familiar to most individuals, either from reading Le Morte de Arthur or, more likely, The Sword in the Stone, during grade school. As with most other enduring legends, the exploits of King Arthur have been fodder for multiple screen adaptations over time, including an animated entry of The Sword in the Stone to several live-action versions, including, most recently, First Knight. Now, producer Jerry Bruckheimer and director Antoine Fuqua have given us King Arthur, a version that strips off most of the mythology and presents the Arthur story as a supposedly historically based telling. The veracity of this claim is questionable, but I can definitely make one determination about this film: it is the worst adaptation of the Arthur legend I have seen.Set in the 5th century, King Arthur opens on the cusp of Arthur and his knights about to be freed from service to the Roman empire. Arthur here is a half British, half Roman commander who leads a band of individuals descended from a group of great Sarmatian knights who fought against the invading Romans in their homeland several generations before and who found themselves and their offspring placed in servitude to the Romans. A Roman bishop has been dispatched to Britain to release the knights, but not before they complete one final mission: rescue a Roman family who have settled North of a great wall that separates North and South Britain before an invading horde of Saxons can reach them. The North is a rather inhospitable place, ruled largely by a people known as the Woads, led by Merlin (Stephen Dillane). Unhappy about the circumstances of their plight but willing to follow Arthur, they set out on this mission with the promise of freedom at the end.King Arthur is a dull and dreary piece of cinema. The film first falls down in the department of character development. These knights have well-known names: Lancelot (Ioan Gruffud), Bors (Ray Winstone), Gawain (Joel Edgerton), among others, yet other than Lancelot and Bors, none of the characters stand out. The rest are all just interchangeable bodies with no personality to speak of. Bors is really the only knight who is reasonably entertaining to watch, an oafish character who serves as comic relief. Clive Owen is serviceable as Arthur, but he hardly gives an especially strong performance. Keira Knightly fills the role of Guenievere, imagined here as a warrior woman of the woods, and while she is also okay in the role, the character at times descends into camp as she screams, kicks and yells while fighting other characters. Merlin is here for name recognition only, he serves little or no purpose in the film. On the villain front, Stellan Skarsgard turns in one of his worst performances to date as the leader of the Saxons, issuing his dialogue in a low, deep whisper and proving to be not the least bit intimidating.Aside for poor character development, King Arthur moves at a glacial pace. The film is too long and too uninteresting to hold the audience interest for as long as it lasts, and it quickly wore out it's welcome with me. Visually, it is also rather unspectacular. The film has the same dark, overcast look of many other historical epics set in the British isles, and even though it may be realistic, it would be nice to see a change of pace now and then. It also has very little in the way of impressive vistas, seeming to have been shot in one set of woods and one field from multiple angles to create the impression that it is different locales. King Arthur has the outward appearance of a film made on the cheap, although studio documentation would suggest otherwise.As with any sword and sandal epic, King Arthur is filled with battle scenes, but the film fails to prove very diverting in this department either. A major battle late in the film seems to drag on forever, and since we couldn't care less about the characters, we must simply look at the swordplay on display, which is frankly not that spectacular, especially when compared to the somewhat more engaging fighting featured earlier this summer in Troy. The only slightly impressive sequence in the film features a fight over a frozen lake that is at least visually interesting.For those with any interest in the Arthur legend, they would do best to pass on this dud and seek out a copy of Le Morte de Arthur or one of the better cinematic renditions of the tale. King Arthur is not worth the time, money or effort.</fullReview>

This tale sets forth a plausible historical figure from the 5th century, a Roman named Autorius (sp?), that could have been the figure from which all the mythical tales of magical deeds sprung forth. There is no magic in this film, just peoples who strive to conquer and peoples who strive not to be conquered as we witness the demise of the Roman Empire in Britain and the invasion of same by the Saxons. Merlin's only magic is seeking Arthur as the leader of his people. The costuming is wonderfully "real" in that it shows a reasonable depiction of that which was Roman evolving into that which could be the ancestor of the medieval knights' clothing. The only chink in this armor was the portrayal of Gwenavere as a warrior princess... with a condescending wink to the feminists who like to think that a 110 lb female with no upper body strength could really duke it out, hand to hand, with battle axes against a 6 ft Saxon and live to tell about it ... well, Gweny is a cute little savage inappropriately costumed in a peek-a-boo leather number, but a real spoiler on the realism scale.
