		<date>2005-08-12</date>
		<username>lizabuffy</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Even thought it had some issues, overall it was a pleasant way to spend two hours and should appeal to fans of Arthurian legend and history alike.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a big fan of Arthurian legend, I was a bit skeptical upon hearing of a new King Arthur story based not on the myth, but on a supposed historical figure that inspired the legend. Add to that poorly produced trailers and fairly consistently bad reviews and I just never managed to make it into theaters to see this. However, with the release of the King Arthur DVD I decided to give it a try.The movie proved to be an interesting deviation from the 'standard' depiction of Arthur and his knights. The film is marked as the story of the man the King Arthur myth is supposedly based on; Lucius Artorius Castorus (Clive Owen) a Roman commander. Arthur's knights are actually Sarmatian who must serve Rome for fifteen years before they can return to their homes. Lancelot (Ioan Gruffudd) is ruggedly handsome, as usual, but is not fated to fall in love with Guinevere (Keira Knightley), who is refreshingly not shown as a weak woman in need of rescuing, but rather as a warrior and a force to be reckoned with.There is no Camelot, only Britania, which is about to be invaded by the Saxons. Rome is crumbling (and historically, as there is a Pope, Rome has already fallen and is in the process of rising based on religious power instead of military) and Arthur and his men must save the Pope's godson from the invading Saxons before they can have their own freedom granted. Arthur is an idealist man who believes in freedom and equality for all. The film does an excellent job of portraying the characters as real while still showing the aspects of their lives the myth was based on. Amusingly, Merlin is not a mage (in fact, there is no magical properties in the movie at all) but rather is the leader of the Woad resistance to the Romans.That is not to say there were not a few issues with the film (as with most epics, everyone seems to speak flawless English). Arthur stresses the freedom of all men "You ? all of you ? were free from your first breath!" but happily glosses over the fact that the entire point of the film is to rescue a Roman son so his own knights can be granted their freedom (having been pressed into servitude generations past by Marcus Aurelius). Some of the dialogue and the script had their issues, but not to the point of being laughable or unbearable.A complaint levied against King Arthur while in theaters was the lack of blood (to the point of being distractingly noticeable), but as I watched the 2004 unrated directors cut I did not find this to be a problem. I cannot imagine not having the blood or length of the DVD version (giving some insight into why it faired so poorly at the box office). It added greatly to the dark feel of the movie, but was still tastefully done in such a way that it enhanced the plot rather than distracted from it. I would recommend only purchasing this version, and in fact question why they bothered to produce the theatrical release at all. These issues are off set by a truly gifted group of actors. Everyone excelled in their roles. Characters such as Sir Bors (Ray Winstone) added a lot of color and humor to the film, which provide a nice balance to the war torn backdrop of the film.Even with its issues, King Arthur was a pleasant way to spend two hours and should appeal to fans of Arthurian legend and history alike.</fullReview>
	</review>

Whether you like the film or not the soundtrack is worth getting if your a Zimmer fan, it would definitely go in his top 10. The films soundtrack is very historical and in places bares resemblance to that of "Gladiator".That all in all creates a fairly good film worth probably about 7 out of 10 not brilliant but not too bad either. Now for the lead balloon that sunk it. SCRIPT. It can be hard to notice when a film has a good script, especially through all the special effects, action scenes and loud music of a modern day epic, however as "King Arthur" shows it definitely becomes clear when you have a bad one. The script to this film was just plain corny. It was so bad in places that it made the film unbelievable. It tries in vain to take on Shakespeare's approach old English but to put it in Modern English for an audience who doesn't want to listen to hard. The scripts downfall may have been partially down Clive Owens rather wooden acting as his scenes were often the worst, but some pretty bad lines also emerged when he wasn't even on screen. Young Lancelot's last line in the first scene is a classic example.This unfortunately is what crippled "King Arthur" as for as I am concerned. The film has its moments, Stellan Skarsg?rd's chilling portrayal of the Saxon leader for example, and many audiences will see in it the potential for a good film, if only the dialogue was better.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2005-05-10</date>
		<username>cooperaitaliano</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A unique and clever contribution to this genre</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I liked this film a lot. I originally saw it at the cinema, but only really appreciated it when I saw it on DVD. Which is strange, it is usually the other way round with films as far as I am concerned. To start with, it is a novel approach to the King Arthur genre. Setting the film, probably around 900 to 1000 years earlier, for a start, during the era when Rome was supposed to be in decline and shrinking back from its empires. I believe that there are a number of historic inaccuracies, including the fact that I believe Baden Hill, where the battle is set is much further south and Hadrian's wall is in the North. The large scale 'invasion' of Saxons didn't happen in the manner reflected, it was a more gradual process. Also, like with 'Braveheart', the concept of 'freedom' is much more recent one. People of this eras in history prior to the feudal system were used to living in subjection to a ruling power. However to be fair, the concept of freedom came from Greek philosophy which predates the era in this film.The decision to reflect the knights as what one critic put 'Russian mercenaries', was a novel choice and gave the film a further uniqueness in this genre. Arthur as Roman officer (half Roman/half Briton) is also interesting.That said, the weapons, armour and battle tactics are authentic for Woads, Romans and Saxons. This aspect of the film is to be credited. The location is also good. Using Ireland as a location was a clever idea and reflects a mainland England that was once more rural than now. The training that the actors and extras were put through is admirable. The extra special features on the DVD gives you an appreciation of what lengths were reached to make the resultant film. The choice of cast is also a good one. None of them are what most people think of as major stars in the Hollywood sense. A wise idea, not just from a budget aspect, but also because it would have been a distraction. The use of colours, weather and landscape set the mood for certain scenes. The action scenes were particularly good and very realistic. There was no sense of making sanitising the film in that sense. It reflects a stark reality, also in the way the actors behave, their clothes and general appearance.One aspect was the reflection of the Christian faith. And as a Christian myself, I found this interesting. Those who are supposedly Christian are shown is an unsympathetic characters, some are shown as persecutors. This is an interesting thing as throughout history, the Christian church has become institutionalised and run by power hungry people who twisted the truth for their own ends and instituted Biblical heresies. In this respect, Arthur as a Christian is the only one shown in a favourable light. It is interesting that the Director and Producer should choose to make this distinction. In fact, Arthur is shown as a Christian with a practical faith prepared to fight injustice and make sacrifices. For this, the film makers deserve to been given credit.The musical score is very appropriate and compliments the film very well. I noticed the music more than in other films, because it stood out and was distinctive.The actual plot is a clever one, weaving the storyline between Arthur and His Knights, the Romans, Woads and the invading Saxons. This keeps the suspense and film builds a pace up to a finale that is a little predictable.The Saxons are brooding menace as the main enemies, Stellan Skarsg?rd and Til Schweiger play their parts up very well and looked very authentic. Ioan Gruffudd looks arrogant, ruthless and cynical. He makes a novel Lancelot. Whilst Clive Owen, an unusual choice for Arthur fills the part well. He sometimes appears a little wooden, but overall, plays the part better than some of the Hollywood set would. Physically, he looks the part well. He plays up the virtuous and noble in contrast to villains of the piece. Keira Knightley is also a good choice. She brings an interesting twist to the portrayal Guinevere. One that I wouldn't have expected. She compliments the film well. Her Guinevere works well with Ioan Gruffudd's Lancelot, though I think that given time, this subplot could have been developed further.Each of the knights are portrayed as having a different fighting style and this adds an additional note to the film. Ray Winstone plays up very much the cockney as almost a 'bar room brawler'. Ray Stevenson's Dagonet, was apart from Arthur, the most sympathetic character in the film. More could have been made of his character.Overall, it is a novel entry to the Arthur legend genre and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I think that it almost makes an epic piece. Certainly it is better than some of its contemporaries. Worth watching. Just keep an open mind.</fullReview>
	</review>

However, this movie was not about history, but about telling a tale (geddit history buffs!?) and depicts a not-too-often-covered 'Beowulf'-like period in movies -the beginning of the dark ages at the end of the Roman empire. The movie is reminiscent of the '13th Warrior' that had a similar dark, forbidding and desolate atmosphere. I enjoyed the somber, gritty and downright wintry setting backing off from some colorful situations and intense, spectacularly choreographed battle scenes. Arthur was portrayed as the Hellenistic hero- he certainly had the worst lines (!), {but then again so did Keaton's Batman against Nicholson's Joker}. Owen was simply the pivot around which the other characters worked. And they did work well! Not least the menacing Saxon king and his sniveling son (well played Till!) which was quite humorous at times. For the 'goodguys', Knightly and Winstone did well in their respective roles as love interest and 'bastard-siring' carouser.A good rental overall giving a good impression of what life might have been like at that time. The movie does not take itself too seriously (unlike say Troy which was over-glorified, stodgy and had blah dialog). This is a movie I'd watch again, not least to see Kiera Knightly with blue skin!I also look forward to seeing Stellan Skarsg?rd (nasty Saxon king) in the forthcoming Bewulf epic!</fullReview>

		<username>bobby-swayback</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Not great, but a refreshing change of pace</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm in love with history. So when I started seeing trailers for this version of the Arthur legend, purporting to be the "true story" of the roots of the Arthur myth, I got a wee bit excited. However, I avoided the theatrical version because I heard too many bad things about it.Then, I watched the director's cut on Pay Per View.Well, "true story" it's not. Most of its historical "facts" are dead wrong. About the only thing it gets right is that one of the inspirations for the Arthur legend may have been a Romanized British chieftan in the 5th Century. This movie takes that idea and runs with it... and does so pretty effectively.No, it is not any sort of "true" story. But it is a refreshing change of pace from the over-done and worn-out trope of chivalric knights jousting for fair ladies and taking up noble spiritual quests for their own sake. This film is a de-mystification and a humanization of what had become a tired legend. No magic, no ladies in lakes, no scheming witches; only early medieval humans struggling against ruthless invaders even as the one force that can protect them is packing up to go.The dialogue leaves a lot to be desired and it's about as historically accurate as Pirates of the Caribbean, but nonetheless, I found that at a visceral level, I liked "King Arthur" better than any other Arthurian movie I've seen. And that surprised me.Even though none of it is "true," this movie had more of the feel of history than any previous treatment of the tale. If nothing else, it gave audiences the right idea of where and when to look for Arthur's origins.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>seaneen</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Grows on you</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I first saw the theatrical release, and due to my OCD about historical accuracy and details I made myself crazy finding logic-gaps and felt let down.The second time was the Director's Cut, which added back in some crucial back-story for Arthur, and incorporates some more of the proto-legend in the alternate ending, which I feel would have been better incorporated just prior to the final wedding/arrows scene vs as an alternate...Once I could let go of the fact that Pelagius, Germanicus, and the Saxon invasions did NOT all take place concurrent with the Roman withdrawal from Britain, I realized that the movie really works quite well.Perhaps for those not book- and history/legend-obsessed more verbalizing of the Arthur legend into the story line in voice-over would have helped tie it into something they felt invested in, but I really think most people have very nearly incorporated the key aspects of the story into their common consciousness.I am stunned by the other writer's view that the acting was wooden, Director's cut fight scenes boring, and viewing it as hokey...Not really sure what that viewer was expecting, but it was wonderfully acted by quality cast with none of the interfering 'star power' issues with getting into a movie's characters. Much of the acting seamlessly displayed the different characters' personalities and motivations.The fight scenes in the DC are very graphic, in many ways more so than other 'epics' as the brutality of the injuries and the methodologies of war and survival depicted are authentic for the period and ethnic groups involved.Yes, I agree there are a few 'light' moments in comments or verbal word play that is 'modern' in tone rather than the type of jest common then, but had they spoken in the archaic verbiage of the time-frame, even if it was semi-translated to 'English', it would likely have turned off most viewers.And, had this been dark from beginning to end it would have felt too long and painful to watch.Me? I would have loved an extra hour or two of character development (especially the fellow 'knights'), more on the Picts and their social and political structure, a better idea why the Pope was obsessed with retrieving Electo, etc... But most viewers would be climbing the wall with that long a film!In short, if you are familiar with the Arthur legend, this is a fresh and surprising take with more than a little of the 'possible' vs fable, making you think anew about history and what we believe about ours.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-01-29</date>
		<username>(ccwmatthews@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Dismantling a Legend</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When King Arthur was first released, I steered clear of it thinking it would be nothing more than trumped up retelling of a story that had been told so many times before and simply didn't needed to be told again. After all, how could anything compare to the splendor of Excalibur in bringing to life the Authurian legends. And seeing Keira Knightly holding a bow and arrow in the trailers and the attachment of Jerry Bruckheimer's name as producer told me that this was going to be nothing more than a silly attempt to make King Aruthur hip and modern. But hearing the reviews I began to realize that my pre-conceptions about this film were all wrong. This film was said to be a more historical accurate telling of story behind the legends. I then thought perhaps this might be a fresh approach and possible a worthwhile venture after all. Yet I remained rather skeptical and waited for the video release.Well, after finally viewing the video, I have to say my initial inclinations to stay away from this film were correct. While this film may be more historically accurate than other tellings of King Aruthur , it does less to reveal the reality of legends as it does it does to dismantle them. Arthur and the Knights of the round table, who's number have been dwindled after years of battle, are reduced to just seven men. They are sullen, morose,and devoid of any charm or charisma. It is even hard to distinguish who is who except the fact they constantly utter each other's names as though the script writers themselves came to realize that how utterly non-descript these men were that they had to give the audience some help. Even Lancelot,in legend Arthur's right hand man and supposedly the greatest of all the knights, is merely just one of the rabble in this bleak band of knights. Keira Knightly as Gwenevire, is reduced to nothing more than eye candy. Her inclusion in the final battle scene dressed in ridiculously skimpy garb was a pathetic attempt at some political correctness that only succeeds in undermining the film's only supposed strength, its realism. But the greatest disappointment of all is the "Head Hauncho" himself. Clive Owen's portrayal of King Arthur is so wooden and uncharismatic, it makes you wonder why anyone would even follow this man to a party let alone write legends about him.Certainly the actors can't take all the blame, as the script and directing is really the true problem here. I am no historical scholar, but even I can tell that while this film boasts about historical accuracy, much of the film is still trumped up Hollywood history in the attempt to be entertaining as well as enlightening. Yet it doesn't work on either level. The pace of the movie is so slow, I found myself having to fast forward through much of it. The battle scenes, which could have been the film's saving grace, are few and far between and lack any kind of excitement. And with the film's PG-13 rating, there isn't even the satisfaction of seeing graphic, bloody clashes. There is one slightly memorable battle sequence that takes place over a frozen lake, but it's hardly enough to redeem the entire film. The dialouge is nothing more than a sereies of speeches and diatribes about "freedom" which can almost be accused of plagorsim from "Braveheart" only with less emotional resonance. Even the speech that Arthur gives to his knights before charging into the final battle fails to hit any kind of inspirational note. It was a wonder the knights didn't simply turn around and go home instead of charging into battle and risking their lives.The fact is, King Arthur, despite all the promise of fresh retelling of the legend , proved only to be a tremendous waste of time. For me, its supposed historical approach only worked to kill the legends of King Arthur. I think when I take this back to video store I'll check out "Excallibur" again to get the bad taste out of my mouth.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Awesome knight movie. Negative reviews are wrong!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched the director's cut of KING ARTHUR, so I can't compare it to the PG-13 version. I purposely held off seeing it until the director's cut came out because I didn't want to see a choppy movie with missing scenes.I am so glad I held off. I can't believe how much hate is directed towards this film. THe dialog is not "painful" or "sickening." It's actually very good. Not profound, but the characters get their points across, and what they say is meaningful.One of the things I liked about the movie is how much social relevance it holds today. Arthur and the knights serve religious fanatics who want to rule everything, and they think God is on their side. Sounds very familiar to certain people. It's great to see the Knights of the Round table show how much they are against greed and conformism.Clive Owen is such a cool King Arthur. Normally, this would be a generic role, but he seems to make Hollywood roles more appealing with his rough voice and rugged stare. I wish that more focus was shown for him. (He's the title of the movie!) THe movie opens up with Lancelot joining the Knights, and when it came to the action scenes, other characters seemed to get more focus than Clive. It must have been easy to get confused on who to focus more on: Lance or Art? They are both cool people.Stellen Skarsgard was also great. He also had a generic part, but did cool things with it. 		<date>2004-12-31</date>
		<username>Eric Endres</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Not "Excalibur", but an excellent film about the reality, not mythology.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>John Boorman's wonderful "Excalibur" has always been one of my very favorite films of any genre, so any other film I've seen about the same subject is always compared with that, and usually they quickly pale in comparison. Of course, the difference with this film is that unlike "Excalibur" and most other Arthur films, which play up the legend and mythology, this new film purports to portray the real events as they supposedly historically occurred, according to recent archaeological discoveries. I'm sure that some things were embellished, regardless, but I think that is one of the things I enjoyed about this; to get a sense for some of the realism behind the legend and for some of the politics and history of the time. And the execution is very well done... not over-the-top at all, but smart and creative, with very credible performances. That I didn't know any of the actors by name or face probably helped, as the prospect of Richard Gere or Ben Affleck or Colin Ferrell whoever in the roles would have been very distracting to take this seriously. The brotherhood and camaraderie of the knights is well written and portrayed, as are the Romans, Saxons and others.Though it would be hard for any film of this type to compare in cinematography to "Excalibur", which I think is just absolutely outstanding in that respect, "King Arthur" has some nice shots as well and does a very good job of capturing its setting.The action scenes are particularly well done, especially compared to so many other "battle epic" films, where it's a whole lot of chaos and the main characters always survive through fight after fight. There is a sense of being able to follow what's going on, while also being in the midst of it all. Some of the tactical strategies employed are reminiscent of the type of clever tactical maneuvers in another great film, "Master and Commander".I'm disappointed to see this film only rated at 5.9 here, with so many other films less deserving getting much higher marks than that. I give it a solid 9 out of 10. Expectations play such a big part in how I perceive movies, and I suppose I didn't expect this to be so well done, or maybe I expected it to be more "Hollywood" or something. But thankfully there was a lot of craft in the writing, the film-making and acting, and I think this makes an excellent "companion piece" to "Excalibur", in terms of comparing mythology against reality.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Fair Attempt</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's begin by reminding ourselves that the story was eked out of archaeological findings and histories written by conquerors (which are always very one-sided), of a group of legendary heroes that were, literally, prehistoric. That means that all of the details are, necessarily, dramatised; so I can't really attack the accuracy of the plot. It was, however, a little cliché-heavy, even for a Heroic epic.Now, I suppose I'm trying to read more meaning into this tale than there truly is, but consider this: Franzoni's Arthur had no identity of his own. He was Briton born, loyal to Rome, and spent most of his life in lands not his own, fighting for the causes of others. When the Woads approach him to lead their rebellion, he refuses at first, but eventually takes up their cause, instead. And then, preparing to ride into the film's final battle, he screams "Rus!" the battle cry of his Asian brother knights. Does he truly have no idea where his loyalties should lie? Add to this the fact that his fellow knights, who wanted only to return to their homelands, turned back and ran to Arthur's side against the Saxon army... Have you noticed that those who seem the most lost somehow engender the fiercest loyalty from their fellows? In the end, I felt more sad for them than triumphant. This Arthur looked to me like a confused and mercurial man that ended up being more of a danger to those that loved him than a help.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Enjoyable, emotional and good-feeling movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Personally I liked King Arthur as a new and a bit unusual interpretation of famous legend. For me it's the best Arthurian movie although this film doesn't follow precisely typical classic fairy story about Knights of the Round Table, wizard Merlin, evil Morgana, lovers Lancelot and Guinevere. Now it looks more like a solid medieval epic tale and a completely new view on this legend. There are Romans in Britain and Arthur is the half British half Roman general of a legendary cavalry knights. He is a strong leader, who always takes care of his men and never remains indifferent to injustice, cruelty and religious fanaticism, which occurred alarmingly often during that time. His believes in freedom and equality of all people and there is nothing surprising that such his idealistic thoughts are not very welcome in that troubled time. Clive Owen played Arthur with lots of realism and created a memorable and rather emotional character. After fifteen years in Roman army Arthur and his knights must get freedom but before that they get their last job. They must try to save a noble Roman family in the heart of the country from rampaging barbarian Saxon hordes. Now Roman forces are leaving Britain and Arthur and his knights have to decide are their war is ended or not. King Arthur represents all typical moral elements for historical epic ? fight for freedom, faith, loyalty, courage, generosity and they perfectly work here. The whole movie is deeply emotional and poignant but never looks manipulative. Sometimes it's rather violent and disturbing but it never oversteps the limits of rationality and necessity. Despite lack of famous names most of the cast have solid performances. Ioan Gruffuld is very good as fearless but flawed Lancelot, Stellan Sarsgaard as Saxon leader and a ruthless conqueror. Keira Knightley is also doing reasonably well as Guinevere, female leading character. The battle scenes are mostly impressive and the only problem is that in last several years there are too many epic movies with well made long battle scenes so now it's very hard to amaze the audience with them. However their realism and tension in King Arthur is another positive point of this movie. Saying so many positive things about King Arthur I also should notice some of its flaws, fortunately not numerous. Of course it has some historical inaccuracies (for example Saxon conquered Britain) and it's not free of stereotypes (though there much less of them here then in most modern Hollywood pictures). But positive easily outweighs here all possible minor drawbacks. King Arthur is a really enjoyable and good feeling movie and in my opinion it is easily one of the best summer movies of the year.My grade 8.5 out of 10. Thanks for reading and sorry for my bad English.I really enjoyed it. Thanks and sorry for my bad English.</fullReview>

Every character is created so carefully and naturally, that you simply cannot answer the question of who was my favorite character and who wasn't. Impossible to name, impossible to imagine the movie without any of the characters or see The Knights of The Round Table somehow differently now. "King Arthur" completely changed my view. (applause)</fullReview>

		<date>2004-09-06</date>
		<username>aimless-46</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Weak, but Consistently Weak</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The process of making a film consists of three distinct stages: pre-production, production, and post-production. Usually when a film just doesn't work it is because the wheels fell off during one of these stages and excellence in the other two stages could not salvage the project. Although a pre-production failing like a poor script cannot be compensated for in production or post-production, valiant salvage efforts can make a production technically interesting. Most high-budget films follow this example as a technically talented cast and crew work to turn a flawed concept into something decent. The result is an uneven product that leaves the viewer sorry that so much talent was wasted on something so ordinary. King Arthur is the rare exception where the all stages are consistently weak, in this project the three production stages truly deserve each other. The uninspiring script gives cast and crew little to work with. While there is nothing wrong with giving the Arthur saga an 'imaginative' twist, the traditional story is fun and interesting and creative freedom with non-history should at least inspire a story that is equally worth telling. This version is neither worth telling nor told in an interesting way. Not surprising coming from the feeble pen of David Franzoni (who can also be blamed for 'Gladiator'). Buried in the mess are painful allusions to how every man is born equal and other messages about positive human values ('The Magnificent Seven' written by Norman Vincent Peale) but there are too many characters and not enough time to explore anyone or anything more than superficially. The acting is absurdly lame, something out of the former NFL star school of film performance. None of them appear to be on the same page. Keira Knightley is unintentionally hilarious; she has probably set her career back 10 years with this role. Perhaps she watched Natalie Portman's bored performance in 'Attack of the Clones' and decided to ham up this role or perhaps she was sick during most of the performance; she looks like she just finished a hard month of intensive chemotherapy. Sets somehow manage the unlikely combination of being confusing AND uninteresting. Director Antoine Fuqua was apparently napping during most of the shooting, as the overall production seems out of control. During his waking moments Antoine staged endless 'walking and talking' scenes; directors use these when they are either too lazy to stage an interesting scene or where the dialogue is so horrible that the distraction provided by a tour of the set is necessary. Both were true in King Arthur.The editing is simply incomprehensible. High budget battle scenes jump all over the place without any logical sign of progression. The huge continuity issues in these scenes do not become a factor because the audience is too busy trying to make basic sense of what is happening to even bother with logical analysis. Antoine's probable dementia becomes apparent when he stages a hopelessly poor imitation of Eisenstein's "Battle on the Ice" scene. If you're going to plagerize an idea at least do it as well as the original.The only character you end up liking or caring about is Stellan Skarsgard's 'Cedric' who is the villain of the piece. Interesting only as an example of consistent mediocrity.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A little long, a different take than usual.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The back story of the movie has to do with the conquering of a far eastern country of Sarmatia by Rome. The warriors that were left standing were allowed to live and were taken into the Roman army, so where their sons and grandsons etc. These Sarmatian knights were the cream of the crop but their servitude has left generations of them wanting to return home. Arthur, also known as Artorius, is a convert to Christianity in these last days of the Roman Empire. He is in command of what's left of the last of the Sarmatian knights, mainly pagans. They are based in a fortress at Hadrian's Wall where Arthur has his round table for war conferences. It is the even of their final day of obligation to the Roman army and they are all anxious to return to Sarmatia and their freedom.But the Bishop has arrived to announce that Rome is pulling out of Britain and they have one last mission to conduct before they are allowed their freedom. They must rescue a Roman family from north of the wall, territory that the heathens and pagans, called Woads, call their own which is in inherent danger of a mass invasion by the Saxons. Arthur feels obligated to his duty and eventually his knights decide to join him too. It seems a bit unbalanced sending an away team of 7 knights against impending thousands of Saxons and hundreds of Woads.They reach the home of the Roman nobleman and discover a walled in prison filled with mainly dead prisoners but manage to rescue a boy and a beautiful "Woad" woman, Guinevere. She's tough, brave and seems to have a fascination for Arthur and he for her. And yet there are stolen glances from Arthur's best friend Lancelot but other than one quick seduction scene the night before a battle, there is no blatant love story here. This movie is not the traditional Arthur tale you know but it tells the tale of how Arthur earned the right to be king of a united Britain, the indigenous armies and the displaced Romans. We know it won't be for long as history points to the Saxons as ruling the island for several centuries before the Conquest.Arthur is played by the lovely green eyed Clive Owen and Guinevere is portrayed by Keira Knightly who continues her feisty chick role. You will remember her from Pirates of the Caribbean, also a Jerry Bruckheimer production as is this. Ioan Gruffudd plays Lancelot and some of you will know him from the Hornblower series, also Poldark. Ray Winstone plays Bors, a character i quite enjoyed. The action and battle scenes are very well done, with a minimum of computer graphics though they are there but not that obtrusive. The fortress representing Hadrian's wall is real, not generated. Actors walk on the walls, the huge gates are solid and ominous. It all adds to the 5th century Britain feel of things. Lots of armour, swords, and archery, Guinevere kicks ass, Arthur and the knights fight bravely. The Saxons are rather understated but clearly the bad guys. The dialogue is a bit lame though. I mean "I'm Arthur. You're safe now" ???? sheesh. The costumes are wonderful, very authentic feeling and the scenery is spectacular. Filmed in Kildare and Wicklow, Ireland, I liked this movie for the fact that it was more historically accurate, assuming there may have been a warrior king named Artorius. There could have been, even if events are fictionalized. There's lots of action and swordplay that maybe goes on a little too long at times. I was a little unclear about whether the knights actually were taken from their homes in Sarmatia or if they were in Britian. I think it was implied that at least Lancelot was from the eastern country but the initial conquest of Sarmatia was 100 years previous to the start of the movie and it seemed like once in the army, most of the soldiers wouldn't likely make it back home to start families and have their sons and future generations then seconded into the army. It was mentioned that Arthur's Roman father married a Briton so it seems likely he was not from Sarmatia. Anyway, that was their ancestral home so i suppose it's irrelevant in the long run.I liked the movie, it was exciting and had some great adventure in it. There's lots of good info on the official site about the movie and the history.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Could have been awesome...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a student of Medieval history and literature I really enjoyed this film. Not because of the intriguing plot (there is none) of the in-depth exploration of the characters (none either), but because I kept laughing my ass of! It could have been so awesome. I mean, using the Celtic Arthurian legend for a change (I for one am more a fan of those than of the rather tame, overly romantic French stories of later date) sounded great to me. Trailer looked cool as well. Clive Owen is an actor I already really liked (after seeing him in Bent and Croupier), as is Stellan Skarsgard. So what went wrong....??EVERYTHING! They just couldn't get ANY even remotely historical or literary aspect of this period and legend right! * Saxons invading from the North (and a couple of centuries too early as well) * A Pope as the head of the Roman Church * A bunch of late-Medieval French knights with famous names disguised as "Sarmatians" from God-knows-where * A table with no clear purpose (which, I must admit, was round) * A crazy wizard-who-wasn't-a-wizard with no clear purpose (although, I must admit, he was called Merlin) * A bunch of blue "Woads" who were also "Britons" (I got really confused here, as the Britons were just one of the Celtic tribes, but here the word "Briton" seemed to be synonymous for "Celt" as in "indigenous inhabitant or Britain") * A never fully explored sword-in-burial mount-theme (I must admit, a boy pulled it out of something and it was called Excalibur) * A guy with a stupid Italian accent (signifying him as being a Roman) living in a Roman villa complete with Mediterranean poplar trees, NORTH of Hadrians Wall (???). Did he have some kind of death-wish? * A half-naked, starved Kiera warrior princess pretending to be a Celtic Boadicae, French Guinevere and Maximus the Gladiator all at the same time * A Lancelot who served no purpose but looking good and moaning to Arthur about going home (while stroking a mummified rat, of whatever it was) * A steamy lovescene that wasn't steamy but blue and boring * A Christian Arthur who marries Boadicae/Guinevere/Maximus in a polystyrene Stonehenge near the coast (??), while being blessed by some Welsh-sounding druid wannabe (at least he pronounced the name of Guinevere the right way, since this is supposed to be the Celtic Guinevere) * Mount Badon being near Hadrians Wall (??) * Mysterious doors that need to be opened the fist time by 2 horses, to open all by themselves after that (maybe they had some unseen cave-trolls on top of the wall...) * Clive Owen uttering the most incredibly cheesy dialogue I have ever heard. "Mark my face, Saxon, for it will be the last thing you see on this earth" -sigh-.... I was constantly thinking "this movie could have been remotely enjoyable, if Arthur would just look rugged and SHUT HIS MOUTH". I got the impression Mr. Owen was a bit ashamed of being in this film as well (at least he looked like it) * Stellan Skarsgard doing even worse, confusing muttering one-word-phrases like "burn" and "kill" in a low American accent with being fearsome. He looked half asleep the entire time! and so on and so on.....This could have been a great movie in the tradition of Gladiator (a movie which actually had a PLOT). The sets looked cool (better than those obvious CGI soldiers and ships in Troy). But what this film missed was a plot, a cool hero (sorry Mr. Owen), a cool soundtrack (please stop copy-pasting from your own previous work, Mr.Zimmer) and blood (this film has the most bloodless battles I have ever seen in a period film. Gladiator is a regular blood-fest compared to this one!).Enjoyable if you want to spend an evening laughing, but could have been much, much, much better (if, say, Ridley Scott had directed it and Clive Owen had just kept his mouth shut).</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Saw it twice. Liked it even better the second time around. It's a MOVIE. A STORY. And it's well-told, with the mystical mumbo-jumbo removed and the French soap opera elements tweaked so that just the names are recognizable. Despite that, and that's one of the things I really liked, it managed to retain the flair of 'legend'. It was an uabashed story about a hero, and there's nothing wrong with that.Another nice tweak: Arthur making the transition from trying to serve a 'higher purpose' to humanization, when he realizes that the 'higher purpose' is probably well and truly corrupted, and that if any purpose in life is to be found it lies in the service of one's people. A good and noble soldier's creed. The stuff indeed, of heroic legend, well told, and with a kick-ass cast.Full marks.Till Noever (Author, Keaen. 		<shortDescription>A refreshing take on the Arthurian story</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to see this film with an open mind, having read some of the less-than-flattering reviews. Growing up in the north-east of England, I was well aware of the Arthur-related stories and legends that exist in this area including the one about Arthur and his knights sleeping in a cave under The Roman Wall until Britains' hour of need. To me, it made historical sense to set the tale in the early Dark Ages and to represent the legend as based on ordinary men doing extraordinary deeds. After all, most of the legend was invented in the mediaeval period, hundreds of year after Arthur was supposed to exist. I thoroughly enjoyed the film, found it entertaining and beautifully shot, and was impressed by the fight scenes. After so much CGI with massive hordes majestically sweeping across plains, it was good to feel that you were right in the thick of it with them and they were really slugging it out.OK, so it's not historically totally accurate - but how can you be accurate about a legend for which there is precious little solid evidence? Go see it, enjoy it for what it is and don't get prissy about the "facts". Remember IT'S JUST A FILM!!!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>this is he one &amp; only Arthur - ever</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>King Arthur was one of those movies i loved instantly upon reading the online advertising before its American release - after which i completely forgot about it because it took almost a year to see that memory visualised in our theaters. Now what were my expectations ? A nice historical mix of Roman &amp; Celtic cultural elements with a budget big enough to provide the 'major-battle' custom to every historic epic since the collisions in Ben Hur. They were fully forfilled and even came with several extra spices, such as the bold humorous dialogues between the knights, mostly regarding Bogs offspring, some beautiful panorama's ( especially of Hadrian's wall ) &amp; an almost unrecognizable Guinevere in combat. On a deeper level, King Arthur offers some clear but amusing references to Gladiator: not only might the leading man just have been Russell Crowe in that armour, he also swings his sword the same way as during the 'Hannibal reenactment fight' &amp; as a first opponent during the major battle, takes out a Saxon carrying a long battle axe. But the one scene that really made my cinemaniac soul go emotional was the battle on the ice, with the cracking &amp; the grasping of the pieces &amp; such, ... it was pure Aleksandr Nevsky.Now for the critical part. The portrayal of the peoples seemed rather accurate, the difference between the short Roman swords &amp; the knight's Celtic types was a nice touch as well as the worldly affairs of the church and its members for the early period, ... but all the Roman footsoldiers carrying that 'Pax' or 'C-R-istos' sign on their shields to indicate the Empire has converted to Christianism is a doubtful element, especially because they are already shown when the time indicator is standing on 300 AD while Christianism wasn't recognized until 312 and declared official religion until 395. Plus, those men are referred to as auxiliaries, who mostly where foreigners with their own specific weapons and skills, not conscripts in a standard legionnaire suit. i hadn't checked on the origins of 5th century horsemen in Great Brittain or the actual timeline for the Saxon invasion, but i'm sure the crew came pretty close with their setting. Only that stupid "Rus !" yell i didn't get ... that was the name for 8th century Viking settlers in present Russia, what has that got to do with 5th century Brittain ?The one thing that just stinks is whatever is preserved from the Arthurian legend apart from the name Artorius - naming the whole gang after the knights was cheap, the Merlin character a hasty solution to the question of making what out of the medieval wizard &amp; i could have done without Lancelot looking at the bathing Guinevere, since nothing further happens.So for once my '8' voting is fully logical : take one point for the Arthurian elements &amp; one for the historical flaws. BUt as long as there isn't an entire flock of Arthurian movies set in this transition period this remains by my judgment the finest Arthur movie ever, outranking Merlin, Excalibur, and Robert Taylor matinees like Prince Valiant.</fullReview>

What we got is good directing, believable battles with living actors that can be counted on the screen, nice script with an interesting idea (Arthur is a roman army officer guarding Rome's outposts in Britain), very fine acting with some great characters (Bors, played by Ray Winstone - Will Scarlet from old Robin Hood English series, Clive Owen, Mads Mikkelsen as Lancelot and last but not least Keira Knightley - still a little bit wooden and cartoonish but damn she's got a lot of charisma as brave Guinevere). The plot itself is just a simple construction to show us some unforgettable battle scenes (the one on the frozen lake will remain in your mind for quite a long time - I can assure you) and moments of great valour, bravery and real friendship between seven knights who remind me "Magnificent Seven".You'll watch the movie on one breath, it's an entertaining and wise story about values that passed away with their bearers. It's strong 8 out of 10 for me.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I had low expectations going to see this, but my friend got free tickets, so why not?! Especially with the prospect of the gorgeous Clive Owen, if nothing else!But I loved it! From what I've read, as written by those who might be expected to know, this is based on the latest historical evidence.I found it very clever, and pretty convincing, the way elements of the myth were portrayed as believable events, which could have been built upon by centuries of balladeers and storytellers (a good example being Arthur extracting his father's sword from the earth).I also did not find it at all insulting to Britain, as one person here said - quite the opposite! Guinevere's petitions to Arthur to lead his people, and the observation that Excalibur was forged in the fires of Britain, were very stirring! I wanted those Romans and those Saxons OUT OF MY COUNTRY!! OK, so a lot of modern Brits are descended from those invaders, but hey - British can be defined a million ways, there's no pure blood in these islands. And frankly those knights are more than welcome here, because everyone knows that whinging about the weather is THE defining feature of Britishness!Anyway, I digress! I loved the relationship between the band of knights; yes, there was a touch of Henry V, or the Magnificent Seven, but that's hard to avoid in such a situation. I found the 'romance' between Arthur and Guinevere convincing - she's a kick-ass warrior, who made him see things differently than he had always believed; he's a legend in his own lifetime, but also a good man, with ideals. (and he's Clive Owen - who'd say no?)I was a bit annoyed that Lancelot came to her rescue in the big battle, but its a minor quibble. And I was slightly distracted by the variety of accents, but I got over it, because who knows what is accurate anyway? Although I was stunned for a moment when I thought the bad guy might actually be played by an American (is that allowed?) but then realised it was a (great) European actor who has picked up the accent while learning English. Ah well, maybe one day.The battle on the ice has been mentioned as a stand-out scene, which it most certainly is, but I can't really pick out a lot of others, because I just enjoyed the film as a whole.And, the unexpected death (not gonna spoil it!) was a welcome twist, because if there's one thing you think you know, it's who will survive. And it's great to have that confidence knocked occasionally in a movie.All in all, a really enjoyable film, that will stir your British blood!</fullReview>

		<date>2004-07-25</date>
		<username>Fenris Fil</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Another good idea badly implimented.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Following in the footsteps of Troy (and very much in the same style) This film is an interesting take on the Arthurian legend, however it is a long way from being historically accurate (even to what little information we have about that age - and shame on you so called "history buffs" for thinking otherwise), suffers from several modern Hollywood clichés, has wooden acting and mixed up accents.First thing I should say is that this is an *attempt* at a historical version of the Arthurian story. Those that prefer fantasy over history will definitely be disappointed and I would recommend for those digging out a copy of Excalibur (which while being very much fantasy over history it is a far better film on the whole). You don't need to even bother reading the rest of this review because you can trust me that you will be disappointed.I very much like the idea of attempting a historical perspective on the legend, however the key word where this film is involved is "attempt" and no one should be fooled into thinking this is anything more then a mixture of educated guess and Hollywood razzle dazzle.It's been a few years since Hollywood has made the English out to be the bad guys so this is somewhat of a return to form for them (and no surprise to find it's a Disney production). Yep that's right; the Saxons (along with the Angles and Jutes, and later on the Normans) form the majority of modern English blood. Yet for some reason they are near mindless (and completely ignorant to any kind of tactic or battle skill), Nazi like (determined not to mix their gene pool), killing machines (and for some reason the appear to be led by a John Wayne impersonator). The historical truth of the matter is that the Saxons where no more bloodthirsty then any other tribe/race at the time, including the Celtic Britons and the Romans. It is funny how perspectives on a people change depending on circumstances. In Hollywood terms the Saxons suddenly become good guys once they have converted to Christianity (and funnily enough are fighting off Heathens in the form of the invading Danes). But while they are Heathens they are evil.Having said that, at least the Britons that are still Heathens are given a kinder portrayal. But then Hollywood does like to show the dark side of Rome (which is one thing I do appreciate) and so the need to have misunderstood, oppressed good guys in the plot led to the acceptance of at least some Heathen tribes. The real truth of the matter though is very much un-Hollywood and for that matter un-Christian. There was no good and evil, simple different sides of a struggle for survival. The term "Woads" doesn't sit very well with me either. The "Britons" were Celts, and the term Woad, last I heard, was actually a Saxon term anyway (meaning Madness). The Celts migrated to England just as the Saxons did (and the Jutes, Angles, Danes and Normans). In actual fact the Saxons, Jutes and Angles were invited in as Mercenaries to defend the country after the Romans abandoned it, it was only later they saw the opportunity to make the place their home. Meanwhile the Celts where renowned for their savagery and their enjoyment of combat (they used to charge into battle naked and painted), they claimed the British isles from the people before them, whom they likely slaughtered or at least forced to move on. So you couldn't really call them in original inhabitants (as far as we know they originated somewhere in Asia). At least when the Saxons came they were able to retain Hibernia and Caledonia (Ireland and Scotland) and they were being moved on by three tribes not just the Saxons. Oh yeah and the Saxons were largely motivated by their own survival too, a point overlooked in this film. They were forced out of Germania by the Romans and they sought the decent farm land of this country so that they may feed their people and ultimately survive. They were also defending their religion, indeed had they been willing to convert to Christianity they would have been under the arm of Rome the same as the Britons were. The Saxons were fighting for their freedom, their religion and their right to live. That doesn't make a good Disney baddie though....The most conclusive research I've seen on Arthur would suggest that the legend is in fact based on two different people with the elements of legend roughly divided between the two. Unfortunately that wouldn't make for a good film, so a lot of elements are thrown into this supposed historical perspective as a way to justify various parts of the legends and a lot of that seems rushed and badly thought out. There were also a whole load of other historical inaccuracies. I never really understood the point of correcting some of the standard inaccuracies of a Hollywood historical epic (such as Guinevere) and ignoring a whole load of others (amongst others, why are there so many crossbows?). So having failed to achieve its original goals of a fair historical perspective we are left to examine the film as nothing more then a film. So what do we have?Well the film is incredibly predictable. While Guinevere may be more accurate, it is typical of modern day Hollywood to cast a woman in an ass kicking role. I'd like to give the makers the benefit of the doubt of making her kick ass out of historical perspective but sadly I think it is just because it's the trendy thing to do. The final battle was mostly predictable, especially the final combat between the big good and the big bad. The overall theme of freedom was a bit of the false side given what I mentioned above (and remember the Celts converted to Christianity fully long before the Anglo-Saxons, and when the Saxons came to Britain there was a resurgence of Heathenism even amongst the Celts who had those trends oppressed under the Romans).The end is incredibly cheesy, and when you consider the real historical perspective of it all (i.e. that the Saxons "won" in the end), it's a bit of a joke. The acting is at times reasonable, but mostly poor. While the old Hollywood concept of placing supposedly chivalrous 14th centaury knights in full jousting place in the middle of the dark ages may have been swept aside in this film they are still using totally inappropriate accents. The new rougher Gwen for some reason still has an ever so posh English accent, as do most of the characters in this film (the most noticeable exception being the Saxon chief whose accent sounds American for some unknown reason). The script is unbelievably Clichéd, and at one point Arthur he even seemed embarrassed to be uttering his own lines. The acting as I said at the start is poor but I would be willing to give benefit of the doubt to a lot of the cast due to the poor script and sub standard directing.Really there isn't a lot of redeeming qualities to this film. I would recommend watching it only as a point of interest and so you can make your own mind up, but I should warn you that for the vast majority of people this film will not entertain much and will always be considered inferior to Excalibur. I would advise against paying to see this in the cinema.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Whats your problem? - Read a book</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't understand what all the hoo har is about people criticisms on King Arthur. Heaps of people are saying that the story is inaccurate.....Well according to the Anglo-centric story spun in the 15th century, which like most Ancient Greek history, has maybe 1 milligram of true historical basis, then it was inaccurate. But according to archaeological studies and earlier literature written a little after the period that is associated with Arthur, the movie has some merit. True the movie has inaccuracies. But so does Troy (and Homer's version itself) and just about every other period piece that comes out of Hollywood. Unrealistic battle scenes? - who was complaining when they saw Lord of the Rings or any other action flick, like Bad Boys. So what's your problem people? It was a great story and from what I saw, it did make an attempt to paint a picture of what could really have happened. Some people complain about the Roman setting, well true the Romans officially pulled out of Britain in 410 AD, but the Church didn't. Thats not to say that "Romans" as such were not still around. The movie did not show masses of Roman legions, just a garrison to protect a Bishop - plausible but whether its true who knows - but plausible. The fact is THERE IS NO CONCRETE EVIDENCE OF THE FACTS......YET. Most sources place Arthur between approximately 420 and 540 AD, the time of the Saxon invasions. That adds merit to the story. Guinevere, if she was a Celt could plausibly have been a worrior - as was common for Celtic women (e.g. queen Boudica in the 1st century AD). Most believe that Arthur was a Romano-Celt. So whets wrong with that aspect of the movie? Hadrians wall was still there around the time of Arthur, there were many forts left behind by the Romans (bigger than any built but those who came later). So why couldn't Arthur base himself in one of those - the Britons were trying to cling to Roman civilization during that period. Some archeologists think that Arthur's "Camelot" may have been a Celtic Hill fort - heaven forbid that! Or better yet, did you know that some archeologists even propose that Arthur as we believe him to be never existed but instead it is the story of about a noble Roman in Britain who live in the second century AD fighting the Picts. Oh but it can't be you say!!!! Others think that the battles associated with Arthur were not necessarily led by him but by the organised group of resistance he was associated with. The only things that are close to certain is that the name Arthur is derived from Latin, the period was soon after the Roman withdrawal and the areas which successfully held out against the Saxons were Wales and Cornwall. So for those who dispute the history, I would say read some books on archeology and try to grasp what the period was like. Some of the complaints I have read border on idiotic. The movie paints a more plausible picture of what could have happened than any other I have seen, and I have seen them all and read the historical sources. Gladiator was completely bunk historically but I didn't see too many complaints. And those who want to see a fairy tail type movie, well wasn't Harry Potter and lord of the Rings enough for you? If you think you can do better, make one yourself. Instead of complaining about things that you seam to not know much about use the movie as inspiration to learn what is actually known. And if you can't deal with this then maybe you should follow some other pursuit.</fullReview>
	</review>

Not all swords and axes, there are quite a few lighthearted moments, and even the bad guys "Saxons" had their good moments. Highly Recommended</fullReview>

		<date>2004-07-11</date>
		<username>Matt</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Your Father's "Arthur"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Now that I can finally see (Long story, don't ask), I ventured out into the real world and caught a new flick. How lucky was I when I strode into the theater and found myself buying a ticket to see 'King Arthur'. Now I had extremely high expectations for this film as I love medieval pieces and especially ones involving anyone from the Arthur lore. But this isn't Arthur lore; least not the type movie goers are accustomed too.Written by David Franzoni (Gladiator) and directed by Antoine Fuqua (Training Day), this film abandons all premonitions of what Arthur was and what he is in all our memories. They do keep some of the same, more recognizable, legends of the king. The Round Table makes an appearance but is not nearly held with as high regard as in previous legends. Also, Excalibur still sits on the hip of Arthur. But there's a different twist here. Where in other legends, Arthur was the son of a poor man who pulled the sword Excalibur from its stone, therefore establishing Divine Right for King of England; here Excalibur is his father's sword. His father is killed in battle and the young Arthur pulls the sword from his father's dead body and carries the sword since. Fuqua decides to use the same imagery as if Arthur was pulling the sword out of a stone but just the idea that Excalibur was pulled from his father's body and he has carried it ever since, establishes a little more depth to the story. And that's where most of the similarities stop. This story is based on historical finds that have been discovered recently that have not been established in other Arthurian literature or film works. Arthur is a Roman that has to serve out his duty to the Roman Empire until he realizes he is fighting for a Rome that is too idealistic to exist. Lancelot is an amazingly gifted warrior who was recruited from a young age to join the conquering Roman army to serve for 15 years. He has more of a friendship with Arthur than a king/knight relationship. Guinevere is not a princess from the neighboring France but an English born slave who is discovered and rescued by Arthur's knights. And Merlin normally considered the lovable magician is more of a rebel ghost who leads a rag tag group of English fighting the Roman Empire. So no, this is not your typical 'Arthur' movie.But what truly surprised me were not the entirely new interpretations but how well every aspect of the film was done. The cinematography was unbelievable. Most of the shots look like they could have been taken start from artist renderings of Arthurian literature. Breathtaking establishing shots of the snowy English landscape transport you back into 400 AD where nature was virtually untouched and made you wish you could visit this country on holiday. The script for the film was done very well also. There weren't those blockbuster, crappy lines that one would expect from a Bruckheimer film. There wasn't even the one liner, 'Braveheart-like' war anthem when going into battle but a very stirring speech from Clive Owen (Arthur) that made you think 'They better kick some Saxon ass.' And it was funny. Not in the modern way either but they took humor and situations from that era and made it funny to today's audience, a true accomplishment.But there are two things that make a blockbuster, period piece like this work?the battle scenes and the acting. First off, the acting was very impressive. Fuqua casted relatively unknown actors, besides Owen and Keira Knightly, to play the other pivotal parts in the film. None of the performances seemed forced and all appear to become their characters which was probably easier because they did not have to play the well known characters. These were all new interpretations of Arthur and his knights, allowing them to play the characters as they see fit. Who was impressive though was Knightly. Although I am a fan, I was even more impressed with the way she handled the role of Guinevere. Guinevere is no longer a princess who watches from the background but a warrior of Merlin who contributes greatly to the battles. Not many young, very young (19), actress today can pull off a role where you have to be a gorgeous potential Queen one minute and then a brutal warrior the next. And it was these battle scenes that made the film stand out just that much more. You have to appreciate it when directors and writers try to find new and innovative ways to have a battle scene that isn't two giant armies running at one another, swinging large weapons. 'Arthur' is one of those movies that made you believe these were how battles of that time should have been fought. And they were fun to watch.All in all, 'King Arthur' amazed me. Very rarely to I walk into a film with such high expectations that they would never be filled. Yea, 'Arthur' surpassed everything I ever imagined. It is by far the best film I have seen this year, yes even better than Spiderman in my opinion, and it will be hard to beat it in the coming months. You might not agree with my assessment of the film but hey, you're not me.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Z Wing</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Very existentialist</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>An excellent all-around piece that presents the basis for the Arthurian legend we're already familiar with. Merlin as field marshall and rumored mystic. Guinevere as beguiling and charismatic warrior princess. Lancelot as noble but conflicted knight. Arthur as world-weary social crusader. The Knights of the Round Table as battle-hardened, homesick conscripts. The performances are heartfelt. Clive Owen's charisma was apparent early in his career when he delivered intense and focused performances in such films as "Close My Eyes." He would make an excellent James Bond if the franchise's producers ever made the wise decision to return the character to his roots. Lancelot, Guinevere, and the Knights are delivered in an understated manner. Particularly memorable for me was Stephen Dillane as Merlin. The film's centerpiece is a clever battle scene between the Knights (plus Guinevere) and a company of Saxon marauders on top of a frozen lake. The climactic battle scene compares favorably to the Battle of the Pelennor Fields in "Return of the King." I would have liked more exploration of the "wolds," the Pict fighters led by Merlin and Guinevere, as well as Guinevere's relation to Merlin, but time would not have permitted. I enjoyed the existentialist theme. What is a soldier's purpose amidst the endless, meaningless conflicts of a collapsing superpower? Arthur, Lancelot, and the Knights face these questions and search for their answers the only way they can. Compared to recent sword &amp; sorcery films, I'd rank this a notch or two above "The 13th Warrior," several notches above "Braveheart" and "Troy," and just under the "Lord of the Rings" films, which of course are in a class all their own.</fullReview>

		<username>fathom_ayo</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Masterpiece of Philosophic and Esthetic Integration.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"King Arthur," scripted by David Franzoni ("Gladiator"), is a marvelous work indeed, especially considering the cultural poverty that Western civilization is presently undergoing. That Jerry Bruckheimer, noted for much more lightweight fare, produced it, is astonishing.In a time when movies about flesh-and-blood (as opposed to comic-book or mythological) heroes are few and far between; in an age where most moviegoers want to see films about non-descript, jaded non-entities in order to reassure themselves that "yes, life shouldn't be taken seriously" and "see, I'm not so bad after all," it is heartening to see a movie that bucks this trend with a cinematic vengeance worthy of human dignity. "Arthur" takes the myth of a well-known legend and makes it a plausible, highly-inspiring history.We are piloted into the period's atmosphere by Lancelot, who tells us that the Church is in charge of Rome and Rome of the world. Arthur is a British-born Roman citizen in charge of a crack squad of renowned fighters. He is a Christian, a follower and student of the Catholic priest Pelagius (who was condemned by the Church not of the more influential, scheming patristic, Augustine. As such, Arthur's highest concern is the freedom of the individual His men, however, are pagans of unspecified denominations.On the day they are to be relieved from the military service of Rome, Arthur and his men are given one last charge: to retrieve, from Britain, a young boy with a powerful future and to deliver him to Rome where he'll be safe.The rest, is the story.And, contrary to what virtually every reviewer I've read has written, "King Arthur" keeps and "explains" each and every aspect of the legend: Arthur's retrieval of the sword Excalibur; Lancelot's place as the King's champion who will stop at nothing to protect his Queen; etc. It's all there. Attentive minds will pick up on these things. There are also solid touches of Romanticism which enliven the story, such as its portrayal of the fact that, in real life, most of the time, men of action attract similar women and vice versa.The only downsides to the movie are the coarse jokes about unwed fatherhood and physical endowment, which should have been left out.This, ladies and gentlemen, is high-level entertainment, with superb acting, tight direction, and kick-ass fight scenes.Enjoy.9/10 stars.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>TheProctologist</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>An entertaining, if a little familiar, story of Arthur</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Better suited for those who have little or no knowledge of the Arthurian Legend as told in books such as The Once and Future King, King Arthur is a solid, albeit well worn, summer action movie. Gone is the familiar magic and love triangle, instead replaced by a reportedly more realistic and historically accurate portrayal of Arthur and his knights.The story follows Arthur and his band of knights, out to complete one last mission for Rome before they are released from their duties to the empire. Of course, the story becomes more complex as Arthur gets involved with the Woads and their feud with the invading Saxons, but suffice it to say, this is not the Arthur that most are familiar with. All of the actors are very good in their roles, Owen giving us a more somber, brooding Arthur, a man on a mission not only for his knights and people, but for himself. Keira Knightley, portrayed as the sweet girl or damsel in distress in her other films, more than holds her own as a more intense, violent Guinevere. None of the characters are extraordinarily deep, but it is easy for the audience to connect with the ideals for which Arthur and his people fight, and the emotions the characters feel. And fight they do. The film sports some astonishing fight sequences, including a wonderful spectacle on a thin sheet of ice. As we've seen in his earlier movies, Antoine Fuqua shows an eye for visual flair in his film.As for the bad, some parts of the battle scenes are rather poorly edited, though it doesn't detract too much from the excitement. My real complaint here is the obvious pain the filmmakers went through to get a PG-13 rating. We could have been treated to a much more visceral, gritty film with an R rating, a feel I'm sure the filmmakers were going for. Unfortunately, Jerry Bruckheimer seems to think good film is made at the box office. The story, as I've said, is well worn, a story that is much more effectively presented in films like Kurosawa's Seven Samurai.In the end, for a satisfying, entertaining way to pass two hours without having to think to terribly hard, King Arthur is just what the doctor ordered.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-07-07</date>
		<username>Joseph Kastner (JAKastner@wi.rr.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>The Moose Hole - Review of King Arthur</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What would the summer season be without another action-packed adventure flick from Jerry Bruckheimer? Since Top Gun officially deemed him one of the leading producers in the summer of 1986 (though, to his credit, it was Beverly Hills Cop that really kicked his career into high gear), he has revved up the careers of such current super-stars as Tom Cruise (Top Gun and Days of Thunder), Will Smith (Bad Boys and Enemy of the State), Nicholas Cage (The Rock, Con-Air, and Gone in 60 Seconds), and Josh Hartnett (Pearl Harbor) as well as director Michael Bay, with whom he has worked with on five feature films over the years. And don't think that time has had effect on his ability to keep turning out hits, not only in the theaters but television as well, or his ability to make stars of his films into leading actors and actresses. He hopes to add Clive Owen onto his already extensive list of accomplishments in Hollywood with the historical take on the Arthurian legend.The story for this telling of the adventures of King Arthur takes away the mythological aspect and place emphasis more on the historical roots that led to the creation of the legend centuries later. Arthur is the leader of a group of loyal knights in the service of the Roman Empire and one who only wishes to finally fulfill his obligation to the Empire and return to the city of Rome to live out the rest of his life in peace. But times have changed; the once great empire that was Rome has become dangerously corrupt and now faces the threat from Barbarian tribes like the Saxons who kill anything and anyone in their way. Those Saxon tribes now have their eyes set on Britannia and Arthur, along with his knights, are sent on one last mission for Rome, which is to bring the favorite godson of the Pope of the Catholic Church to safety. But while accomplishing his final task for the Romans, the realization that the once great center of civilization is gone sets in and Arthur comes to decision that he must take up arms with his former enemies in order to unite the people of Britannia and repel the Saxon force that has invaded their homeland. The story for King Arthur seems rather lifeless and bland when one compares it to the legend on which it is based but taking it for what it is, a historically tweaked version of the story, it is at least a noble effort, if not one that comes off more mediocre then the filmmakers would want. The problem is that Hollywood is devoting too much time and effort into grand historical epics, referring to the lack-luster Troy earlier this year, when they should be putting more thought into bringing the legends to life, not through historical context but through the full-realization of the myths themselves and what they stood for those who heard them.The feature's lack of star power is not its primary draw-backs, in fact it's one of the its better assets, but rather the blame can be transfixed on the script's undeveloped and, at times, meaningless characters. Clive Owen takes his first leap onto the main stage as the historical equivalent to the legendary King Arthur, known as Arturius, and produces one of the film's best performances. Despite an exhilarating performance given by Owen, the audience is often left confused as to the just end Arthur is seeking. At one point, he fights for the Romans, but with the empire crumbling and the realization that his utopia doesn't exist, he shifts course ? if only the filmmakers informed us what that is. Obviously at the end, everything comes together and the goal Arthur was seeking becomes, but unfortunately it comes too late for us to put too much emotional investment in the film's climatic battle sequence to care all that much. Keira Knightley's role as Guinevere is another in which there is confusion placed on the movie-goers as to certain actions that are placed around her. For example, what is her exact relationship with the tribal leader Merlin? In one scene she leads Arthur into a clearing in which the tribal leaders comes out to speak to him about the invading Saxons ? Is she his daughter or just a loyal tribal follower? And what was the sole purpose of Ioan Gruffudd's Lancelot? He's suppose to be Arthur's most devoted follower but often he comes off as whiny and too much of annoyance. And is the whole Lancelot glancing at Guinvere every now and again the best the filmmakers could do into incorporating the Guinvere and Lancelot adultery aspect of the myth into this story? It's not romantic but rather creepy and flat. Overall, for those who had grown up reading about the legendary King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table, the Jerry Bruckheimer spectacular may come as disappointment, not so much as to the point of echoing Warner Brothers' Troy, but rather for its less attractive approach to the legend. For the less informed individuals of this society not willing to venture to Spider-Man 2 for the twentieth time in a week, King Arthur at least offers itself as a reasonable, if not an inferior, alternative. When Jerry Bruckheimer originally envisioned the film, he had planned on a no-holds barred blood, sweat and tears aspect of the Arthurian legend but unfortunately producers must bend to the whims of their studio masters, in this case Disney (can someone just dump Eisner already?), and so the wonderfully choreographed battle sequences are toned down to the level of PG-13 audiences in order to reap in more box office coin. As one can probably guess, the film, namely its action sequences, suffer severely because of this ? perhaps if they had left out a `love scene' between Guinvere and Arthur, which, considering their ages (Knightly ? 19, Owen ? 39), comes off as more disturbing then anything else, and the language had been toned down a bit, certain sequences could have been saved. Don't get the idea that the film's an utter mess; it's actually quite decent if one understands the historical context in which the film is placed and isn't expecting something on the level of Gladiator but more along the lines of the usual Bruckheimer diversion. It's definitely a disappointment considering the amount of marketing blitz Arthur has been given and Bruckheimer's 2003 summer hit, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl, but if one goes in looking for a simple diversion for the summer, then you won't come out demanding your money back at least.My Rating: *** ? out of 5 (Grade: C+)</fullReview>
