		<date>2007-02-06</date>
		<username>GaryIndianna</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>The Real Star Of 'King Arthur'</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'King Arthur' finds producer Jerry Bruckheimer labouring uncertainly in the territory previously occupied by 'Gladiator' and 'Lord of the Rings'. Like Gladiator, King Arthur takes a genuine historical situation and invokes moral outrage over it. In Gladiator, it was slavery and the coercion of men into killing each other in the arena; here, it's the press ganging of conquered citizens into the Roman army. From Lord of the Rings, King Arthur takes it's small group of heroes bound together by fraternal loyalty. It also determinedly avoids the familiar elements of the King Arthur story, so that there's no Camelot, no Lady in the Lake, no round table. Merlin and Guinivere are 'wodes', an otherworldly people who live in the English woodland; Arthur and Merlin rarely meet and when they do they don't like each other. The staple elements of the Holy Grail and Guinivere's infidelity are nowhere to be seen. Instead we have Arthur and his loyal subordinates risking their lives on what appears to be a waste of time conflict with some invading Saxons.It's hard to imagine this film getting made without the muscle of Jerry Bruckheimer behind it. Antoine Fuqua, who directed the very urban 'Training Day', silhouettes his actors against cloudy skies and you can almost smell the rubber tyres which must have been burning just off camera to create the affect. The characters do some illogical things too - why, for example, does Dagonet act suicidally during a battle in which the knights have the upper hand? The supporting actors are generally fine, but Ray Winstone and Stellan Skarsgaard are both cast so close to type that they virtually disappear off the screen. Only Ioan Gruffudd gives an actual performance, and like everyone else, he's hampered by the unspeakable dialogue.The real star of this film, though, is Clive Owen's dentist. In every scene, Owen's gleaming porcelain dentures yank us out of the film and into the 21st century, reminding us we're watching an English actor in the process of crossing over to Hollywood, rather than a historical figure. And it's not just his teeth which are unconvincing, every other inch of him is too. The lack of conviction with which he speaks his lines has to be seen to be believed, so much so that you may doubt your own sanity when you hear him speak the devastating line 'Prepare for combat'. Jerry Bruckheimer may have got this film made, but it might have been for the best if he hadn't.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A taste if life in the dark ages</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think that the most misleading part of this movie is the title. However I found it to be a refreshing look at a period of time that is very seldom depicted in movies. As for being 100% historically accurate, it is probably not. If you want that then better watch the History channel.I found the depictions of the Saxons and Woags especially interesting. The saxon commander was almost devoid of emotion. His campaign was simply that, a job that needed to be doing. Cruelty and death were a part of the campaign, but nothing to be worried about. The woags (I would assume that these are actually Celts or Picts) were depicted as wild eyed naked yet noble savages. An attempt to portray their language was absolutely haunting.As for Arthur and his knights, they were depicted as what they were; forced conscripts into roman service from conquered Barbarian territories. Each had his own personality and style.Most of what you will bring out of this movie is a feeling for the rugged uncomfortable, dirty times of the period known as the dark ages. It was not a fun time to be alive and I think this movie depicts that very well. Other comments refer to the negative treatment of Christianity and Christians by the knights. Remember, at this time Christianity had not spread world wide. These knights would not have come from Christian lands and thus would not have been born Christian. As is common throughout history, unscrupulous people used religion as a way to assert authority over others.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Disappointing.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I rented Paparazzi, which looked like the potential for it to suck was pretty high, so I got King Arthur just to have something to fall back on. Besides, I have been meaning to see it for months, since I never got around to seeing it in the theaters. As it turns out, I was completely wrong. Paparazzi was outstanding, it was King Arthur with all the suck potential. The movie bills itself as the truth behind the legend of King Arthur's knights, which should have been a warning sign to me because Hollywood is not exactly who you want to turn to for the truth behind stories and legends that are centuries old. And after watching the movie, I am reminded of a possible truth of King Arthur that I actually learned in a historical literature class at the University level, which was that there was more than likely not literally a "round table" involved. This movie disagrees.A big step that the movie makes in trying to live up to its promise of providing the reality behind the legend is that Guinevere and Lancelot are not lovers, they just flirt a lot. Lancelot is far too loyal to Arthur, whom he serves and who IS Guinevere's lover. I guess the fact that a Hollywood movie that has two sexy actors of the opposite sex not ending up together at the end of the movie is a good way to give the illusion of reality. By the way, I say illusion based on my immense doubt that the movie really has much to say about the reality behind the legend of King Arthur, not because of any deep knowledge on the subject myself.If you want an interesting story about the time of King Arthur, Mark Twain wrote an outstanding book called "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court," and I very highly recommend it. It is incredibly well written and is a fascinating story, and probably involves more truth about the legend, even though it contains a bit of time travel. Merlin is even more different than his legend in that book than Arthur. Twain actually makes him a villain in his book, which threw me off because my previous knowledge of the legend came mostly from The Sword in the Stone, one of my all time favorite movies.I have to say that I was impressed with Keira Knightly's performance, although under certain conditions. I loved her performance, but her part was badly written. She is given cheesy lines but delivers them as well as they could have been delivered, and here's the even weirder part, I liked her better in this movie than I did in Pirates of the Caribbean, although I liked Pirates of the Caribbean much more than King Arthur. This is also one of those times that I have to disagree strongly with the critics, who compare it to "last summer's disappointment" (London Times Online) or "the flat out silly" (Roger Ebert) Troy. I liked Troy. Maybe I should acknowledge that it's possible that I don't know what I'm talking about.Nah.The climactic scenes of the movie involve lots of stabbings and swordplay and skewering and whatnot, reminding me that I'm really getting tired of these epic battle scenes. They blew me away in Braveheart, but have become so commonplace that they become tiresome to watch because I've seen it all so many times before. At the very least, they really tried to keep the digital effects to a minimum with the battle scenes, which I appreciate. And here's another odd thing, minimizing digital effects was certainly not a priority in Troy, and I liked that movie much better. I think that the small fights were so good that I was able to forgive the tedious digital battles.For a Hollywood Arthur, Clive Owen delivers a fine performance. He looks the part and he is one of the relatively few characters in the film who doesn't have an accent that is wildly out of place and time. James Bernardelli points out that the legend of King Arthur is one of the most enduring stories in all of European culture, a statement with which I whole-heartedly agree (which is also significant because I usually have the exact opposite opinion as he does about movies). And given that, it is hard to believe that what is presented in this movie is what grew into that legend.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I really enjoyed this film overall. First Knight and obviously Sword in the Stone). Gone are the flowing robes and clean faces of the actors that play Arthur, Lancelot and Guinevere. In their place is grit and dirt, sweat and blood. I think that's one of the strenghts of the film in not sugar-coating the "history" behind the story. The battle sequences remind me of Braveheart (but then again what sword and shield action/drama doesn't these days) and Arthur is written as a true hero. Maybe that's why the critics hated it so much, because Arthur was portrayed as a true, courageous hero who gets things done and not a weak, unassuming husband who has no idea Lancelot is getting it on with his wife.I liked this version and found myself drawn in. If I had a critique, the director's cut runs a bit too long (two hours and twenty minutes) and the cinematography in the final battle sequence was a bit too obscure and tightly framed, while all the previous battles are beautifully shot.Maybe it's not the true story and maybe it's not the most historically accurate, but it is definitely entertaining and in some places, an inspiring piece of cinema.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Too bad this wasn't called KING ALFRED or KING ALRIC or KING GEORGE THE HUMANE or almost anything but KING ARTHUR. Then I could have bought it. But KING ARTHUR? Uh-uh. It has nothing to do with the legend we all know and love, the first (and admittedly fictional) King of England as immortalized by Mallory and White and in previous movies like CAMELOT, KNIGHTS OF THE ROUND TABLE and Excalibur. It also is a bit confusing, trying to keep straight who's who and what's what. Apparently, Arthur and his knights are Dalmations (Sarmations in the movie, but I prefer the word Dalmation) who have been raised and trained by the Romans to do their bidding, even if it means slaughtering their own people. The Dalmations go around in the movie dressed as Roman soldiers, even though Arthur refers to them as knights. A group of blue-faced woodsmen (never named, so we shall call them Picts or Merlin's men, since they are led by a hairy, unkempt woodsman named Merlin) basically hide in the forest from Arthur and the Romans. Yet another group, the Saxons, are on the hunt against Arthur and the Romans. They appear to be bloodthirsty Berserkers, or Vikings, which I doubt is historically accurate. Someone who knows more about this stuff than I told me Saxons may have been of Norse origin but they were not ax-wielding savages. They simply were looking to find their place in a land of immigrants. Eventually, the Romans abandon Britain while Arthur and his crew, along with the blue-faced boobies -- I mean Picts -- defeat the Saxons in a bloody if confusing battle that is no match for a similar showdown in the recent TROY, where the Spartans, Greeks and Trojans have at it. Arthur himself is badly acted by Clive Owen, an angular-faced, hoarse-voiced British actor relatively unknown here but whose name was briefly bandied about as the next James Bond. Gueneviere is played by Keira Knightley, the Natalie Portman-lookalike who costarred in PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN, and is portrayed here as a blue-faced warrior princess. She kills with the best of them. Knightley's awful in the role, through no real fault of her own, I suspect. It's the script. To give her credit, she is nearly naked in parts of this movie and that makes up for much. Lancelot is played by some forgettable Brit actor. The CGI is unimpressive, and the battle scenes are few and far between. This looks to have been shot on a fairly tight budget. TROY does a not-dissimilar plot much better, and was shot on a much larger budget. If you have to pick one, see TROY instead.</fullReview>

But given that these are men who have spent 15+ years killing other men up close and personal, as their duty - Men taken from their homes as children and taught to kill - How much emotion can we expect? I saw this lack of emotion as men who had grown used to distancing themselves from the world around them. And who had become just plain tired of the killing (obvious in their longing to be free).Clive Owen played this brilliantly. Every so often there's a glimpse of the turmoil beneath and we watch as he struggles to bring it under control.Watch the actors and their faces. It is the subtleties of their performances that provide the passion and make this movie. Moreover, even these "good guys" aren't so black and white. And that makes them all the more believable.This is an action movie first and foremost, and one of the best kind. NOT a "history". (good thing there isn't much dialogue, cuz the script sucks big time.) Overall, one I will add to my collection.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I've been able to see an advance copy of the DVD, Fuqua's director's cut. I feel this version, his original vision, is much better than the original release. Touchstone/Disney insisted on his cleaning up the violence in the battles, giving it a fairy-tale ending (the wedding) and other PG fixes. Fuqua's audio commentary is extremely frank in discussing this, as well as offering insights on how/why he made the choices he did. The DVD also shows his original ending, which I found far more subtle and less obvious ("on the nose," as we say in the business). Other extras include a 17-minute "Making of" featurette, which is interesting and informative and a round-table discussion with Knightley, Owen, Dancy, Gryffudd, producer Jerry Bruckheimer, writer David Franzoni and director Anthony Fuqua. On the whole, I think this one is a worthwhile buy. I understand it will be available Dec. 5.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Saw King Arthur for the third time (yeah, baby!) this Saturday in a much better theater with great a sound system, and this made a difference in watching the movie. Watched KA the first two times in the local theater which has a poor sound system and the most uncomfortable seats my ass has ever sat in! Anyway, the movie, King Arthur. What made it better this time? Was it good enough this time around for a 10/10 rating? Oh yeah, you better believe it! Because of the differences between the theaters that's mentioned above, the whole experience was so much better; I could live myself into the movie, laugh and cry with the characters and sit on the edge of my seat during the fights and battles. What is King Arthur about? The Roman Empire is stretched across many nations, including Britain. In their conquest for more land, the Romans went into Sarmatia where they fought the very brave Sarmatian cavalry. The Romans, impressed by the Sarmatian's weaponry and fighting skills, included them into their army as knights. After 15 years of serving and fighting for the Roman Empire, the Sarmatian Knights are about to be free as the Romans are leaving Britain. But the Knights must carry out one final order before they are free. A Roman priest and his family, especially his son Alecto, must be rescued from the invading Saxons. But there is another danger lurking on the road to freedom - the Woads, British rebels who hate the Romans. What makes this movie so damn good then? Let's start with the comradery between the Knights. You can really feel that these men have been fighting side by side for 15 years, the interaction between them is very well-written, kudos to David Franzoni. The story is also very well-written, and capturing. Characters could have been a little deeper, but what was there worked for this movie. The acting performances were outstanding. Clive Owen as Arthur was a very good choice from the director and producers, he has this depth in his performance that you don't see from many actors these days. Ioan Gruffudd as Lancelot was also a very good pick. I would say he had the same depth as Owen in his performance, very rare. Ray Winstone as Bors, what can I say, just simply amazing and amusing! He definitely provides the funny moments in KA. Keira Knightley as Guinevere was very good, I love to watch women who fights (just look at Uma in Kill Bill). And the villain, Cerdic, played by Swedish actor Stellan Skarsg?rd. The first time I saw the movie I wasn't THAT impressed with him, but the second and third time he just blew me away - "evil as hell, he MUST die", that's what I was thinking during the movie.And the music by Hans Zimmer is one of the most amazing scores I've ever heard, after The Last Samurai. It's not too overwhelming, but it helps make the movie stronger and more powerful in many scenes which is just a bonus.The cinematography by Slavomir Idziak is great. In many shots I was just like "Wow" and "Ah", especially in the ice battle, my God, that's good stuff right there. So in conclusion; this is another great movie from Jerry Bruckheimer with a lot of heart and great performances along with a great score by Zimmer, although it has taken a lot of cheap shots from reviewers and critics. If you like movies like Gladiator, Troy and The Last Samurai, you will probably enjoy King Arthur. 10/10Review by Andreas FurumoGet Ready to Rock!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-07-18</date>
		<username>madam_Q</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Noble intention, poor execution</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*MINOR SPOILERS*Logic dictates that taking Britain's most well known and oft told myth and stripping it of everything that makes it memorable is a bad idea. This did not deter the makers of 'King Arthur', and while the premise is interesting, it's execution is sloppy, leaving behind a film doomed to reside in the shadows of such great predecessors as the film 'Excalibur', and the TV min-series 'Merlin'.Historians have long speculated over the real identity of the mysterious King Arthur and his knights of the Round Table and, as the prologue of this film tells us, recent archaeological discoveries point to him being a descendent of Sarmatian knights. As it stands, this is only speculation, but gives the film its premise. As the film opens, the Romans are pulling out of 'indefensible outposts' such as Britain, leaving the native people to defend themselves against the bloody thirsty and murderous Saxons. Artorius (Arthur to his pals) and his knights are eagerly awaiting their deeds of emancipation so they may return to a home they barely remember after fifteen years of service in Britain. But he and his knights are handed one final mission - to rescue an important Roman family who have settled, for reasons best known to themselves, on the other side of Hadrians Wall. This is the film's first misfire - it makes no sense. If this family are so important, why have they been allowed to live in such a dangerous place? To reach them, Arthur and his knights are forced to travel through territory controlled by native Britons, known as 'Woads', making their task a virtual suicide mission. Except it isn't. Because Merlin, paying lip service to the Arthurian legend as the leader of the Woads, knows that the rampaging Saxons will shortly be on their doorstep and Arthur and his knights could be their only hope against a much stronger enemy.After a strong first act, the film becomes a gloomy, murky stew. The characters founder - Arthur's knights are virtually interchangeable and have surprisingly little of the screenplay devoted to them. Ray Winstone's rambunctious Bors is memorable, but all the others, even Lancelot, are as dull as ditch water. Keira Knightly adds her own sparkly charm as Guenevere but her character is woefully underwritten. Her only purpose is to let loose a few arrows - Orlando Bloom showed her a thing or two on the set of Pirates of the Caribbean, it seems - and throw a spanner in the works as Arthur's love interest. But this only paves the way for what is, in my mind, the biggest disappointment in the film - the fabled love triangle between Arthur, Guenevere and Lancelot has been scrapped. Oh sure, Lance spies Guennie looking fetching while bathing and there are a few meaningful looks, but the ultimate opportunity to create a drama with the potential to actually suck us into this world and make us care about these characters has been abandoned. Still, that may be no bad thing because the fewer occasions on which Clive Owen is required to emote the better. Clive has his own physicality that serves him well in the fight scenes, but speaks his lines as though reading from a cue card. This is disastrous - like Russell Crowe's Maximus in 'Gladiator', Arthur is the foundation this whole house of cards is built on.Oh, if an actor of Russ's caliber had taken the helm, it could have been a completely different film. Without a charismatic leading man, the film steadily crumbles as it heads towards a climax you just don't care about.But, hey, it doesn't matter if the hero is a big dull dud as long as you have an interesting villain, right? Ehm, wrong. As the leader of the Saxons, the usually serviceable Stellan Skarsgard looks bored and gives the impression that he is working on another much more interesting movie during the week and only mucking in on 'King Arthur' on his days off. We only know he is a baddie because he issues orders like "Burn every village, kill everyone" and, in a confusing sequence, saves a woman from being raped and then orders her death.So the film lumbers on to the inevitable final climactic battle. Guenevere reappears in a costume (well, if you can call two strips of leather a costume) that Xena, Warrior Princess would blush and back away from and Arthur and his knights get to look cool while silhouetted on a hill top - the filmmakers apparently confused as to whether they are retelling the Arturian legend or paying homage to 'The Magnificent Seven'. The battle that follows is confusing, choppily edited and uninvolving. Some of the fighting is impressive, but pales in comparison to the far superior swordplay in previous epics such as 'Troy'. Like much of the preceding film, it's dark, dour and gloomy. When it's finally over we are treated to the prerequisite happy ending, which contrasts too much with the rest of the movie not to throw the whole thing off balance.The look of the film is another major downfall. Yes, this is a 'realistic' retelling of the story of King Arthur, but why must it be so gloomy? Sitting in the cinema I felt like somebody needed to turn the contrast up. It lacks an epic feel that you might have expected in this sort of movie - there is a stunning paucity of sweeping aerial shots and stunning scenery. Instead, it gives the impression of being made on the cheap, with one section of forest standing in for a variety of locations. Everything is dark - the sets, the costumes - nothing stands out as remarkable. There is none of the punch or dazzle usually associated with a Jerry Brukheimer film.'King Arthur' would have benefited from a tighter storyline and more focus on the central characters. I would have liked to see the relationships between Arthur and his knights better developed. We find out nothing of their motivations or why they are so attached to Arthur that they will follow him to almost certain death instead of beating a path to the utopia of Rome like sensible people. That's the film's biggest mystery - why would anyone want to follow the sour faced Mr Owen ANYWHERE?Overall, it's a pleasant way to waste a Sunday afternoon. Much of the fun is in seeing the filmmakers' imagining of where the classic hallmarks of Arthurian legend - the round table, Excalibur - originated. Remove the familiar elements and you are left with a gritty and sour period piece that is ultimately disappointing.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A Great Movie - Get the DVD !</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a truly great motion picture.There appear to be many inaccurate and misleading negative comments about this movie. When it first came out, the harshly negative reviews and the 'dark' preview caused me to miss one of the best movies in 50 years. I don't want to be too hard on critics, but for the benefit of others who may want an informed opinion on the 2004 motion picture, "King Arthur", I recommend you buy the DVD if interested in possible historical origins of the Arthur myths.For a critic to simply say the movie is 'non-historical' is well off the mark, and in fact not true at all. For beginners, one might refer to Linda Malcor's excellently researched and fully documented articles; one is online at,http://www.mun.ca/mst/heroicage/issues/2/ha2lac.htmand her book, coauthored with Littleton, "From Scythia to Camelot". Sadly for those who would prefer some mythical - yet no doubt 'British' origin of Arthur - it appears almost certain now that he was in fact a Roman army officer. There are stone-carvings with the name 'Artorius' in his honor; there appears to be no trace of any English or Celtic root for the name, Arthur, contrary to the desires of many English medieval kings (and their public) who wished such a lineage.There are, in the movie, a number of deliberate departures from known (or probable) history; for one, the Saxons would be hardly likely to land north of the wall, knowing of its existence as they do in the film, then having to face it later. But it is easy to see that these are nothing more than 'dramatic license', which add to the storytelling, and do no damage at all to the main point of the movie - Arthur as the Roman, and the knight stories as transfers of Sarmatian myths. In fact, this is far and away the most realistic movie - or story - yet made about Arthur. The medieval tales, and the comic books, are clearly all myths.Some argue that it would have 'made no sense' for the Romans to move captive soldiers from one end of the empire to the other, to provide local defense. In actuality, this was a rather common practice of Rome's, see for example Goldsworthy, "Roman Warfare", 1999, Cassell, Great Britain. And in point of fact, approx. 5500 Sarmatian cavalry were transferred to Britain, many to service on Hadrian's Wall, after their defeat by Marcus Aurelius in the 2nd century A.D. It seems probable, following Malcor and Littleton's research (among others, beginning in 1925), that the commander of these Sarmatians was a certain Roman officer named L. Artorius Castus.That is why this movie is such a grabber - it may not portray every event, or even most events, accurately; it may not get every sequence correct; but it goes a long, long way to capturing the essence of what many now believe about Arthurian history. I submit that is all a movie can do in 2 hours - and most fall miserably far short of the standard set here. Of course some myth- lovers are defiant: they have lost their stock in trade - the discussion of Arthur in mythological context only. The story is real, and bears only a little resemblance to the myths; in fact, it is a better story than the myths, and more exciting, as fact almost always is. The music and acting are superb, and sent shivers down my spine. It makes 'Camelot' (1960's), 'First Knight', 'Excalibur', etc look like the fairy tales they are.Though I am a Christian, it is good to see an accurate portrayal of the early Church. Such extreme treatment of pagans - and heretics - was not unusual, and the Church was at times synonymous with the Roman State. I believe that was why the artifice of Pelagius' presence was used - it forms a central part of the development of Arthur's character. And in fact, Germanius did actually go to Britain - to preach against the Pelagian Heresy - that too appears to be well documented. Again, it sets the tone.A suggestion - the movie happens fast. It really does not become clear in a single watching. Those confused might try a 2nd or even 3rd viewing. The DVD is better by far than the theater version. The CD music is haunting and beautiful.jrc</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Exceptional adaptation. Shockingly underrated. Beyond original.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I first visited this page, I expected the overall rating for this movie to be much higher. I can theorize as to why perhaps this movie is not quite yet getting the credit it deserves from the userbase as I am a huge fan of the King Arthur legend and before having viewed this movie was extremely skeptical seeing as, in my mind there could never be a movie that would top John Boorman's "Excalibur", which is probably my favorite movie of all time.When I finally conceded to risk seeing "King Arthur", there was something I liked so much about it... just the overall feel of the movie: the story and how it was all put together... and yet I needed more time to get used to it because the truth of the matter is, this movie is in a class of it's own. So when I saw it for a second time (this time the Director's Cut, which is the best version not just due to the extended fight scenes but notably for more detail on the relationship between Guinevere and Lancelot) more was made clear to me...the character of King Arthur is presented as a historical figure who is linked to Rome and the conquests of the Roman Empire, and the struggle to liberate Great Britain from Roman occupation and Saxon invasion.Comparing King Arthur to Excalibur is like comparing an apple to an orange. There is no point because each is its own freestanding entity. In other words, one must distance oneself from the closer-to-fiction-like versions of King Arthur, and open ones mind a little to a more realistic and closer-to-history version/vision of King Arthur, or Lucius Artorius, the name by which he is known in Rome. Lancelot, Guinevere, Merlin and the Knights are all portrayed differently than in prior adaptations and even if you're addicted (like I am) to the more fantastic, there is a chance you will really enjoy this movie, especially if you (also like me) have a love of history, lineages, past cultures and excellently choreographed battle scenes.Clive Owen is perfect for the role he plays (Arthur). The closeups of him mounted and in full armor (the costumes are fabulous in this movie) epitomize him as the Brit/Roman in the traditional dress of an officer in the Roman Cavalry: he is absolutely majestic. I find it extremely interesting that he is, of course, British and yet he seems to have some almost Nicolas Cage-type attributes as if maybe in real life he is partially descended from Italy or someplace nearby.If there is possibly an actor who fits a designated role even better, it is Stellan Skarsgard as the leader of the Saxons. Whoever's idea it was to cast Stellan as the Ultimate Viking, as in this movie, should get some kind of award, seriously. I have been in awe of Stellan ever since I first saw him in "The Hunt for Red October" (another one of my favorite movies). He is such a versatile actor and seeing him in this light; the image of him: tall (they do a great job of emphasizing his height in this movie), and about as Norse looking as it gets (not just the classic long hair and braids, but also his exquisitely Nordic facial features) is an unforgettable experience. His overall presence along with his characteristic gruff, raspy voice and blunt mannerisms showcase his talents in a way better than ever.On that note Til Schweiger, whom I had never seen prior to this movie, really caught my eye. As with the rest of the cast care is taken to focus on his features (in his case classically Germanic), and this along with the determined, fierce look in his eyes makes a very convincing son and second in command to Cerdic. Arthur's Knights all hail from the Eastern European regions, I believe, and once again the casting here was superb. Keira Knightly's Guinevere is actually a Celt in this movie as is Merlin, who is portrayed as somewhat of a wildman and is very striking. The acting job of everyone is superb.In closing I need to say that I, like others, have been very disappointed with past attempts to create a story of King Arthur for movie viewers. Before I saw this movie, after having seen others fail, I didn't know how this movie was to succeed, especially having the monumental Excalibur to live up to. If you decide to give this movie a chance, you may just find yourselves swept away by it just like I was. I read someone comment on a bit of excessive bloodiness in the movie, and I agree with this which could qualify as my only (minor) quibble. I'm not a huge fan of unnecessary violence in movies. There may be a couple of instances where the fights were a little savage for my tastes, but these instances were relatively few in this movie (there are much, much worse in this respect out there). For the most part the battle scenes were quite thrilling; filmed very well along with the dramatic music. The scenery and special effects were absolutely beautiful and, in response to naysayers who claim to have a problem in that some of the scenery does not depict any part of England actual I feel inclined to remark that this movie is shot in a different time than our present one, and even if there never was anything like "ice" in England...this is, well, after all a movie and if it adds anything to the drama or flair and excitement (which I certainly thought it did), I don't mind one bit. Artistic Licence exists for a reason. Ability to use this license well is what separates great movie makers from the rest. The Bruckheimer/Fuqua collaboration is a winner. The movie is a triumph. I look forward to more good work by everyone involved in it.10/10.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-07-17</date>
		<username>suren113</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Possibly more truth than fiction</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First I'd like to give a number of commentators a C- simply for a natural lack of curiosity due to a sad educational system. Recent evidence in the social history of the Scythes and their descendants ( the Sarmatians ) has tied the origins of the legend of King Arthur neatly to that part of the world and NOT England. The Sarmatians ( who historically were superb horsemen ) made up a large contingent of the Roman army of occupation in ancient Britain. There was a historical Sarmatian commander named Aurtoius with considerable power. Arthur is not a Celtic name. And Roman cavalrymen were called 'Knights'. The final battle against the Saxons actually did take place, but little evidence exists as to the composition of the British/Roman Army. The film's storyline made a nice stab at it but there were probably far more Sarmatians and Romans and other auxiliaries involved. Though the film showed a strong desire on the part of the Sarmatians to return home after their tour of duty was over, by that time there was no Sarmatia. The Huns had pushed them into Southern Russia and Poland ( in Poland their legacy can be found in Polish heraldry ).Many Roman Auxiliary troops would inter-marry with the locals. More than likely this was the case with the Sarmatians. And from them stories would pass from generation to generation. Though the costuming in the film was off ( budgets! ) for the time period where the Romans are concerned, there is a splendid scene before the final battle where three of the Sarmatian knights are decked out in Sarmatian armor ( even to the conical helmet which became popular among European knights centuries later ). All in all there was possibly more truth than fiction in this film. The pace was fast, battle scenes furious, acting ( for an international cast and considering a lean script ) was fine. Label this a 'guy's' movie as long as the 'guy' isn't hung up on the fantasy of the Legend. I give it 7 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>OK! I'm not too sure PRECISELY when the Romans withdrew from Britannia.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(some spoilers?) * * * * * But, I agree with the script writers. It was sometime in the 5th century AD (or, CE--Common Era--for all you British readers). That being said, I think this movie is the most historically accurate swashbuckler, in recent years. Even more so than "Gladiator" and "Braveheart" put together! For instance; there were, indeed, conscripted POW'S employed as auxiliary cavalrymen in Roman Britannia. Especially, near Hadrian's Wall. Some of them were Sarmatians (racial kinfolk/rivals of the equally equestrian Scythians), whose heraldic flag was a dragon-headed banner. Others came from North Africa, Spain, and even Gaul (alias France)!I find the latter fact very interesting. Because, while I know that this movie's version of Guinivere is written as a warrior princess of the Woads (in Latin; Picts), in most traditional compendiums of Arthurian lore, her father was a _French_ king. Gorlois, I believe. Whose to say that the real-life basis of Guinivere wasn't half-Gallic/half-Pictish? That would certainly explain why this movie-version felt such an intense attraction to the Romano-Britonic Arthur! In any case, I give Mr. Fuqua et al five stars for both originality, emotional involvement, and action-packed storytelling. And, if you see any other movie after "Spider-Man 2," make it this one.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A both positive and negative look at King Arthur</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Positive attributes: Story is the backbone of every movie ever made. If it's loose or incomplete, the whole movie usually falls apart. Luckily, this movie's story is good enough to keep it on its feet. After years of mandatory service to Rome, Arthur and his knights are just one mission away from the sweet, sweet freedom they've craved all their lives.Good acting for the most part. Clive Owen delivers a realistic performance as the legendary King Arthur, portraying him as a loyal and level-headed Roman commander. Ioan Gruffudd also does a great job of Lancelot, Arthur's loyal but very different friend. Merlin has been completely stripped of his magical powers and given a much grittier feel as the leader of the Woads, the warlike rebellion against Rome's occupation of Britain. The award for best acting, though, should definitely go to Stellan Skarsg?rd, who gives a rough and scary portrayal of Cerdic, the ruthless, bloodthirsty leader of the Saxons. The battle action isn't anything you've never seen before. It's bloody, brutal, realistic, blah blah blah... Hans Zimmer shines (in moments) as the movie's composer, eliciting a powerful score to wrap the rest of the movie in.Negative attributes: If over and underacting annoys you as much as it does me, then wear a mouth guard, for you'll be grinding your teeth quite a bit. Overacting seems to be popular amongst (mostly) the secondary actors in this film, for whatever reason. Unfortunately, Keira Knightly (who plays Guinevere) only provides more evidence to my suspicion that she can't actually act by her displaying some more of her acting abilities in this film (or lack thereof).Also, if you're an avid hater of clichés (as I very much am), be prepared to catch a net-full. In fact, there are so many in this movie that they become downright tiresome almost right away.Another minor complaint I have with this movie is that it didn't draw out the love triangle between Guinevere, Arthur, and Lancelot as much as I would've liked.Conclusion: Overall, King Arthur is an OK movie, certainly worth seeing. For me, what is most disappointing is that Antoine Fuqua, the acclaimed director of Training Day, took over this after Michael Bay (who I don't especially like) dropped out, and I can't really imagine what Bay might've done differently (with the exception of maybe subtracting some from the story and tossing in a few more special effects). As long as you aren't expect Shakespeare when inserting the disc into your DVD player, you'll at least be entertained.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>In a demystified version of the King Arthur legend, Clive Owen (Arthur) must fight for the freedom of Britain from an invading Saxon army.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This new version of the King Arthur legend has gotten a lot of bad criticism, but is also not recognized for its better meanings. One of the major changes in the story is that Arthur, not yet a king, is a Roman officer who is in charge of a group of Sarmatian knights. These knights take on the legendary names such as Lancelot, Gawain and Galahad.Some elements of the story from a historical point of view are inaccurate. For instance, the time period of the film takes place long after the Romans have already left Britain and also when the Roman Empire itself had basically collapsed.The character of Arthur is also altered. He is given a much darker personality, and is a man who contradicts himself throughout the movie. The character of Guenivere (Keira Knightly) is also different as she is a brutal warrior rather than the classical lady in white robes. As for the knights, I would recommend that you see this movie several times to get their individual character traits as the story focuses mainly on Arthur, Guenivere and a very brave, very unfortunate Lancelot (Ioan Gruffiudd).The extended director's cut is a better version of the film as it provides a more brutal and therefore emotional environment, as well as a better film of character development. The film includes wonderful costumes, brutal battle scenes (that includes an amazing duel between Stellan Skarsgard and Mads Mikkelsen), okay acting, a beautiful environment and also a well played score by Hans Zimmer.All and all this is a well made movie that focuses on another perspective of a legendary tale, a concept that I always enjoy.I would also recommend Braveheart for its theme of freedom and Gladiator for its brush with the Roman world.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>The sadly underrated "King Arthur" provides a rip-roaring and original take on the classic Medieval legend. The film is set in the brutal world of the 5th Century AD, right at the moment when the crumbling Roman Empire is turning inward and withdrawing its forces from far-flung outposts such as Briton, where barbarians from the north, sensing Rome's weakness, are beginning to make incursions into the regions south of Hadrian's Wall. In this version, Arthur's famous Knights of the Round Table are a compendium of conscripted tribesmen who have faithfully and courageously served the cause of Rome for the past 15 years. Now, just at the moment when they are about to be granted their hard-earned freedom and are eager to return home, they are sent on a final dangerous mission deep into Saxon territory to rescue a boy who may be a possible successor to the Pope in Rome."King Arthur" focuses more on the geopolitical aspects of the tale than the customary romance and magic - although neither of those has been completely slighted in this telling. The film opts for a darker, more realistic treatment of the story - there's no talk of Camelot here - one in which, Arthur, Lancelot, Guinevere and the rest undergo internal conflicts and moral struggles often overlooked in earlier versions of the story. Arthur, in particular, the product of a Roman father and a Saxon mother, is torn between his loyalty to Rome and to the island he calls home. But, above all, he is faithful to the men who have served under his command and, with whom, he has been able to forge a chivalric code of ethics - one whose very cornerstone is individual rights and freedoms - that seems like an anachronism in a world dedicated to enslavement, brutality and destruction. The violence in the film is grim, graphic and gory but appropriate to the times in which the movie is set.David Franzoni has written an intelligent, dramatic screenplay, and Antoine Fuqua has directed the movie with flair and style. The action scenes are vivid and intense, and the film features the best ice floe battle sequence since "Alexander Nevsky." The acting - by Clive Owen as Arthur, Keira Knightley as Guinevere and Ioan Gruffudd as Lancelot - is no great shakes, but at least it's unobjectionable.For the most part, the movie's attempts at de-romanticizing the legend work well - although turning Guinevere into a halter top-wearing, bow-wielding combatant on the order of a Boudicca or even Xena-Princess Warrior, does seem a bit much. However, since the film is less a retelling of the Arthurian legends and more a chronicle of the "real" people on whom the characters were allegedly based, such re-imaginings are more forgivable than they might otherwise have been. And like most actions films these days that don't seem to know when to leave well enough alone, "King Arthur" is saddled with a saggy third act whose repetitive battle scenes drain some of the life out of the story.All in all, though, "King Arthur" emerges as a handsomely produced, thrilling tale of love, hope and freedom that should satisfy the schoolboy adventurer in all of us.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Written by Todd McCarthy of Variety:Brandishing a surprising seriousness of purpose for a would-be summer blockbuster, "King Arthur" bracingly repositions the Arthurian myth in a specific and savage historical moment quite removed from its usual placement in a bucolic world of chivalrous knights, a mischievous magician and an errant queen. Impressively made and well acted by an exceedingly attractive cast, this dark tale of ceaseless conflict is adult entertainment and will likely disappoint viewers expecting a "Camelot"-like love triangle, as it will the fun-seeking youth audiences that made "Pirates of the Caribbean" a smash for Disney and producer Jerry Bruckheimer a year ago. As a result, domestic B.O.B.O. will likely be closer to that of "Braveheart," which grossed only $76 million even with its Oscars, than to the Bruckheimer norm. In line with most big-canvas action fare, overseas should yield considerably higher returns.</fullReview>

The accents range from traditional Oxford English to Cockney and the Romans speak in thick Italian. This is a vastly different take on the story of Arthur and it's both a hit and miss but with the dark and dirty look and a pretty strong performance by Owen I found this to be a fairly effective film.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>When I heard about this movie, I was expecting another remake of the old legend. Which was fine with me, as I am a great fan of the legend. What we have here is not a fairy tell brimming with completely selfless men in shining armour, doing their duty to protect peace without a thought for themselves. No. This is a much more realistic take on the legend, in the sense that it shows the actual harshness of the period in which it takes place. Nobody (Romans and Arthur aside) wears flawless armour and carries a jewel-encrusted sword. The knights are just ordinary men, taken from Sarmatia by the Romans to serve in the Empire as knights. They are not at all pleased to be fighting, and long to get back to home. Doesn't that sound so much more likely?This movie takes place at the end of the fifteen years a group of Sarmatians (Lancelot, Galahad, Gawain, Tristan, Bors, and Dagonet) have to serve to Rome. They are eagerly anticipating returning home, when they are sent on one final mission. They are extremely displeased, as would be expected. They must rescue an important Roman family in the north from a massive Saxon invasion.I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. I don't actually care if the history was slightly off (Saxons and Romans at the same time), it was just a very entertaining film. The characters are interesting, the scenery is terrific, the battle scenes are brilliant, and the script can be funny even in such a serious plot. 		<username>ConsultingHobbitExtractors</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Had potential, but the characters hold it back from greatness.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie in a nutshell is a missed opportunity. You've got a great plot basis but not enough historical evidence to prevent you from making your own story. The filmmakers certainly did make their own story of the legend, but they kind of shifted their aim halfway through making it and missed the target. There are some good points to it, but it definitely could have been better. The main two problems are that it 1) tried to be like Pirates of the Caribbean too much, and 2) tried to rationalize too much of the legend into a more realistic context. The latter mostly comes out in the characters, who end up being pretty disappointing. Arthur and his knights in legendary form might not be true to life, but they are nonetheless good characters. Part of this comes from the fantasy element of the legends, which makes them nobler and generally more memorable. So putting it into historical context, while sound in theory, turns out like it would if you re-made the Harry Potter movies to be about a school of exceptional magicians instead of actual wizards. Historical accuracy is fine in some films, but it doesn't necessarily mean that it will be a good story. Braveheart has a lot of historical inaccuracies, but it's still regarded as very good film, and I think they could have taken a page out of that book here.The plot itself is not bad, even if it's action driven. Arthur is asked to send his knights on one last mission just as they are about to be given their freedom. This involves them traveling into hostile lands and rescuing a high-ranking roman's family. After that, they have to protect the entire village that they end up bringing along with them from the barbarians of Britain. The entire plot structure has a very Bruckheimer-ish feel to it with the ideas of rebelling against the powers that be and those characters that play are both friend and foe, sometimes simultaneously. None of the plot is based on the stories or on any historical evidence except for the setting. All other factors aside, the plot gets a B to B+.However the characters are another matter. They aren't terrible, but they could have been much better. Arthur's leadership and strong defense of his knights is presented pretty well with the injustices done to them by the roman superiors. His other qualities are unremarkable for somebody in his position, and his relationship with Guinevere was given almost zero plausible development. Guinevere could have been done better, though I liked her statement about how Arthur is described as "somebody so selfless and noble they can't be real". Her character is only half complete and almost makes her seem like she's acting for somebody else since she has motives, philosophies, and battle skills to boot, but no real personality to compliment this. The inverse can be said of Lancelot, who has a personality with dignity, but his intentions are unclear and/or inconsistent. This is really too bad since he dies at the end and his death scene could probably have been better if he had a little more depth. Cedric and Cynric are okay villains, though Stellen Skasgard's performance was slightly disappointing. The other knights are fair characters, and will probably seem only slightly above or below average depending on whether you liked them. I couldn't stand Bors and liked Tristan (Mads Mikkelsen), but others will feel differently. The supporting characters were written well, with the exception of Merlin, who is added into the story pretty haphazardly without doing justice to his part in the legend.The action's not bad and feels a lot like the action scenes in Gladiator, though of course without the Gladiator fighting setting. It's not a huge adrenaline rush or a great work of choreography or effects like the Matrix. The best action sequence in almost every regard is the frozen lake. A lot of it is small scale skirmishes until the big climatic battle. The final battle isn't terrible, but it's kind of disappointing for a climatic scene. There's a bit of blood throughout, but nothing too intense. The screenwriters made a few attempts at comic relief, mostly generated by Bors. I really disliked this aspect of the film because I didn't find any of it amusing and it the only character it ever really developed was Bors, who I don't like anyway. Saying that the comic relief is straight up bad is too much, but it's definitely sub-par especially for a Bruckhiemer flick.The technical execution was pretty good. The costumes, editing, spfx, and acting were just fine, maybe even above average. The script wasn't too bad either, even if the characters weren't written well. Hans Zimmer's score was below average for him, and sounded a lot like a blueprint for his Pirates of the Caribbean scores. There are a lot of melodies that should sound vaguely familiar to Pirates fans, though not quite as good.Overall, it's not a terrible film, but it could be much better. I would recommend it if you're looking for a strictly action film, but consider some other options if you're seeking a great cinematic work. If Bruckhiemer is your absolute favorite producer/director, go ahead and buy this, but I advise everyone else to rent it. It's not a general crowd pleaser or a group movie that you can talk to your friends during, so only watch it with a max of about four people. If you aren't enjoying it after about an hour, I would suggest stopping because the second half won't change your opinion. Overall Rating: 7.7/10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Not bad, not great.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched this movie for the first time just recently, after many years, so I have passed the prejudiced feelings of release-time hype. As an historian myself, I found the movie had many historical flaws, especially in its main theme of Arthur and his "knights" being foreigners recruited by the Romans from faraway Sarmatia - a recently proposed hypothesis that has no factual support, especially as the Arthur legends themselves have little factual support. And of course we know that the Saxons did not come down across Hadrian's Wall, they came mostly from the east of England. What I do like about this film, however, is the departure from the romanticized Camelot and Round Table chivalry styles we are used to seeing, with all the noble derring-do of Arthur's knights. The real Arthur - if he lived - lived in a much earlier time of Roman Britain, and the movie did away with the ridiculous elaborate suits of armor, jousting and banner-laden lances of the later Middle Ages. The movie as filmed was beautiful, with its green Celtic Britain landscapes, weather, and the stone circles (of which there are many all over the British Isles), so the imagery and atmosphere are very well portrayed - much like in the Lord of the Rings films. You feel like you're really there. The acting sucks, mostly. Clive Owen and Keira Knightley are both wooden actors who - in this and all of their films - cannot seem to loosen up or unfreeze their faces for anything, no matter how emotional or expressive. Knightley's mouth moves slowly and steadily while her eyes and face don't move at all. It's difficult to sympathize with them when they are so superficial; it's like, "OK, so am I to feel sorry for these two about anything? All they do is look forever serious for some reason they're not telling me yet". I can think of a hundred better actresses for her role here, both physically and in acting ability. Uma Thurman comes to mind - they should have used her for Galadriel and not Cate Blanchett who also had Keira's boring frozen face look). However, the other actors, from Ray Winstone onward, all did remarkable jobs and made up for the lack of the two majors.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Interesting take of the Arthurian legend, fails to convince</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Arthur, King of Britons, as a Roman officer. It's not as outlandish an idea as it first might seem to be. There has a been a lot of debating going on about the possibility of Arthur Pendragon being at the very least based on a true historical person. And there lived a Roman man named Lucius Artorius Castus in the late 2nd and early 3rd centuries. This movie is based on his fictional exploits in the conquered Britain, long before knights and castles.As said, an interesting idea and the film has some good things going for it. Clive Owen makes for a fantastic King Arthur. His nobility, creed and pure will to do right shine from his every expression and he can totally sell the warrior king aspect of the character as well. She has a few good moments here and there, but most of her performance consists of her glaring around petulantly and being saved by the actual knights. Unfortunately the same cannot be said about the villains, who are just a one-sided bunch of barbarian conquerors. They try to give them a bit of character, but it never rises above clichés.King Arthur is a good movie to check out if you like the Roman period or are interested in seeing a totally different take of the Arthurian legend. Few of its elements rise above average, but it's not a bad film by any means.</fullReview>

		<username>jkbonner1</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>As entertainment just passable-as history total rubbish</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The chief problem with this movie is that it takes itself very seriously. The opening scroll-down boldly announces that historical research has now established the truth behind the legend of Arthur. Really? I don't think so. But with that said, we, the audience, are then supposed to believe that what is presented in the movie is historical fact. It is suggested that the "real" Arthur was in fact one Lucius Artorius Castus, a Roman cavalry commander in charge of a group of Sarmatian horsemen stationed at Hadrian's Wall. There is some historical evidence that such a man existed, but that particular Artorius Castus lived in the second century CE.This movie, however, takes place in 452 CE, about three hundred years later. Our film's Artorius Castus (Clive Owen) is half Roman-half British (Celtic), and his knights of the round table&#x2015;yes, there is a round table in the movie&#x2015;are Sarmatian cavalrymen. Let's see. The Sarmatians came from the region north of the Black Sea (present-day Ukraine), and they are known to have been closely related to the Persians. And Roman cavalry consisting of Sarmatians did serve in the Roman Army stationed in Roman Britain. But they almost certainly would not have resembled the movie's Sarmatians, and they certainly would not have had names like Lancelot, Gawain, and Galahad. These are pure Thomas Malory. I guess giving them Sarmatian names would have been too "historical." We don't need no stinkin' history to confuse things! And while we're mentioning history, all the books that I've ever read say the Roman legions departed Britain around 408 CE, forty-four years before our story takes place. Oh well. And a Roman villa north of Hadrian's Wall? I don't think so. No Roman would have been that insane. And then there's Keira Knightley (Guinevere) prancing around on the ice in a Peplos-type gown that has no more consistency than a modern nightgown. Hmm! Wouldn't she have gotten a bit chilled? Didn't appear so though. No doubt she'll be playing Queen Boudica soon.I did find the Saxon army convincing, even if they didn't use crossbows. But in Dark Age battles, it generally wasn't death to the last man. The battle stopped when one of the war-leaders was slain, and his head and hands hoisted on poles for all to see. And for those who know their "history," those nasty, brutish Saxons of course did succeed in repulsing the British (Celts), driving many of them out of what is today England into the hills of Wales and Cornwall. Some no doubt mingled with the Germanic invaders and adopted their Germanic tongue (Anglo-Saxon or Old English, which eventually evolved into Modern English). I'm leaving out two more significant invasions of England that occurred later: the Scandinavians who established the Danelaw (chiefly 9th-10th centuries) and the Norman conquest in 1066. They are not pertinent to the subject of the movie but did contribute greatly to the formation of modern England. BTW the term England comes from a variant on one of the other Germanic tribes that was invading Britain at the time, the Angles: Anglaland. Land of the Angles.It's been pointed out numerous times that Hollywood epics aren't meant to be historical. OK. Then why imply historical accuracy at the beginning? Why don't such movies just be forthright and honest? Either strive reasonably for historical accuracy or else just say that the story's meant to entertain. Unfortunately, this King Arthur lamentably falls on its face in both departments.3/10 (as I said, I liked the depiction of the Saxons)</fullReview>

		<fullReview>If your fancy takes you in the direction of a cinema showing this version of King Arthur or your TV channel of choice happens to be screening it and you fancy brushing up on your British mythology, the chances are that you will be a tad disappointed. Antoine Fuqua's take in the Arthurian legend has precious little to do with chivalry and gallant knights, pennants a blowin', saving damsels in distress. Instead there's a lot of portentous loose talk about 'freedom' and 'free will' and a storyline which is at times difficult to follow.Arthur in this version wasn't the king at Camelot, but a cavalry commander serving Rome in Britain, the son of a Roman and a British women. As played by Clive Owen, it has to be said, he comes across more as a dull real estate salesman. His bride Guinevere ? they do get hitched in the end, although she makes it obvious that she would have preferred Lancelot but he, unfortunately for them both, is killed in the final battle ? is a British woman who likes nothing better than to go into battle in skimpy clothing, but is no mean fighter.There is admittedly no definitive version of King Arthur's life despite the spurious claim when the film kicks off that archaeological evidence is being discovered that Arthur was much like the man portrayed in the film, but take that with a pinch of salt, because he probably never existed (and is probably not sleeping in some cave waiting for the call from a grateful nation to free Britain). This Arthur is very much an acquired taste. I personally prefer the 'gramercy, my liege' and 'I must shrive my soul' version of the myth.There is any number of infelicities: the tribes in the North of the islands which the wall built by Hadrian was intended to keep out were Picts and Scots, not Saxons (who didn't arrive until a couple of centuries later). And there was no such tribe as the Woads. But what the hell. This version should go down a storm with pre-pubescent lads who enjoy World of Warcraft and like a bit of fighting and carnage, but more discerning viewers will have to be pretty terminally bored and very much at a loose end to consider giving it much of their time. Basically it's hogwash ? well made hogwash, certainly, but hogwash all the same. The giveaway if the never-ending, loud and stirring soundtrack: as a rule the louder and more stirring the soundtrack is, the less real excitement a film has to offer. Oh, well. See it with your lad if you like.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>King Arthur is an ambitious attempt to wed the legend of King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table with known historical facts of the era.It stars Clive Owen as the title character together with Ioan Gruffudd as Lancelot, and Keira Knightley as Guinevere.Mads Mikkelsen,Joel Edgerton,Ray Winstone,Stephen Dillane,Stellan Skarsg?rd,Til Schweiger,Hugh Dancy and Ken Stott co-star to play key supporting roles.It was written by David Franzoni and directed by Antoine Fuqua. Arthur, a heroic knight and devoted Christian, is torn between his desire to travel to Rome to serve his faith and his loyalty to the land of his birth. As England falls into lawlessness, Arthur throws in his lot with a band of knights who hope to restore order to their fair and pleasant land and hopes to win freedom for his comrades, among them Lancelot,Galahad,Tristan,Gawain,Bors, and Dagonet. In time, Arthur and his men join forces with Merlin, a shaman whose band of renegade knights were often pitched in battle against Roman forces. Forming a united front as loyal Englishmen against the invading Saxon armies, Arthur, Merlin, and the brave and beautiful Guinevere are determined to unite a sovereign Britain under one army and one king.It's got a round table, some knights, and a noble warrior who rises to become King Arthur, but everything else about this revisionist legend is pure Hollywood and it has become a generic action film. That's not such a bad thing if you enjoyed Rob Roy, Braveheart, Gladiator, and Troy, and there's some intriguing potential in presenting the "real" Arthur as a 5th-century soldier of Rome, assigned to defend Roman-imperial England against a hoard of invading Saxons. As revamped history and "archaeological findings" would have us believe, Guinevere is a warrior babe in face-paint and Lancelot is a nonentity who fades into the woodwork. Never mind! Best to enjoy the harsh, gloomy atmosphere of Irish locations, the ruggedness of Owen and his hearty supporting cast, and the entertaining production.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Disgraceful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Nobody will ever know if Arthur existed, but what cannot be disputed are the origins of the legend. For over 1000 years the stories have evolved, and the line between myth and reality has become famously blurred.What is indisputable is that, whilst the real people who may have inspired legends have long since faded into the mists of time, their lands remain. The castles, fortresses, forests and lakes are all well documented and exist today as they did in the middle ages when the legends really came to prominence.The vast majority of places exist in the Westcountry of England, namely Cornwall, Devon and Somerset. Some also refer to South Wales. Tintagel is perhaps the one place most often linked to the birth of the legend, and remains here date from the 5th and 6th centuries with the main structure as we know it dated to the 13th century.This is the basis of the stories, and they have not changed for a millennia. Until now. This film has no historical basis at all, and clearly that can be proved. More to the point, it has no basis in any of the Arthurian legends, and that is unforgivable.Had it been presented as fantasy or fiction, and the names changed to remove any links to existing stories, it might have been acceptable. It is not a bad film, though not good by any means. The landscapes are clearly modern - hedgerows, stone walls, cropped grass and trees all point to an enclosed, livestock-based agricultural system that was non-existent in Britain until well into the middle ages.Set aside the bendy plastic swords and wood/fibreglass castle, and the film is pretty good visually, with some attempt at creating atmosphere. The camera work is good, scenery impressive, and the direction competent. Script and acting leave something to be desired.Ultimately though the film is judged by the presentation of a supposed accuracy that could not be further from reality. On that basis it is an insult and a disgrace.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I saw the extended director's cut, and I can say the fight sequences are pretty realistic.Someone criticized how ragtag and crude the Britons were, esp Merlin. After her daughters and herself were raped and beaten by the Romans, she came back with vengeance and showed no mercy. In all, she killed about 70,000 Romans.In their final historic battle, although they vastly outnumbered the Roman legion sent to subdue them, they nevertheless fell prey to superior Roman military tactics.Boudicca was never heard from again, rumored to have either been among the slaughtered, or committed suicide.So, from this perspective, the movie did a fairly accurate job in portraying the pagan tribes in Britain.HOWEVER, I can't help but compare it to Gladiator, since some who were involved in the creation of that movie were also involved in this.No doubt, the creators were aiming to make an epic as rousing as Gladiator. They certainly had the right subject matter in King Arthur.But in this effort it fell far, far short. It just didn't have the same emotional depth and resonance. I didn't find myself drawn in as much.Maybe it's unfair to draw a comparison between the two movies. 		<date>2006-06-24</date>
		<username>eht5y</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Bad, If Taken for What It Is</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'King Arthur' is a curious production that has understandably aroused quite a bit of disagreement among critics, historians, and fans of the Arthurian legend. But really--this is a Jerry Bruckheimer production, people! Let's keep the operation in perspective! Bruckheimer has always been about one thing, and one thing only: spectacle, a.k.a. cheap thrills. 'King Arthur' might be gift-wrapped as a revisionist history, but it's a popcorn movie, plain and simple, and as such, it is for the most part a success.The main premise of the film, of course, is that the Arthur of legend was not, in fact, the magical king of Camelot, but, rather, a half-Roman, half-Celtic warlord--the captain of a clan of Sarmatian knights pressed into service to the Roman Empire as young men. Our tale is narrated by Lancelot (Ioan Gruffudd), who (like Arthur) is introduced as a young boy on the day of his departure for his 15-year term of service to the Emperor of Rome. The film jumps ahead to the final days of that term, rejoining the characters as seasoned warriors: the familiar names are there--Arthur (Clive Owen) and Lancelot, joined by Gawain, Galahad, Bors, Dagonet, and Tristan. Although most of these characters bear little to no characteristic resemblance to their legendary precedents (Galahad, for instance, is traditionally described as Lancelot's son, not his contemporary; Bors is usually described as pious and devout, as opposed to his rugged, profane characterization in this film; Dagonet--heroic in this version--is usually represented as Arthur's court fool), the actors each manage to project strong, distinct characters for the audience to identify with. Especially strong are Ray Winstone (Sexy Beast) as Bors, Ray Stevenson as a quietly heroic Dagonet, and Mads Mikkelsen, who nearly steals the film as Tristan, here presented as a falconer and expert archer in Asian/Mongolian-style dress and armaments. The fine performances of these actors were clearly noted by casting directors: Winstone is set to play another early English epic hero--Beowulf--in a forthcoming adaptation; Stevenson was cast as another formidable but good-hearted warrior in HBO's 'Rome'; Mikkelsen--a star in his native Denmark, but an unknown elsewhere prior to 'King Arthur'--is set to play the villain in the forthcoming James Bond film, 'Casino Royale.' The basic plot positions Arthur and his knights as having earned their freedom towards the beginning of the Roman Empire's decline and fall. No longer able to afford the human and material expense of holding its most distant territorial outposts, Rome has decided to abandon Britain, leaving it to be fought over by its various tribal factions and invaders from neighboring lands. The history is fuzzy here, but again, this is an action movie, not a documentary, so picking apart the historical inaccuracies seems beside the point.The Romans are in full retreat, but the Bishop Germanius (Ivano Marescotti) won't give the Sarmatian knights their discharge papers until they complete a final task: rescue a young Roman noble beloved by the Pope whose family estate lies in the path of the Saxon invaders. The men reluctantly accept the charge out of loyalty to Arthur, who prays to his Christian god for the safety of his pagan knights (another big deviation from Arthurian legend, in which Christianity figures heavily as part of the code of chivalry).The film's advertising gives top-billing (along with the infamous digitally-enhanced bust) to the sublime Keira Knightley, but her Guinevere appears late in the action, so don't rent this one expecting to see too much of her. In this version of the story, Guinevere is the daughter of Merlin (Steven Dillane), who is initially Arthur's enemy, as he leads a tribe of Woads (a version of the Picts), native peoples of Britain who wage war on the Roman invaders Arthur and his Sarmatian Knights serve. Eventually, Arthur and Merlin join forces (thanks to Guinevere) to defend Britain against the invading Saxons, led by Cerdic (Stellan Skaarsgard, who seems to be really enjoying himself playing a bloodthirsty viking).This scenario affords director Antoine Fuqua plenty of room for expansive battle sequences, some of which meet and even exceed the standard set by 'Braveheart' for the genre. There's quite a bit of gore, and at times the battles seem endless and repetitive, though there are a few fine sequences, especially a battle that takes place on the frozen surface of a lake (nevermind that a Saxon army would never have invaded in winter; snow battles are cool!). The first half of the film allows for some nice, subtle character development for the knights, but without the familiar antagonists and problems (Mordred, Morgan La Fey, the Lancelot-Guinevere-Arthur love triangle, which is barely hinted at in the film), Arthur is a generic hero whose battle-cries for freedom are both contradictory and achingly derivative of 'Braveheart.' Clive Owen is a fine actor who acquaints himself well here, but his character is dull and one-dimensional, and seems much less compelling than secondary characters like the enigmatic Merlin, the intrepid Tristan, and the courageous Dagonet.Nevertheless, I felt like I got what I paid for from 'King Arthur.' The acting is above average, the costumes are cool, the villain is nasty and scary, the fight sequences are well-staged and visceral, and the soundtrack appropriately martial and dramatic. While I can understand why Old English history and Arthurian legend buffs might object to it, I think I'd prefer this film to one which tried to recreate the aspects of the myth already portrayed in other Arthur films, especially 'Excalibur,' which, for my money, is the gold standard of King Arthur flicks.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>If you liked "Gladiator", "Troy" or "Kingdom of Heaven", you will probably like King Arthur. These are not the knights of "A Knights Tale". 		<username>bas rutten</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>I liked it in spite of some rather serious flaws</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>-- Based on the Director's Cut -- If anything, this movie is a highly unusual take at the beloved legend of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table. In fact, apart from the names of the characters and the location (England), it has next to nothing to do with it. Also, in spite of claims that this is the "true" story of King Arthur, I seriously doubt that this has much to do with real history. Sure, there were Romans in England, and Hadrian's Wall was a real structure, but this movie is full of historical inaccuracies and anachronisms. I have nothing against this, but please don't claim it's the real story when it really just isn't.Another gripe I have with this movie is that the legend of King Arthur is abused to tell a very contemporary and rather moralistic story of freedom and equality. I love freedom and equality as much as anybody, but trust me, this is something people in the Roman and Middle Ages really weren't familiar with and that didn't start appearing until the 18th century. It also doesn't help that there are some fairly easy-to-point-out inconsistencies in the entire story: if Arthur values equality so much, then why does he become a king (who is by definition not equal to the rest of his people) and how does he combine his belief in free will with his belief that it's God's will that Lancelot dies instead of him? Then again, maybe I'm reading a bit too much into this. In spite of its fairly heavy-handed approach, this really isn't a movie that shouldn't be taken too seriously. And judged as entertainment only it's certainly very decent. For one, Arthur and his knights are a very charming bunch, and they really come to live due to some fine acting. Of course they're all pretty flat characters, but they ARE colorful.Next, "King Arthur" looks absolutely marvelous. The landscapes, shrouded in fog and snow, are a sight to behold, and combined with the great musical score and the good-looking costume and set design they do create a really epic atmosphere.Also, I have to say that I really did enjoy the action sequences. For the most part, they are truly spectacular, without ever becoming too unrealistic (no bullet time here, fortunately, just good old-fashioned sword fighting). There's also plenty of gore, at least in the director's cut that I watched. Also, fortunately, the action doesn't suffer from the frenzied editing style often seen in similar movies: at least, here you can see what's going on.In the end, this leaves me with mixed feelings about this movie. For the most part, it's a really well-made, exciting action movie. It's just a shame that it takes itself so dreadfully seriously, with a rather clumsy message and a lot of false claims about historical accuracy.*** out of *****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A much different King Arthur tale, I like it!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It is well established now that many negative comments and reviews have been written against this version of the 'King Arthur' tales. His men were looking forward to settling down somewhere in England, south of the Hadrian Wall. The north section was over run with Saxon heathens who took pleasure in killing their adversaries.There was a catch. A bishop representing Rome gave Arthur and his men one last assignment, to go into the north of England and rescue a young nephew of favor, and see that he was sent to Rome unharmed. A difficult task, but Arthur and his men made it, the defining battle came on a frozen lake, and sacrificing his life ultimately, one of Athhur's men used his axe to crack the ice to seal the fate of the enemies.Safely south of the 'wall', Arthur's men were content to be headed home after being given their freedom. But Arthur decided to stay and fight, his homeland, England, was worth it. His men after a short while turned around and joined him in a fierce battle. Guinevere, whom Arthur had rescued from an unholy prison when north of the 'wall' turned out to be a fierce fighter also. In the final battle, just south of the 'wall', and using smoke and fire as part of the strategy, killed all the invading Saxons from the north. In the end, there was a simple ceremony near the sea, amidst a structure of large stones similar to Stonehenge, where Arthur and Guinevere are married and Arthur is chosen as king. The idea that being king is an achievement, not something you get just by pulling a sword out of a grave or a stone.Ioan Gruffudd was Lancelot, Joel Edgerton was Gawain, Hugh Dancy was Galahad, Ray Winstone was great as large and excitable Bors, Keira Knightley was a sightly Guinevere, and perhaps the best was Stellan Skarsg?rd as Cerdic, the leader of the band of invading Saxons, a powerful warrior who would not hesitate to put a knife through his own son's heart if he thought he was giving less than 100% effort and loyalty. His final battle was the showdown with Arthur.</fullReview>
