		<date>2004-12-12</date>
		<username>mentalcritic</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Caught firmly in no man's land...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The legend of Arthur, an early King of what would eventually become the so-called United Kingdom, has been rendered in many ways. It has been done as a serious drama, a comedy, and even a cameo appearance at the end of a Kevin Costner film, where Arthur was, ironically, played by Sean Connery, a fierce Scottish nationalist. Jerry Bruckheimer, however, pulls off a Peter Jackson by taking one of Britain's most revered legends and pulling it down to the lowest common denominator.If Bruckheimer's goal was to make Jackson's rendition of Return Of The King look good, he failed by making King Arthur at least somewhat cohesive. And therein lies the big problem. It is not good enough to work on its own merit, and yet it is not bad enough to be good as an unintentional comedy. So all around, the entire film can be stated as a failure that sits in no man's land.Let's start with the casting. The Knights are not well-developed enough to really be memorable, but the actors make a decent enough fist of them to at least say they put in the effort. Even Lancelot, who is presented as being ambidextrous here, really doesn't get much more than one dimension. But the real problem here is the man they cast to play King Arthur. Clive Owen, whose inauspicious performance in Beyond Borders was enough to make many a struggling actor wonder why they bother trying to develop their craft, is so unconvincing that it is hardly any wonder this effort literally came and went by itself at the box office. He sounds more like a member of the Trainspotting cast than a Roman Knight. Keira Knightley, in the role of Guinevere, acts rings around him.Another big problem is all the made-up elements that try to demystify the Arthur legend. I can accept the idea of Arthur and his compatriots starting out as a Roman Knight, becoming disillusioned with Rome, and forming a Kingdom in Great Britain. What I cannot believe is Saxons, Woads, and Romans all fighting one another in the same island and time period. In the time period claimed for this film, the Romans would be fighting Celts and/or Gauls. The only reference to Woad I can find in more credible stories is the plant's use to paint the faces of guerrilla raiders who sacked English encampments in Scotland, about a thousand years after the Norman sacking of England. Speaking of which, no mention is made anywhere of Normans.But it gets worse. Although the battle scenes are beautifully shot (no shaky-cam here, thankfully), the sheer number of mechanical and scientific inaccuracies is dazzling. In one battle that takes place on ice, a Saxon archer fires an arrow at the Knights, only to have it stop short. While I can accept that the Knights may have bows with better range, what I can't stomach is how the Saxons with crossbows don't line up and fire instead, at least not until they're nearly a mere forty feet away from the Knights. Crossbows fling bolts at a much faster speed than bows can ever hope to accomplish, and therefore should have a much greater range, not to mention armour-piercing ability, than the bows. I also find it difficult to believe that the "Woads", who do not even seem to have basic housing, can slap together trebuchets for a major battle.Then again, given that they couldn't even get the accentuation in Stellan Skarsg?rd's name right, I would hardly expect a Bruckheimer production to correctly depict logistics of fifth-century English warfare.I gave the director's cut of King Arthur a two out of ten. The acting is sometimes bad enough to appall, but not bad enough to amuse. Ditto for the script, the effects, and most of the designs. As a result, King Arthur stands firmly in No Man's Land. It is worth watching once, just for a bit of amusement (preferably while you are doing something else, just so the time is not completely wasted), but this is far from a keeper.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-08-02</date>
		<username>Tom Clarke (tjcclarke@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>History for Dummies</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Much has been made of the historical significance of Antoine Fuqua's take on the story of Arthur and his knights. The ad men purport it to be the `untold true story that inspired the legend', while scornful detractors have dismissed it as being as fictional as the traditional myth. Unfortunately, the end product leaves the viewer caring little either way.Far from the magical medieval world of Camelot with all its swashbuckling sword-fights and sorcery, Fuqua sets his story a thousand years earlier in the barren, misty wastelands of Northern England. A group of Sarmatian conscripts plucked as boys from their Eastern European homeland to fulfil a debt of gratitude to the Romans have just completed their 15 year tour of duty in Britain. Having served under legendary Roman soldier Arthur (Clive Owen), they have developed into a tight-knit fighting unit revered by their public and feared by the insurgents who plot raids from North of Hadrian's Wall.The Romans' occupancy of Britain is coming to an end. Arthur dreams of a return to Rome with all its culture and liberty, while his knights are looking forward to going home to Sarmatia, but before they can leave they are given one final mission to rescue a wealthy Roman family caught in the far North in the middle of a Saxon invasion.Hence we have the time-honoured scenario of a bunch of brave warriors outnumbered by thousands to one marching glibly into certain death, wise-cracking all the way. It is fairly standard stuff: The pretty boys with the wavy locks, neatly trimmed beards and chiselled features, led by the irritatingly handsome Lancelot (Ioan Gruffudd) are offset by the lumbering, gurning Bors (Ray Winstone). All are fairly tidy in the fighting department, though it helps that arrows seem to bounce off them and opponents appear to queue patiently before being slaughtered by axe or sword. This film is so full of epic-battle, courage-under-fire staples and stereotypes, it makes it hard to take its sincere historical credentials seriously.It doesn't help that Jerry Bruckheimer (never a man to favour substance over style) is producing it. With him, it seems, all subtlety and nuance is immediately binned in favour of another sweeping battle scene or Ray Winstone making tiresome gags about flatulence. Which is a shame, because there is a lot of potential intrigue amongst the trite, ham-fisted set-pieces. Lancelot and Arthur are best chums, but both harbour feelings for the beguiling Guinevere (Keira Knightley). You get the impression Fuqua is keen to explore this conflict more, but was perhaps vetoed by Bruckheimer who evidently wanted to forego an emotion-wrought love triangle in favour of more footage of men in armour running at each other really fast.Performance-wise, King Arthur is adequate, but it is very difficult for actors to be believable when they are spouting such clichéd, clunking dialogue. When it comes to brooding, it is hard to match Owen, but he is hardly physically imposing. When he brazenly stands alone on a hilltop in full battle regalia facing hordes of Saxons, he is not so much the bristling epitome of menace as the simpering pinnacle of high camp. As it becomes clear to him that his beloved Rome is tarnished with corruption and greed, he faces an identity crisis: Half-Roman and half-Briton, he is forced make decisions about who or what he must fight for, but all his inner demons are masked by the same drab, humourless expression. Even the prospect of bedding Knightley isn't enough to put a smile on his face. There is just no pleasing some people.The rest of the cast are OK. Winstone is ludicrously over-the-top as the boisterous Bors and Stellan Skarsgard is a scene-stealer as the Saxon leader Cerdic. The excellent Australian actor Joel Edgerton plays Gawain, but is underrated and hence woefully underused. None of them, however, are good enough to make this anything other than a turgid time-filler.Bragging about accuracy is fine, but to then employ every unimaginative device in the book is nonsensical. The Saxons here are portrayed as filthy, snarling savages raping, pillaging and looting their way through the countryside while the knights have honour, comradery and dashing good looks on their side. Fuqua would have been better off saying `bugger historical precision', slapping a pair of tights on Gruffudd and Owen and settling for a more traditional Camelot. Instead we have ghastly allusions to the established Authurian legend ? the scene where Arthur retrieves Excalibur from the stone is particularly awful, and Merlin, instead of being a kindly old wizard, is a bizarre tree-hugging loon caked in body paint.It is difficult to be too critical. Filmmakers deserve credit for trying new ideas and straying from the beaten path, but this effort doesn't know whether to be wholly original or stick to well-worn formulas and it ends up as a curious hybrid of the two. There is no mystery and no magic, but nothing new cinematically either. The film itself is, like the argument between the producers and the historians, essentially pointless. 6/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>It had the potential...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I happen to be a big fan of epic films. You know, films set in the time where sword and bow where the only weapons, and grand warriors and heroes grace the screen. Action scenes are usually abundant, vast and hugely entertaining. Large armies clashing in the scene, trying to cut each others throat by any means necessary.None of these things fit into this movie, sadly. It had the potential to become a great action/adventure/epic. But many things dragged this film down. Mainly the script, which was average at best. Only thing that is relevant in this film is the main plot, even tho there are several subplots. To bad the subplots are extremely poorly written and executed. They could be cut out of the film completely, and it would actually have made a better movie. OK, so let me get going with the story...In 300 A.D. the romans waged war against the Sarmatians, whom they defeated. However, they were so impressed with the Sarmatians fighting skills that they let them live, in exchange for them fighting in the roman army. This deal would not only go for the sarmatians who survived the battle, but all sarmatians, and their sons and grandsons and so forth. Now, fastforward to 452. Lancelot, Bors, Gawain, Galahad, Dagonet and Tristan are all young Sarmatian boys who live in a village. One day the roman arrive and take the young boys with them, so that they can serve the Roman Empire. The boys are stationed in southern Britain, under the command of Arthur...15 years later, the boys have almost fulfilled their deal with the Empire, and are ready to go home to their native lands. However, they are given one last assignment: They must travel north, into the lands of their enemy, and fetch a Roman noble. The reason for this is that the Saxxons are invading the lands from the North, and the Roman empire can stand no chance against them.Hmm... Could certainly be a good plot there. But it isn't. The movie tries to introduce to many characters. The only characters that get a real development are Arthur and Guinevere. Not even Lancelot, who is supposed to be the third main character in the film, feels anymore alive than any of the other knights. And they are all 1-dimensional. This is basically the character development done for the knights: "We want to see our native lands. We hate Rome. We fight for a cause that isn't ours.". And that's it. This is all done in the first twenty minutes of the film. Speaking of characters, the knights are not the only 1-dimensional characters in this film. Merlin is pretty much in two scenes. Why the heck did they even put him in there? He serves no purpose whatsoever! Guinevere gets some screen time as she claims that Britan is "her land" and that she "belongs to it". OK. That's it for Guinevere. Oh, and she heals rapidly, too, she must be some kind of medieval Wolverine. One day she is found tortured, pale and badly beaten. Her hand is pretty much broken. But hey, the next day she is up there, standing with the knights, fending off the evil Saxxons. Interesting. Oh, and speaking of Saxxon, I have never witnessed such a poorly executed gang of bad people. Their leader, Cedric, is seen bossing them around in a few scenes, saying intuitive and clever things such as "Burn the village..." or "Kill her..." or even "Obey me or die...". And that's it for him. He has a son too, who seems to care more for his men than Cedric does, but never challenges Cedric to a duel in order to take his place as the leader, even though he watches Cedric willingly slaughtered his sons group of warriors. Man, those saxxons are stupid. And not only are they stupid, their reputation doesn't really do them justice. In the film, the romans fear them. They even flee from Britain in order to avoid dealing with them. Yet, when it comes down to fighting, the Saxxons ENTIRE ARMY, are easily dispatched by seven knights and a group of perhaps 200 native people, with horrible fighting skills (and don't say they were good fighters, cause in the first battle of the film, the woads were slaughtered without really killing anyone, even though they vastly outnumbered the romans). Conclusion: Saxxons really suck ass. The knights could probably have taken them down themselves. In every battle, the Saxxons are completely slaughtered... And we're supposed to fear these barbarians? A group of peasants could easily have taken them down.Some of the acting is pretty horrible too. Clive Owen was definitely the wrong choice for Arthur... But that's all I'm gonna say. The only thing about this film was the score. It was pretty good, but not great. The soundtrack is probably better than the film itself. I think I might actually pick that up.Toss out all logic, all dreams of having an interesting story, all character development and add ONE half-decent battle scene. And you get King Arthur. Sounds good, eh?4/10.</fullReview>

I try to keep an open mind going into it, but I find that it's hard to do. Bruckheimer's films are known to be showy and big-budget, but lacking in cinematic elements, such as script and plot. And when you have a movie that's based off of something well known, such as the legend of King Arthur, you need those elements. Unless, of course, you change what you say "actually happened". Then you can get away with it, and Bruckheimer continues his streak of mediocre films with large budgets.Instead of focusing on anything that people know about Arthur, Arthur (Clive Owen, from the wonderful Croupier) and his Knights of the Round Table have to go out to Britain and get a boy who will become bishop (or Pope). There are supposed to be many dangers. Guinevere (Keira Knightley) is rescued about halfway through, and becomes a fearsome warrior a few times before going to the background. There's also some stupid animal symbolism and morals thrown in, along with neo-feminism and Stellan Skarsg?rd with a braided beard.The battle scenes were quite good. Unlike so many other movies out there, they never got old or repetitive. They were pretty exciting and involving. It seems like the whole movie was leading up to the final battle scene, with good reason. But that leaves no room for any real relationship to develop with Guinevere and Arthur (and Lancelot, as the story goes), and it basically makes the first half useless, since it's resolved so early. It's almost like two separate movies there. Also, there's almost no character development. Merlin comes in once, and Skarsg?rd, as a random Saxon warrior appears randomly. WHO is he? The Knights' names are barely mentioned. I wish I knew who played the large, ax-throwing guy, because kudos to him. Knightley, besides being in the film for about 20 minutes, puts in a one-note role and now seems to be a teen idol. I liked her better when she was in things like Bend It Like Beckham. She's just here to draw in audiences. And Skarsg?rd, who I'm looking forward to seeing in Exorcist: The Beginning later this summer, has fun with his role. King Arthur is an unmemorable but entertaining movie that plays faster and looser with facts than Michael Moore. But it's worth a visit if you're bored.My rating: 6/10Rated PG-13 for intense battle sequences, a scene of sensuality and some language.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Unique, savage, beautiful, reverent</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>King Arthur - The Director's Cut (Widescreen, 2004). Runtime: 142 minutes."King Arthur" sheds the legend and theorizes the true story of the British leader of the late 5th and early 6th centuries, who led the defense of Britain against Germanic invaders (the Saxons) in the early 6th century as the Roman Empire was crumbling.This is Medieval-British Isle flick in the tradition of the three 1995 films "Braveheart," "Rob Roy" and "First Knight," as well as 2006's totally underrated "Tristan and Isolde," which I feel is the best of the batch."King Arthur" is my second favorite, followed by the underrated "Centurion" from 2010. "King Arthur" is visually gorgeous, shot mainly in Ireland, but also Wales and England. It has a good assortment of actors, including Clive Owen as Arthur, Ioan Gruffudd as Lancelot, Keira Knightley as Guinevere, Ray Winstone as Bors, Stephen Dillane as Merlin and an outstanding performance by Stellan Skarsg?rd as the Saxon villain, Cerdic. Although I'm not a huge fan of Keira she certainly has a striking face, utilized to great effect in this film, and she looks awesome as a blue-painted Pictish warrior (i.e. a "Woad").The soundtrack is good and is sometimes reminiscent of "The Last of the Mohicans" (1992), but blander and nowhere near as overpowering.The theme here, other than duty and war, is that of finding one's true home and calling. Many of us dream of "home" as some far-off place to find in the near or far future, but home may be closer than we think. We just need to be open and open our eyes. This reminds me of this story of a Texas minister who wanted to move to a place with small lakes &amp; springs, etc. and the LORD told him it was ALREADY there on his property, he just had to use his imagination and create it. So he made some small lakes on his property with seven springs, as well as other modifications. Later, when his father was visiting, the subject of vacationing came up. His dad confessed that he enjoyed coming to his son's house rather than traveling elsewhere because it was so beautiful and peaceful that it felt like paradise. The minister learned a lesson: You might be sitting on your paradise (or "home") and just don't realize it. In short, quit looking for the greener grass somewhere else and simply open your eyes! FINAL WORD: I put off seeing "King Arthur" all these years for no particular reason and, after finally viewing it, I must say it's much different than what I expected. I expected another take on the legend like "First Knight" or "Excalibur" (not that those two films are in any way interchangeable), but "King Arthur" is totally different. It's got a unique story, full of savage Medieval action, but it also possesses an undeniable air of beauty and reverence with quite a few epic/dramatic moments.GRADE: B+ or A-</fullReview>

Secondly, the clothing she wore? She would have been branded a harlot and hung/drowned/burned at the stake. It's not as simple as, reset, wait a day or two, and you're back to normal. Doesn't work that way. And there's no way a woman of her size, with or without broken fingers, would have been able to shoot a bow of that size and make as far as the men. Not possible. There's no redeeming qualities to this movie whatsoever, other than the shots of the scenery, which were quite beautiful. Otherwise... It was a puke fest, the whole way through.</fullReview>

The rest of Arthur's knights role is too limited to get emotional involved with any of them (With the exception of Lancelot, who disappointingly gets killed at the ending, which also makes it even weirder that the story is somewhat told from Lancelot's perspective and even begins with his character narration followed by his youth.) and I still don't know who is who exactly.The actors give the best they got but the dialogs are just plain weak at times, which makes their acting performances also look silly at times.But still as entertainment this movie is perfectly watchable. It's obvious that Antoine Fuqua is a great action movie director. The battles are looking good and spectacular but unfortunately the story and characters make sure that this movie is also a forgettable one. The atmosphere was better than I expected. I don't know but for some reason I expected this movie to be full of far too bright colors (Maybe it's because of the movie its reddish cover?). The musical score by Hans Zimmer is good on its own but isn't really ever able to sparkle in the movie itself. If your able to ignore all the inaccuracies and poor character treatment, you might be able to enjoy "King Arhur" as pure entertainment.6/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>It's a great shame that a great legend was turned into Hollywood tripe.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A big budget film based on the Arthurian legend sounds like a great idea for modern technology to tackle. There's more than enough about this great piece of legend to make a great film, so when I heard that one was being made I was relatively excited to see it. That is until I heard that Jerry Bruckheimer was set to produce the project, and then all hope of it being any good faded. Bruckheimer, with his 'high concept' films has become well known for creating overblown pieces of trash, and that's exactly what this film is, I'm sad to say. Most probably in the name of entertainment, this film claims to be about the 'true' events of King Arthur's life, and this means that King Arthur and the noble knights of the round table have been miscast as a bunch of thugs that wouldn't look out of place in a post-Lock, Stock gangster flick. This silliness puts it on the back foot from the offset and it never regains it's footing, as it's hard to take a bunch of fifteenth century knights that sound like gangsters seriously.This film's main problem is that, like The Last Samurai before it, it's simply too ridiculous. For most of the movie Clive Owen looks bored, and for the other half he's making 'awe-inspiring' speeches to his men, and the performance doesn't bode well on the whole at all. I don't know what's going on lately, but it seems nowadays every film of this nature has to include the hero giving speeches to his men about the virtues of freedom and whatnot, and it never quite works as it should. The overbearing soundtrack doesn't exactly do the film any favours either and merely serves in making the finished article more ridiculous (which is basically exactly what a score shouldn't do), and a torrid script that features any number of the daft moments that I mentioned earlier also drags the film down. It's a shame that all historical epics these days have to be in the style of Lord of Rings; comic book battles don't work well with a film that is supposed to be based on one of the greatest legends of all time.Like most people, my number one reason for seeing this film after I found out Bruckheimer was involved was Keira Knightly. Knightly was voted sexiest movie star by Empire magazine recently, and although this isn't true; she's very sexy. I haven't thought much to her before this movie, as she tends to either star in movies I couldn't care less about, or not look particularly startling in the ones I do. Here, however; she gets to wear skimpy outfits, have her hair dark and generally look very sexy. But...there's a catch. You have to wait almost an hour before she makes her appearance, which isn't good when you're spending that hour waiting on it as there isn't much to entertain you in the meantime. As you might expect, all of her best moments are included in the trailer anyway, so when she does appear it isn't that good as you've seen her best moments from the trailer. I suppose it's probably better if you haven't seen the trailer...or the film.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>After fifteen years "in service" of the ruling Roman Empire, the Sarmatian knights are to be given their freedom as the Roman Empire prepares to withdraw from the hard to defend, outlying colonies. However on the very day of their freedom, Arthur, their leader, is given a final mission to head north and bring back one of the Pope's favourite godsons. The Saxons have invaded the north and their army is sweeping south and Arthur's men reluctantly accept their duty. Heading directly into the path of the Saxons, Arthur finds not only the boy Honorius but also villages of people he cannot leave behind, including a captured woman from the Woads ? the English rebels.With middling reviews (lets be honest) and not any real interest in the first place, it was no wonder that I decided to leave this film until such a time that it came to DVD or something like that and, this week, it did just that and I relented. While the film is undeniably "good" it is perhaps a bit too gritty and low-key for its own good ? certainly it never gets the feeling of grandness that comes with, say, Gladiator. It is still quite good though because of this same grit and low-key approach, I was more convinced by this than the sweeping sentiment of some other films or the focus on the magical side of the Arthur legend of other versions. The slow pace may put off some viewers and I know that many have complained about the lack of real gore and excitement but these were both things I could cope with and suited the whole mood the of the film. One thing I would have liked would have been better development of the characters but then they were still sturdy enough to do the job.The cast are a bit mixed but they serve the material well despite being perhaps being a bit too modern at times. Owen is a strong jawed presence and he suits this sort of role ? manly but not macho, suave but able to get gritty (sound like any other famous character?). He is well supported by a cheeky Winstone within a strong group that also includes manly performances from Gruffudd, Dancy and others. Knightly hasn't convinced me she is anything other than the next pretty young thing yet but she is a good presence here, even if her Guinevere smacks a bit too much of modern sexual treatment rather than a supposedly "realistic" portrayal of who she would have been ? still, as a male fantasy she still works well while also doing enough to convince as a woman opposite Arthur. Skarsgard does the minimum but still is an enjoyable main baddie. Generally the cast do help the material by adding a bit of gruff humanity to it.Overall this is a good film but the lack of anything that special prevents it from really sticking in the mind. It is enjoyably low-key and gritty even if its claims of realism didn't really convince me that much! The pace is mostly slow but with tension and atmosphere and the battle scenes are enjoyable even if they do lack a bit of the sweeping majesty that many will have come expecting due to other films in the similar vein doing it.</fullReview>

This story follows the legend of a Roman figure named Arturius. Arturius is a good Christian and loyal Roman that believes in the inherent freedom and equality of every man. Beliefs at odds with the Roman Empire. The storyline concerns him and his small band of knights as they believe they are free of their tour of duty in Britain. Instead they are given one last impossible task. Of course they complete the task. (What good are 200+ Saxons when faced down by 7 Roman knights and a bow-wielding Guinevere.) At the end Arturius joins Merlin and the locals (the very rebels he just spent 15 years keeping under control for the Roman empire) and defeats an obscenely large Saxon army. (By the way, how do the rebels--that live on the North side of the wall, only fight Arturius with axes, a few rusted swords, bows and arrows--suddenly show up on the South side of the wall with half a dozen trebuchets ready to go?) All the characters we do associate with the legend are in the movie. Some of them are very different from what people might expect. Merlin, most of all. Merlin is written as the rebel leader originally fighting Arturius, but the story doesn't allow us to know anything about him. We can't even tell if he's particularly wise, let alone a decent leader.Keira Knightley is always a pleasure to look at. But she wasn't given much to work with. And no matter whether or not you buy this is the true Arthurian legend (as the movie claims) or not it is tough to stomach the idea that the best fighter in all of Britain outside of Arturius and his band of knights is skinny little waif of a woman recently freed from torture, starvation and near death. Clive Oven looks every inch the conflicted loyal Roman leader. Unfortunately too many times the dialogue sounds more like political speeches than any type of conversation actual people would have. The rest of the actors did as much as they could with the limited writing.The cinematography was good. The actions sequences fast-paced, if a little unrealistic.If you enjoy movies where action is a premium over story, dialogue and character development this is for you. This movie was promoted when it was released as the true historical portrait of King Arthur (someone who, most likely, never existed), so it's fair to question this aspect of the movie. According to this film, Arthur was a Roman general who, by the time of the withdrawal of the Roman troops from the British Isles in the 5th century, decided to join the Celtic locals against the Germanic invaders and eventually become their king. Well, where one can start? With Arthur's warriors shown as improbable proto Russians? With its anachronic portrayal of the Catholic Church, already more powerful than the Roman empire and engaging in the inquisition (an invention from the late middle ages)?. With its laughable references to historical figures like Bishop Germanius and the heretic writer Pelagius? If you want to see an entertaining movie, you might enjoy this film, but if you have some interest in the history of the period, you are bound to came out very disappointed.</fullReview>

Clive Owen's Arthur was a warrior, and a visionary, but also a flawed, rather never human being. Guinevere was portrayed as lovely, and resourceful; strong-willed, and fragile; treacherous, and arrogant. There are also Grade-A performances from the actors who portrayed the knights.I thought there was one, really rich irony that was left out of the movie for narrative reasons, and it's kind of shame because it really lends credence to the adage that there is no black, and white, only shades of gray. Arturus provided the legendary name, but it was another historical figure who actually embodied King Arthur's courage, and inestimable character. That person was (drum roll): Alfred of West Saxons--the King of England following the roman withdrawal from the British isles. So, a member of the invading army we saw in the film actually added to the Arthurian mythos. In the future, it would be interesting to see a drama that compares, and contrasts these two individuals who did so much to shape the face of British, colonial history.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I waited for King Arthur with great anticipation (quoting bishop Germanus) and I was more than satisfied. It stands above the common movie with the common clichés which is something that has particularly impressed me. Keira Knightley has been the perfect choice for the role of Guinevere, although perhaps a slightly older actress (like Sophie Marceau a few years ago) would have a very good choice indeed and Clive Owen is an excellent actor for the pragmatic and idealist role of Artorius Castus. The background of the characters could have been developed, I'm referring in particular to the conflict between Pelagius and those loyal to Germanus and the Woads themselves. Alike the LOTR most of the setting was actually built, something that I will always appreciate in any movie. Furthermore the sceneries and the atmosphere that surrounds the movie leaves the mystical imprint of the lands of Scotland and Northern England. There is an important balance between action scenes, narration scenes and scenes that lead the viewer to ponder over universal themes like religion and the freedom of men. There are various side-scenes which do not follow the general storyline but give the characters a chance to evolve and open themselves to the viewer which is fantastic, I'm referring to, in particular, to the scene of the Christian shrine where pagans were tortured which has an important outcome on Arthur's judgment of the ideals he had cherished for so long. The use of actors who do not appear in blockbusters is, again, a wise choice. I was very enthusiastic of Mads Mikkelsen, the actor who plays Bors and the actor who plays Lancelot. I've also appreciated the relationship that is built between the knights across the 15-year service period. The deaths of Dagonet, Tristan and Lancelot are much mourned for but unfortunately they become necessary to the course of events. I was very enthusiastic of the presentation of the Woads and Merlin and the language choices (both in the Woads and the Saxon). The only "coquille" as the french would say is the ending, it becomes too banal and tends to diverge to ceremony rather than effective curtain falling over the 2 hours of entertainment, the alternative ending which can be found in the bonuses of the DVD is much more effective and much more appealing, in particular for the symbolism of the little pagan child taking the sword out of the mound. I hail Fuqua for such a successful movie which has left me breathless and full of uncluttered emotions through the waves of a wondrous soundtrack.Absolutely outstanding, deserves a few nominations at the Oscar prizes and will certainly be better than the blockbuster Alexander.In some ways this movie reminds me of the 13th warrior, which again, despite a few wrong choices, was an outstanding movie for the history of the northern European cultures in the so-called dark ages.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An enjoyable possible history of Arthur and post-Rome Britons</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thoroughly enjoyed this movie, unlike most who have reviewed it. The screenplay takes a "legend" and, with the help of history of the period, rewrites it to fit what may have actually occurred.Students of history know that the story of Arthur was a fairy tale that was probably passed as lore for generations but it probably had some basis in fact. Most Britons at the time of Arthur were just being released from the subjectivity of Rome. The few that could stand on their own were probably trained as Roman soldiers. Many feel that a Roman trained Briton by the name Riotamus may have been the source of the myth of Arthur. Many of his conquests matched those of Arthur and in the same time period.The cinematography was outstanding (a la John Bormann although not as lush, which is in itself a plus since the dark ages were truly dark for many reasons). The period wear, the treatment of Merlin and the Woad, the weaponry and warring tactics were all done to satisfy historical accuracy rather than exploiting the same old story. It made this movie just that much more attractive and entertaining. I give it an 8/10 and I will definitely be purchasing the DVD.</fullReview>

Yes, the Romans were long gone by the time of this movie Pelagianism, to correct another commentator, was not all that widely embraced, after all Vortigern was a follower of Pelagius before being overthrown by Ambrosius, who supposedly handed command over to Arthur much later than this film suggests. Now, if you read Geofforey Ashe (not that idiot Monmouth) Arthur's character himself falls in line with the Riothamus (High King) theory in description and time period. I recommend, however, if you'd like to pursue the theory of a real Arthur, look up "King Arthur-The True Story" by Graham Phillips and Martin Keatman. 		<shortDescription>At least they spelt 'Arthur' right</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a medieval enthusiast and an aspiring historian, this version of a classic tale was utterly repulsive. I had several prominent problems with this retelling.The first, The time period: In this version Arthur is fighting for Rome, the Western half in particular. Historians place Arthur around 450, to 500 A.D. 50 to 90 years, after the Western half of Rome fell. If Arthur did live, (Which there is significant evidence saying that he did.) He would have been born to Uther and Igraine years after Rome was taken over by the Goths. Second: Morgan Le Fay vs. Guinevere. A more appropriate name for Guinevere in this version would have been "Morgan Le Fay," "Morgaine," or "Morgana." Guinevere was a blond, dainty, Christian woman who married Arthur only because her father forced her too. Morgan Le Fay was a pagan priestess and enemy to the throne of Arthur. Morgan was Arthurs sister, and she and Guinevere hated each other. It didn't help that Guinevere thought Morgan, and everyone like her, was a walking sin that should be killed on sight. (And historically, they were.) Third:Merlin Merlin was not someones name. LIke Morgan, it is a title meaning "lord." Arthur went through to Merlins during his rule, Taliesin (The stereotypical wise old man.) and Kevin. (The prisoner in the oak.)"King Arthur" was a big let down of a movie. The facts were off and the plot weak. A disappointment in Arthurian film.</fullReview>
